questions.text: Which of the following is not a component of the Bishop score?
questions.solution:
The type of maternal pelvis is not a component of the Bishop score.

The Bishop score is a scoring system used to assess the inducibility. It is based on the station, dilation, effacement (or length), position, and consistency of the cervix noted by doing a vaginal examination.

Note: In the modified Bishop score (1991) the effacement is replaced by a cervical length in cm.

Related Pearl: Bishop’s Score

Score 0 1 2 3
Dilatation (cm) Closed 1-2 3-4 5+
Cervical length (cm) >4 2-4 1-2 <1
Consistency Firm Medium Soft -
Position Posterior Midline Anterior -
Head-Station -3 -2 -1, 0 +1, +2

Total score = 13

Favourable= 6-13

Unfavourable= 0-5

NOTE: 6-13 seems to be a general consensus for a favorable score.

  • To be specific, according to NICE guidelines -A score of 8 or more generally indicates that the cervix is ripe. 
  • According to Williams Obstetrics (25th edition) - A score of 9 or more indicates a high likelihood of successful induction.
  • A score of 5 or less is an indication for induction by cervical ripening agents.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man with h/o dizziness and palpitations for the past few days  with past h/o ischemic heart disease is brought to the emergency in an unconscious state. His ECG is given below. The most possible diagnosis is
questions.solution:
The given ECG is suggestive of ventricular fibrillation. The clinical scenario points to the occurrence of ventricular arrhythmias which have now progressed to ventricular fibrillation.

The features in the above ECG that support the diagnosis are:

  • Disordered electrical ventricular activation with no identifiable QRS complexes
  • No identifiable P-waves, no PR interval

Possible mechanisms of ventricular fibrillation include spiral wave reentry and multiple circulating reentry wavefronts (image below).

The management of ventricular fibrillation and pulseless ventricular tachycardia is the same. Immediate chest compression is to be started.

It is of utmost necessity to defibrillate at the earliest because of the chances of survival decreases by 7-10% every minute without defibrillation.

Defibrillation involves delivering an electrical current between two pads placed on the chest so as to interrupt the disorganized cardiac activity and restore an organized cardiac rhythm or asystole for at least 5 seconds.

Related Pearl: ECG patterns of various ventricular arrhythmias

Ventricular tachycardia

 

Polymorphic ventricular tachycardia associated with QTc prolongation- Torsades de pointes

 

Ventricular flutter

 

Ventricular fibrillation

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true?

choices.text: Head circumference equals chest circumference by 9-12 months.
Birth weight doubles by 2 years and quadruples by 5 years of age.
Newborns typically regain their birth weight within 24 hours after birth.
Head circumference should be measured within 24 hours after birth.

questions.solution:
Head circumference equals chest circumference by 9-12 months.

In newborns:

  • Head circumference increases rapidly during the first year of life and is generally greater than chest circumference at birth.
  • By 9-12 months of age, head circumference typically equals chest circumference.
  • After 1 year, chest circumference tends to exceed head circumference.
  • It's important to measure head circumference accurately using the cross-tape method.
  • Head circumference should not be measured within 24 hours after birth due to molding during delivery, which can affect accuracy.
  • Birth weight typically doubles by 5 months and quadruples by 2 years of age, reflecting rapid growth and development in infancy.

 

Related Pearl: Weight and height changes in children

Term newborns may lose up to 10% of their birth weight in the first few days of life (due to extracellular fluid losses). Most healthy newborns typically regain their birth weight by 10 to 14 days. Thereafter, approximate daily weight gain is as follows :

  • 0-3 months ~ 30 grams/day
  • 3-6 months ~ 20 grams/day
  • 6-12months ~ 12-15 grams/day

Weight gained with respect to birth weight

Age Weight
5 months 2 × birth weight
1 year 3 × birth weight
2 years 4 × birth weight
3 years 5 × birth weight

Formulae for calculating the weight in children

Age Formula
3-12 months
Weight =[age (months) + 9]
2
1-6 years Weight = [2×age (years)] + 8
7-12 years
Weight = [7×age (years) - 5]
2

Height with respect to age

Age Height
At birth 50 cm
6 months 65 cm
1 year 75 cm
2 years 90 cm
4 years 100 cm

questions.text: A 50-year-old man comes to the clinic with a fever for 3 days associated with chills, rigors and multiple painless lesions on palms as below.  He has a history of prosthetic valve surgery and cardiac auscultation shows a new-onset systolic murmur in the mitral region. Which of the following is not seen in this disease?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of infective endocarditis (IE). Sydenham's chorea is a late-stage manifestation of rheumatic fever, not infectious endocarditis.

Fever PLUS a new-onset systolic murmur in the mitral region with a history of prosthetic valve surgery is strongly suggestive of infective endocarditis.

The skin lesions shown in the image are Janeway lesions. They are non-tender, erythematous or hemorrhagic macular or nodular lesions, which are present on the palms or soles.

Infective endocarditis is the infection of the endocardial layer of the heart. It may involve the endocardial layer over the heart valves, mural endocardium or septum. However, it can also affect intracardiac devices.

Risk factors for Infectious Endocarditis (IE):

  • Age >60 years
  • Male sex
  • Injection drug use
  • Poor dentition, dental infection or inadequate antimicrobial microbial prophylaxis
  • Structural heart disease
  • Valvular disease
  • Congenital heart disease
  • Prosthetic heart valves
  • History of IE
  • Intravascular devices
  • Implantable cardiac devices
  • Transcatheter aortic valve replacement
  • Chronic hemodialysis
  • HIV infection

Clinical features of left-sided endocarditis include:

  • Fever with chills, anorexia, weight loss, malaise, headache, night sweats, abdominal pain and arthralgias
  • Cardiac murmurs, valvular insufficiency, heart failure
  • Splenomegaly, splenic infarction, renal infarction, glomerulonephritis
  • Embolic stroke, intracerebral hemorrhage
  • Vertebral osteomyelitis, septic arthritis, and abscesses
  • Peripheral manifestations

Peripheral manifestations of infective endocarditis include the following:

  • Petechiae: Common but nonspecific finding.
  • Osler nodes: Tender subcutaneous nodules usually found on the distal pads of the digits.
  • Janeway lesions: Nontender maculae on the palms and soles.
  • Roth spots: Relatively rare retinal hemorrhages with small, clear centers.

An image showing Roth's spots which are exudative hemorrhagic lesions.

An image showing Janeway lesions.

An image showing Osler's nodes.

A clinical image of splinter hemorrhages, which should prompt suspicion for infective endocarditis :

Treatment of infective endocarditis
Streptococci Penicillin with gentamicin
Staphylococcus aureus infecting native valve Vancomycin
Staphylococcus aureus infecting prosthetic valves Vancomycin +gentamicin +rifampin
Enterococci Ampicillin with gentamicin
HACEK group Ceftriaxone or ampicillin with sulbactam
Coxiella burnetti Doxycycline with hydroxychloroquine
Bartonella Doxycycline with gentamicin

Related Pearl: Modified Duke's criteria for diagnosis of infective endocarditis

Diagnosis of Infective endocarditis is by Duke's Criteria, which requires either:

  1. Clinical criteria
  2. Pathologic criteria

If clinical criteria are used, definitive endocarditis is defined by the presence of 2 major or 1 major + 3 minor or 5 minor criteria.

Presence of single pathological criteria is definitive of infective endocarditis.

Clinical Criteria

Major Criteria

1. Positive blood culture

Typical microorganism for IE from 2 separate blood cultures.

(or)

Persistently positive blood culture of an organism consistent with IE from:

  • Blood cultures drawn >12 h apart.
  • All of 3 or a majority of ≥4 separate blood cultures, with first and last drawn at least 1 h apart.

(or)

Single positive blood culture for Coxiella burnetti or phase I IgG antibody titer of >1:800.

 

2. Evidence of endocardial involvement

Echocardiographic identification of oscillating intracardiac mass on valve or implant or in the path of regurgitant jets

(or)

New Valvular regurgitation

Minor Criteria

1. Predisposing heart lesion or intravenous drug use

2. Fever ≥38.0°C (≥100.4°F)

3. Vascular lesions: Major arterial emboli, septic pulmonary infarcts, mycotic aneurysm, intracranial hemorrhage, conjunctival hemorrhages, Janeway lesions.

4. Immunological evidence: Glomerulonephritis, Osler nodes, Roth spots, rheumatoid factor.

5. Microbiologic evidence: Positive blood culture but not meeting the major criterion, or serologic evidence of active infection with an organism consistent with infective endocarditis.

 

Pathological Criteria

1. Microorganisms demonstrated by culture or histologic examination, in vegetation, embolus from vegetation, or intracardiac abscess

(or)

2. Histologic confirmation of active endocarditis in vegetation or intracardiac abscess

Note: The diagnosis of endocarditis is rejected if an alternative diagnosis is established, if symptoms resolve and do not recur with ≤4 days of antibiotic therapy, or if surgery or autopsy after ≤4 days of antimicrobial therapy yields no histologic evidence of endocarditis.

questions.text: Radiotherapy is most useful in:
questions.solution:
Seminoma is a highly radiosensitive tumor and hence radiotherapy is commonly used for treatment.

Related Pearl: Radiosensitive and Radioresistant Tumors

Highly radiosensitive tumors are

  • Lymphoma
  • Seminoma
  • Myeloma
  • Ewing’s sarcoma
  • Wilm’s tumour

 Highly radioresistant tumors are

  • Melanoma
  • Osteosarcoma
  • Pancreatic carcinoma
  • Hepatic carcinoma
  • Renal cell carcinoma

questions.text: Which is the first lymph node involved in the lymphatic spread of vulval cancer?
questions.solution:
In the lymphatic spread of vulval cancer, the first group of lymph nodes to be involved are the Superficial inguinal lymph nodes.

The lymphatic spread was described by Parry Jones which occurs in a systemic manner. The first group of lymph nodes to be involved are the Superficial inguinal lymph nodes after which the malignancy spreads to deep nodes and via the gland of Cloquet to the external iliac glands, obturator and common iliac nodes in the advanced stages.

  • Most common type of spread in vulval cancer: Lymphatic
  • First lymph node involved: Superficial inguinal lymph node > Deep inguinal lymph node > Femoral group of lymph nodes
  • The sentinel lymph node biopsy is helpful for evaluating the spread of vulval cancer.
  • The sentinel lymph node for vulval cancer is the superficial inguinal lymph node.
  • Most important prognostic factor: Lymph node status

Related Pearl: Treatment Modality in Vulval Cancer

Stage Treatment
1A
  •  Radical wide local excision
     
1B
  • Partial vulvectomy + ipsilateral inguinofemoral lymph node dissection
II
  • Tumor 2-4cm – total vulvectomy + B/L groin lymph node dissection
  • Tumor >4cm or poorly differentiated – radical vulvectomy + B/L lymphadenectomy + pelvic lymph node dissection
 
III
  • Megavoltage radiotherapy
  • Local surgical excision - Radical vulvectomy + B/L lymphadenectomy + pelvic lymph node dissection
  • Local recurrence – chemotherapy
 
IV
  • Chemotherapy or radiotherapy
  • Local excision on residual tumor
  • ipsilateral inguinofemoral lymph node + ve – contralateral node removed
  • Femoral lymph node +ve – pelvic lymph node removed

questions.text: The usage of the instrument given below is contra-indicated in ________
questions.solution:
The instrument given in the above image is a proctoscope. An acute anal fissure is a contraindication for proctoscopy.

Acute anal fissure is a severely painful condition. Due to pain, digital rectal examination and anoscopy are not performed immediately. It is reserved for later, when the symptoms resolve or the patient is in the operating room under anaesthesia.

Proctoscope: 

A proctoscope is conical in shape, with proximal diameter more than the distal, so as to illuminate the light at the required site properly. Obturator is the inner part which allows the easy insertion of the proctoscope.
  • Used to inspect the anus, anorectal junction and lower rectum, lesions upto 10-15 cm from the anal verge.
Indications:
a. Diagnostic—piles(haemorrhoids), fissure in ano, polyps,carcinoma and stricture, etc.
b. Therapeutic—injection therapy for partial prolapse or piles, cryotherapy or piles, polypectomy, biopsy for carcinoma rectum or anorectum.
Technique of Proctoscopy:
After doing a digital examination, a proctoscope with the obturator is introduced inside, through the anal canal in the direction towards the umbilicus. The obturator is removed. A proctoscope is withdrawn and during the course of withdrawal, any pathology has to be looked for.

questions.text: A 25-year-old patient  with breathing difficulty had high respiratory rate and 88 % saturation on pulse oximetry . Her examination findings with  imaging of spine is as below. Which of the following is seen in this type of  respiratory failure?
questions.solution:
The given patient with scoliosis and acute onset breathing difficulty points towards respiratory failure. It is most likely Type 2 respiratory failure.

It is characterized by low pO2 and high pCO2.

Type 2 respiratory failure is characterized by low pO2 and high pCO2.

Acute respiratory failure refers to acute impairment in gas exchange between the lungs and the blood causing hypoxia with or without hypercapnia. The various types are classified based on the abnormalities in respiratory function and are given below:

  • Type 1 is due to an alveolar oxygenation defect or a diffusion defect leading to hypoxia (low pO2) with normal or low pCO2 but not high pCO2. There is an increased alveolar-arterial oxygen gradient (high pAO2-paO2) and often a ventilation-perfusion(V/Q) mismatch; the volume of air flowing in and out of the lung is not matched to the blood flow to the lung.
    • Interstitial lung disease
    • Pulmonary oedema
    • Lung injury and alveolar haemorrhage
    • Pneumonia
    • Acute severe asthma
  • Type 2 results from the inability to eliminate carbon dioxide effectively due to a ventilation defect. This leads to hypoxia (low pO2) with hypercapnia (high pCO2). As diffusion is not defective, the alveolar-arterial gradient is unaffected with both low pAO2 (alveolar) and low paO2 (arterial). Causes:
    • Respiratory centre: brainstem injury, severe hypothyroidism, sleep apnoea, sedative drug overdose.
    • Chest wall and neuromuscular: Kyphoscoliosis, ankylosing spondylitis, myasthenia gravis, motor neuron disease, myopathy, fatigue.
    • Lung: COPD, pleural pathology, foreign body obstruction.
  • Type 3 results from lung atelectasis commonly during the perioperative period.
  • Type 4 is due to the hypoperfusion of respiratory muscles secondary to shock.

Related Pearl: Types of respiratory failure

 

Type Name Mechanism Associated conditions
I Acute hypoxemic respiratory failure Alveolar flooding and subsequent intrapulmonary shunt physiology. Sepsis, gastric aspiration, pneumonia, near-drowning, multiple blood transfusions and pancreatitis.
II

Hypoxemia with hypercapnia

 Results from the inability to eliminate carbon dioxide effectively. Drug overdose, brainstem injury, sleep-disordered breathing, severe hypothyroidism, myasthenia gravis, Guillain-Barre syndrome and amyotrophic lateral sclerosis
III Peri-operative respiratory failure Results from lung atelectasis. After general anesthesia.
IV Shock Results from hypoperfusion of respiratory muscles in patients with shock Cardiogenic shock.

 

Related Pearl: Respiratory failure types

 

Respiratory failure PaO2 PaCO2 Special Points

Cause:
  • pneumonia
  • Pulmonary edema
  • Asthma
  • ARDS
  • Pulmonary embolism

questions.text: Which is the characteristic pattern seen in Brown Sequard syndrome?

choices.text: Contralateral loss of joint sense and position
Ipsilateral loss of complete sensory functions

questions.solution:
The Brown–Sequard syndrome presents with contralateral loss of pain sensation.

Lateral hemisection of the spinal cord produces the Brown–Séquard syndrome.

Clinical features

  • Ipsilateral weakness (corticospinal tract involvement) 
  • Ipsilateral loss of joint position and vibratory sense (posterior column involvement)
  • Contralateral loss of pain and temperature sense (spinothalamic tract involvement) one or two levels below the lesion
  • Ipsilateral segmental signs like radicular pain, muscle atrophy, or loss of a deep tendon reflex

Related Pearl: Brown Sequard syndrome (Hemisection of spinal cord)

questions.text: A patient previously diagnosed with Gestational Trophoblastic Neopalsm(GTN) comes for a routine follow up. Chest X-Ray reveals the following. There is no evidence of other site involvements. What is the FIGO staging of this patient?
questions.solution:
The chest X-Ray reveals numerous, dense, bilateral metastatic nodules, of varying sizes and according to the International Federation of Gynecology and Obstetrics (FIGO), metastases to lungs are considered as stage III.

 

International Federation of Gynecology and Obstetrics (FIGO) Staging for GTN is as follows:
Stage I - Disease confined to the uterus

Stage II - GTN extends outside of the uterus but is limited to the genital structures    

(adnexa, vagina, broad ligament)
Stage III - GTN extends to the lungs, with or without known genital tract involvement
Stage IV - All other metastatic sites

questions.text: You are working as a Junior Resident in the department of pathology. You receive a specimen from Gynecology OT following resection of a lateral adnexal mass. You see the following marked structures on light microscopy. This is a distinct feature of which cell?
questions.solution:
The formation of Call-Exner bodies is a distinct feature of granulosa cells.

The mature graffian follicle is spheroidal or ovoid in shape and contains pent-up secretion, the liquor folliculi. The lining consists of two layers: (i) Theca interna and (ii) Granulosa layer.

Within the theca interna layer lies the granulosa cell layer, which consists of cells that have a characteristic appearance. The cells are 8–10 μ in diameter. The nuclei always stain deeply and the cells contain relatively little cytoplasm.

Scattered amongst the granulosa cells, particularly in the vicinity of the discus proligerus, are small spherical globules around which the granulosa cells are arranged radially. These structures form Call-Exner bodies. These are pathognomic for granulosa cell tumors. They are distinguished by their "coffee bean" nuclei.

In one area, the granulosa cells are collected together to form a projection into the cavity of the graffian follicle called the discus proligerus or cumulus oophorus.

questions.text: A 26-year-old female presents with complaints of irregular cycles, acne, excessive facial hair, weight gain and failure to conceive over the past 8 months. On examination there is central obesity with a BMI of 28.5 kg/cm2. Ultrasound pelvis reveals the following image. All of the following hormonal changes are noted except ____
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the ultrasound shows multiple ovarian follicles arranged in a necklace pattern is suggestive of polycystic ovarian disease (PCOD) wherein there is increased levels of E2/Estradiol hormone in the serum.

Polycystic ovarian disease is an endocrinopathy in women of reproductive age, affecting multiple systems.

Rotterdam criteria is used to diagnose polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS). The presence of any two of the three components of this criteria establishes the diagnosis of PCOS.

Rotterdam criteria (ASRM/ESHRE- European society of human reproduction and embryology, 2003):

Clinical/biochemical hyperandrogenism
Oligo/anovulation
Polycystic ovaries on USG

USG Criteria includes :

  • Increased ovarian stroma 
  • 12 follicles each measuring 2 to 9 mm arranged in a necklace pattern
  • Ovarian volume >10 ml
  • Single ovary meeting this criteria is enough to diagnose PCOS.

Related Pearl: Endocrinological changes of PCOD

  1. Elevated Estrone/E1 levels.
  2. LH level is raised over 10 IU/mL. FSH level remains normal to low, but FSH/LH ratio falls.
  3. Testosterone and epi-androstenedione levels rise.
    • Testosterone >2 ng/mL, free T >2.2 pg/mL (Normal level 0.2–0.8 ng/mL)
    • Normal androstenedione level is 1.3–1.5 ng/mL
    • DHEA >700 ng/mL suggests adrenal tumour
  4. Serum SHBG is reduced.
  5. Triglyceride level >150 mg/dL-hyperlipidaemia HDL <50 mg/dL.
  6. Fasting blood glucose/fasting insulin <4.5 suggests insulin resistance
  7. Prolactin is mildly raised in 15% cases
  8. Fasting insulin is more than 10 mIU/L in PCOS in 50–70%cases
  9. Thyroid function tests may be abnormal (hypothyroidism)
  10. 17-a-hydroxyprogesterone in the follicular phase >300 ng/dL suggests adrenal hyperplasia due to 21-hydroxylase deficiency.
  11. Urinary cortisol <50 μg/24 h.

questions.text: A 4-year-old child was brought to the OPD with a painless deformity. A radiograph of the child's legs is shown below. Which of the following is not a radiological finding associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
The radiograph shows bowing of legs which is most commonly seen in rickets and pelkan spurs is a characteristic radiological finding in scurvy and not seen in rickets.

Radiological features of rickets:

  • Widening of the growth plate
  • Cupping of metaphysis
  • Fraying
  • Bowing of diaphysis
  • Loss of provisional zone of calcification

In toddlers, bow leg or genu varum is one of the most common initial signs of rickets. In older children, genu valgum or coxa vara might be present.

The characteristic features of rickets include:

  • Delayed closure of the fontanelles
  • Frontal bossing
  • Craniotabes - soft skull bones
  • Rickety rosary - enlargement of the costochondral junction
  • Harrison sulcus 
  • Pigeon chest or pectus carinatum

Related Pearl: Important Clinical Features of Rickets

Related Pearl: Radiological features of rickets

Radiological features of rickets:

  • Delayed appearance of the epiphysis.
  • Widening of growth plate: normal width of growth is 2-4mm. It is increased in cases of rickets due to excessive accumulation of uncalcified osteoid at the growth plate.
  • Cupping of metaphysis: normally metaphysis meets epiphysis as a smooth line of sclerosis. But in rickets the line is absent and the metaphyseal ends appear irregular and the cartilage accumulating in the growth plate creates a depression in the metaphysis causing cupping.
  • Fraying: indistinct margins of the metaphysis
  • Bowing of diaphysis, with thinning of cortices.
  • Loss of provisional zone of calcification (becomes denser in healing rickets, known as the white line of Frenkel).

Related Pearl: Radiological features of scurvy

Radiological features of scurvy:

  • Generalised osteopenia
  • Cortical thinning: pencil-point cortex
  • Periosteal reaction due to subperiosteal hemorrhage
  • Scorbutic rosary: Expansion of the costochondral junctions
  • Hemarthrosis
  • Wimberger ring: Circular, opaque radiological shadow surrounding epiphyseal centers of ossification, which may result from bleeding
  • Frankel line: Dense zone of provisional calcification 
  • Trummerfeld zone: Lucent metaphyseal band underlying Frankel line
  • Pelken spur: Metaphyseal spurs which result in cupping of the metaphysis

questions.text: A physician notes the following clinical finding in a patient who also has axillary freckling and multiple small, rubbery lesions with slight purplish discoloration of the overlying skin throughout the body. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image shows discrete nodules over the iris, which are referred to as Lisch nodules, are commonly seen in patients with neurofibromatosis (NF). Axillary freckling and multiple neurofibromas also favour this diagnosis.

It is an autosomal dominant disorder. NF-1 is the most prevalent type and is caused by loss of function mutation of NF-1 gene.

NF1 is clinically diagnosed when any 2 of the following 7 features are present:

  • Six or more café-au-lait macules
  • Axillary or inguinal freckling
  • Two or more iris Lisch nodules
  • Two or more neurofibromas or 1 plexiform neurofibroma.
  • A distinctive osseous lesion such as sphenoid dysplasia
  • Optic gliomas
  • A first degree relative with NF-1

Note:

Lisch nodules are characteristically seen in NF-1; however, few cases of NF-2 have also been identified with Lisch nodules.

Other options:

Tuberous sclerosis: It is a neurocutaneous syndrome caused by mutation of genes coding for hamartin (chromosome 9) and tuberin (chromosome 16), which leads to the formation of hamartomas.

 Clinical features:

  • CNS
    • Glioneuronal hamartomas 
    • Subependymal nodules  
    • Subependymal giant cell astrocytomas (SEGAs) 
    • White matter lesions 
  • Skin
    • Facial angiofibroma (adenoma sebaceum)
    • Periungual fibroma
    • Shagreen patch
    • Confetti skin lesions

Von Hippel–Lindau disease: It is a neurocutaneous syndrome  characterized by cerebellar and retinal hemangioblastomas, spinal cord angiomas and cystic tumors of kidneys and pancreas. 

Sturge–Weber syndrome: It is a sporadic vascular disorder characterized by facial capillary malformation (port-wine stain, leptomeningeal angioma and glaucoma.

 

Image: Café-au-lait macules

Image: Axillary freckling

questions.text: A preterm infant, was  brought  to  the paediatric emergency on  the 2nd day of her life with the chief complaints  of respiratory distress  and intermittent grunting. A plain radiograph of the abdomen shows the following findings. All of the following are true with respect to this condition EXCEPT?

choices.text: Single most important risk factor is prematurity
Most common gastrointestinal surgical emergency in the neonatal period
Pneumatosis intestinalis is a pathognomonic sign
Duodenum and jejunum are the usual affected areas

questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC). The radiograph shows the presence of the multiple air bubbles within the bowel wall. This is called as pneumatosis intestinalis and is a pathognomonic sign suggestive of necrotizing enterocolitis.

The distal ileum and ascending colon are the usual affected areas. (not duodenum and jejunum)

Necrotizing enterocolitis:

It is the necrosis of a portion of the bowel and is the most common gastrointestinal surgical emergency in the neonatal period.

The single most important risk factor is prematurity. Other contributing factors are enteral feeding, ischemia, and infection.

It usually occurs in the first few days of life after the initiation of the enteral feeds. The babies become lethargic and develop abdominal distension, abdominal tenderness, bloody stools, and feeding intolerance. 

The distal ileum and ascending colon are the usual affected areas.

The radiograph may show pneumatosis intestinalis (presence of air within the bowel wall), portal venous gas, ascites and presence of free air.

Initial medical management consists of orogastric tube decompression, fluid resuscitation, blood product transfusion, and broad spectrum antibiotics.

Surgical management of NEC include resection of all nonviable intestinal segments with ostomy diversion.

Indications for operative management of NEC:

  1. Presence of intestinal perforation, as revealed by free air on plain abdominal radiographs (ABSOLUTE INDICATION)
  2. Clinical deterioration
  3. Abdominal wall cellulitis
  4. Palpable abdominal mass
  5. Persistent fixed radiographic bowel loop.

questions.text: A 38-year old male presents with exertional pain in both forearms and hands. He is a heavy smoker for the past 20 years. On examination, distal peripheral pulses of his upper limb are feeble. Image  of his hand is shown. Angiography of his upper extremity shows smooth tapering segmental lesions in the distal arterial vessels. Which of the following treatments has the greatest chances of success?
questions.solution:
This is a classical clinical scenario of Thromboangiitis Obliterans. Key points in the question:

  • Male < 40years
  • Smoker
  • Involvement of upper extremity
  • Raynauds phenomenon

There is no specific treatment except abstinence from tobacco. Hence, Smoking cessation has the greatest chance of success.

Heaprin (Anticoagulant) and Prednisolone (Steroid) have no role in treatment of Thromboangiitis Obliterans. Cilostazole can be used as an adjuvant therapy to improve circulation.

Thromboangiitis Obliterans (Buerger’s disease):

It is a progressive nonatherosclerotic segmental inflammatory disease that most often affects small- and medium-sized arteries, veins, and nerves of the upper and lower extremities.
  • Most common in men <40 years of age.
  • Although the cause of thromboangiitis obliterans is not known, there is a definite relationship to cigarette smoking in patients with this disorder.

The patient presents with intermittent claudication, chronic extremity ulcerations, and later progressing to frank gangrene.

The microscopy findings include luminal thrombosis (thrombangiitis), that is, thrombus containing microabscesses that occlude the lumen (obliterans) and the vessel wall is infiltrated with leukocytes.

Characteristic angiographic findings show disease confinement to the distal circulation, usually infrapopliteal and distal to the brachial artery. The occlusions are segmental and show “skip” lesions with extensive collateralization, the so-called corkscrew collaterals.

 Treatment:

  • There is no specific treatment except abstention from tobacco.
  • The prognosis is worse in individuals who continue to smoke, but results are discouraging even in those who stop smoking.
  • Antibiotics may be useful.
  • Anticoagulants and glucocorticoids are not helpful.
  • If these measures fail, amputation may be required.
Drugs that maybe used in Buerger's disease: (All drugs act at the collateral level than on the diseased vessel.)
  • Pentoxiphylline
  • Low dose of aspirin 75mg once a day - antithrombin activity
  • Cilostazole 100 mg bid—is a phosphodiesterase inhibitor which improves circulation (ideal drug)
  • Graded injection of xanthine nocotinate 3000 mg from day 1 to 􏰼000 mg on day 5 is often practiced to promote ulcer healing, helps to increase claudication distance as a temporary basis
  • Naftidofuryl is useful in intermittent claudication; it alters the tissue metabolism.

No Smoking Day is observed every year on the second Wednesday of March, this year it falls on March 10. The aim of the campaign is to encourage people over the world to quit smoking. The main purpose of this day is to spread awareness about the harmful health effects of tobacco consumption through cigarette and other modes.

questions.text: Precocious puberty  is defined by the onset of secondary sexual characteristics before the age of_________.

choices.text: 9 years in girls and 8 years in boys
7 years in girls and 8 years in boys
8 years in girls and 9 years in boys
9 years in girls and 10 years in boys

questions.solution:
Precocious puberty is defined as the onset of secondary sexual characteristics before the age of 8 years in girls and 9 years in boys.

Depending on the primary source of hormonal production, precocious puberty can be classified in the following manner:

Central Precocious Puberty

(Gonadotropin-dependent puberty)

Peripheral Precocious Puberty

(Gonadotropin independent)

Due to the excess secretion of gonadotropins (FSH and LH) from pituitary

Due to excess secretion of testosterone or estrogen from the gondas/adrenals.

Always isosexual (appearance of phenotypically appropriate secondary sexual characteristics before age 8 years in girls and before 9 years in boys).

Can be isosexual or heterosexual (appearance of secondary sex characters of the opposite sex).

Girls 

  • Idiopathic (most common)

Boys

  • CNS pathology (most common)

Girls 

  • Estrogenic ovarian cysts (isosexual)
  • Congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH) (testosterone increases; heterosexual)

Boys

  • CAH (isosexual; most common)

Note:

Central Precocious Puberty >> Peripheral Precocious Puberty

questions.text: A 35-year-old sustained a crush injury and he says his urine is brownish in colour. On investigation, his urine/plasma creatinine levels were <20. What could be the possible cause?
questions.solution:
A history of crush injury along with brownish urine and urine/plasma creatinine ratio of <20 is observed in renal AKI, which can be caused by rhabdomyolysis in this case.

Rhabdomyolysis is a serious life-threatening condition that involves a rapid breakdown of damaged skeletal muscle cells due to direct or indirect injury. Muscle breakdown causes the release of myoglobin, which contains heme into the bloodstream, causing heme pigment nephropathy. The heme pigment can cause direct PCT injury and vasoconstriction leading to fractional excretion of sodium(FENa)less than 1. Pigmented granular cast precipitates in the tubule causing oliguria and renal failure.

Causative factors include:

  • Traumatic crush injuries
  • Muscle ischemia during vascular or orthopaedic surgery
  • Compression during coma or immobilization
  • Prolonged seizure activity
  • Excessive or strenuous exercise
  • Heatstroke or malignant hyperthermia
  • Infections
  • Metabolic disorders such as hypophosphatemia or severe hypothyroidism
  • Myopathies (drug-induced, metabolic, or inflammatory)

Skeletal muscle damage causes excessive release of myoglobin, which acts as an endogenous toxin and can cause acute renal failure.

Laboratory features include elevated myoglobin, creatine kinase. Hematuria on dipstick examination without red cells indicates the presence of myoglobin.

The treatment includes administration of large amounts of fluid (5-6 liters), alkalization of urine, and hemodialysis. 

The rest of the options include causes of prerenal AKI, wherein the urine/plasma creatinine is >40.

  Pre renal  Renal Post renal
Urine osmolality >500 mOsm/kg <350mOsm/kg < 400 mOsm/kg
Urine Na <20 meq/l >40meq/l Variable
FeNa <1 >2 Variable
Urine creatinine/plasma creatinine >40:1 <20:1 <20:1
BUN: Creatinine  >20:1 <20:1 >20:1
Urine microscopy  Hyaline Muddy brown cast Normal or RBC/WBC

Causes of AKI are given below:

questions.text: A 80-years-old male presenting with dysphagia, regurgitation and halitosis. A barium swallow was done and is given below.  False statement regarding the condition is_____.

choices.text: It is usually seen in the middle aged and in the seventh decade of life.
It arises between the oblique fibers of the thyropharyngeus muscle and the horizontal fibers of the cricopharyngeus muscle.
It usually occurs on the left side
In most cases, excision is indicated if the sac is 2-4 cm.

questions.solution:
The history is suggestive of Zenker's diverticulum. The given image shows the collection of contrast in a pouch-like structure, which favours the diagnosis of Zenker's diverticulum. Excision of a Zenker's diverticulum is indicated for a large sac of size more than 4 - 5 cm.

Zenker's diverticulum / Pharyngeal pouch:

Zenker's diverticulum is a protrusion of the mucosa through Killian's dehiscence- a weak area of the posterior pharyngeal wall between the oblique fibers of the thyropharyngeus and the horizontal fibers of the cricopharyngeus.

Impaired relaxation and spasm of the cricopharyngeus muscle after swallowing can result in increased pressure within the distal pharynx and development of Zenker's diverticulum.

It is usually seen in during the middle age and peaks in the seventh decade on the left side.

Presentation:

  • Intermittent dysphagia
  • Regurgitation of foul-smelling, undigested material
  • Halitosis
  • Gurgling sound on swallowing
  • Nagging cough

The most serious complication from an untreated Zenker's diverticulum is aspiration pneumonia or lung abscess.

Investigation:

  • Investigation of choice for Zenker’s diverticulum is barium swallow.
  • Barium swallow examination is performed, which may show a diverticulum arising from the midline of the posterior wall of the distal pharynx near the pharyngoesophageal junction. The outpouching may be transient, and some refer to the transient variety as a “pharyngeal pouch”.
  • The pouch is best identified during swallowing and is best seen on the lateral view, on which the diverticulum is typically noted at the C5-6 level. Since ~90% of patients with a zenker diverticulum have a hiatal hernia and gastro-oesophageal reflux, the distal oesophagus should also be evaluated.
Treatment:

The treatment is either endoscopic or open surgery. 

  • Myotomy alone is sufficient if the sac is <2 cm.
  • A transoral endoscopic approach (Dohlman's procedure) -using staplers, laser, or coagulation through an endoscope that ablate the septum between the diverticulum and the cervical esophagus, can be used for diverticula between 2 and 5 cm in size.
  • Excision of a Zenker's diverticulum is indicated for a large sac of size more than 4 - 5 cm.

Note: Indication for standard open surgical approach instead of the endoscopic approach:

  • narrow mandibles or small oral cavities 
  • diverticula that cannot accommodate the scope 
  • diverticula that are not posterior
  • diverticula in which mucosal neoplastic changes are known to exist 
  • very large diverticula that cannot be approached safely with a peroral technique

Related Pearl: Zenker’s Diverticulum

  • Hypopharyngeal diverticulum
  • False diverticulum
  • Pulsion diverticulum
  • Acquired diverticulum, seen in the elderly (>60 years)
  • Herniation is through the Killian’s triangle (a weak area between two parts of the inferior constrictor) in the posterior pharyngeal wall
  • Clinical features:
    • Dysphagia
    • Regurgitation
    • Halitosis
    • Aspiration
    • Gurgling sound during swallowing
  • Investigation of choice: Barium swallow (Lateral X rays)
  • Treatment
    • Cricopharyngeal myotomy
    • Surgical diverticulectomy
    • Marsupialization
    • Dohlman’s procedure

Zenker’s diverticulum

Related Pearl: Pharyngo-esophageal diverticula

A) Zenker Diverticulum
B) Laimer Diverticulum
C) Killian–Jamieson Diverticulum
D) Lateral pharngeal Diverticulum

 

Diverticula Weak space Site
Zenker diverticulum Killian triangle/ Killian dehiscence

Above the upper esophageal sphincter

Between the oblique fibers of the thyropharyngeus muscle and the horizontal fibers of the cricopharyngeus muscle
Laimer's diverticulum Laimer’s triangle/ Laimer–Hackermann’s area

Posteriorly below cricopharyngeus and above longitudinal muscle layer of the esophagus
Killian– Jamieson Diverticulum Killian–Jamieson area

questions.text: Which of the following statement is true regarding Brodie abscess?

choices.text: It a localized variant of chronic osteomyelitis
Lytic lesion with dense sclerotic rim

questions.solution:
Brodie’s abscess is a localized variant of subacute osteomyelitis with a milder presentation which appears as a lytic lesion with a dense sclerotic rim on radiograph.

It is associated with little or no periosteal reaction. It most commonly involves the metaphysis of the proximal tibia and distal femur. The patient presents with intermittent pain and tenderness in the affected area.

 A biopsy is often needed to confirm the diagnosis. It is managed by antibiotics and curettage.

 

 

The above x-ray shows the dense sclerotic rim and minimal periosteal reaction in the upper end of the tibia.

Differential diagnosis of Brodie abscess :

 Brodie abscess can be mistaken for many neoplasms on plain radiographs and all of such conditions may present with a history of swelling and pain. However, the differentiating features of each of the conditions are as follows:

Condition Age group Radiographic findings
Brodie's abscess

Children, adolescents

 Lytic lesion with dense sclerotic rim, minimal periosteal reaction
Osteosarcoma Children, adolescents and seventh decade Periosteal reaction leading to sunray appearance and Codman triangle
Osteoclastoma 20-40 years Lytic lesion with thin sclerotic rim, minimal periosteal reaction
Ewing's sarcoma 10-20 years Periosteal reaction leading to onion peel appearance

questions.text: A 32-year-old female comes to the clinic with complaints of weight loss, low-grade fever, and chronic cough. X-ray shows the mediastinal nodal enlargement with parenchymal lung changes. AFB negative. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Female patient with low-grade fever, weight loss and chronic cough with negative AFB, who is presenting with the above mentioned radiological presentation is diagnostic of Sarcoidosis.

Pulmonary sarcoidosis can be classified on a chest radiograph into 5 stages:

  • Stage 0: Normal chest radiograph.
  • Stage I: Hilar or mediastinal nodal enlargement only.
  • Stage II: Nodal enlargement and parenchymal disease
  • Stage III: Parenchymal disease only
  • Stage IV: End-stage lung (pulmonary fibrosis)

Radiographic features are variable depending on the stage of the disease.

Stage 0: Normal chest radiograph.
Stage I: Hilar or mediastinal nodal enlargement only.

 

Options A, B, C would present with more severe systemic symptoms and would most likely have an acute/a subacute history of coughing rather than chronic.

Stage II: Nodal enlargement and parenchymal disease.

Stage III: Parenchymal disease only.

Stage IV: End-stage lung (pulmonary fibrosis)

  • 1 Curie = 3.7 × 10 ^10 disintegration /s =1 gram Radium disintegration /s
  • 1 Becquerel = 1 disintegration /s

questions.text: A patient who is a known case of small cell carcinoma of the lung is diagnosed with the syndrome of inappropriate ADH secretion (SIADH). It is characterized by:
questions.solution:
The syndrome of inappropriate ADH secretion (SIADH) is associated with increased urinary excretion of sodium, thereby leading to euvolemic hyponatremia.

Small cell lung cancer is commonly associated with SIADH due to the ectopic release of antidiuretic hormone. 

The excess ADH secreted leads to the gain of water. This stimulates baroreceptors to release atrial natriuretic peptide (ANP). ANP leads to the loss of water and salt with urine sodium level is > 20 mEq/L in these patients.

Thus, the level of water reaches a steady-state (euvolemia) but the urinary loss of sodium continues to occur giving rise to hyponatremia.

Clinical features of SIADH 

  • Euvolemia: No signs of dehydration
  • Hyponatremia: Na less than 135mEq/L
  • Inappropriately elevated urine osmolality (less than 150mosm/Kg)
  • Excessive urine sodium excretion (more than 30 mEq/L) 
  • Decreased serum osmolality (less than 280mosm/Kg)

Laboratory features

  • Hyponatremia (Na less than 135 mEq/L) 
  • B.U.N. and serum uric acid falls because of plasma dilution and increased excretoin of nitrogenous products
  • Serum potassium and bicarbonate levels are normal in SIADH 
  • Low serum osmolality

questions.text: A young patient with Hepatitis E virus infection develops acute liver failure. Which of the following scores can be used in assessing the prognosis of this patient?
questions.solution:
In a patient with acute liver failure, MELD score and King's College Hospital criteria can be used to assess the prognosis.

Child-Pugh score is used to assess the severity of the cirrhosis. 

Pitt score is used used to predict mortality in patients having bloodstream infections.

Related Pearl: Model for End-stage liver disease (MELD) scoring system

Components:

  • Creatinine
  • Bilirubin
  • International normalized ratio (INR)
  • Serum Sodium (mEq/L)

Uses:

  • Predict short-term prognosis in patients undergoing transjugular intrahepatic portosystemic shunt (TIPS) insertion
  • Assess and prioritize patients awaiting liver transplantation
  • Assess prognosis in cirrhosis

 

Related Pearl: Child-Turcotte-Pugh Score

The CHADS2-VASc score here is 3

As the patient is a female - 1 , diabetes-1, hypertension -1 ;so total comes to 3.

questions.text: Which of the following is the best prognostic factor for melanoma?

choices.text: Depth of invasion of the tumour

questions.solution:
Tumor thickness or Breslow index is the best prognostic factor of melanoma. It indicates the depth of invasion of the tumour.

  • It is the distance in millimeters (mm) between the epidermal granular layer and the deepest level of invasion of the primary lesion.
  • Thicker tumours have a higher metastatic potential.

Image: Breslow Depth

Related Pearl: Main Prognostic Factors for Primary Melanoma

The following are the prognostic factors for primary melanoma (predictive value from *** high to * low):

  • Thickness (Breslow index)***
  • Sentinel node status***
  • Ulceration**
  • Mitotic rate** (negative value especially in thin tumours)
  • Regression* (underestimation of Breslow)
  • Age* (negative for older age)
  • Sex* (negative for males)
  • Location* (negative for head and neck)

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy with progressive muscle weakness and walking difficulties presented to the OPD. On examination he has  pseudohypertrophy of calf muscles . What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The presence of pseudohypertrophy of calf muscles, which along with a history of progressive muscle weakness and walking difficulties, is suggestive of a diagnosis of Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD). Pseudohypertrophy of calf muscles is the characteristic feature of DMD, whereas the other 3 conditions mentioned in the options do not have this feature.

Duchenne muscular dystrophy is the most common hereditary neuromuscular disease. It is an X-linked recessive disorder.

Clinical features:

  1. Progressive weakness with developmental delay
  2. Pseudohypertrophy of calves
  3. Wasting of thigh muscles
  4. Characteristic Trendelenburg gait or hip waddle.
  5. Gower’s sign
  6. Dilated cardiomyopathy

Diagnosis:

  1. Elevated serum creatine kinase levels
  2. Polymerase chain reaction (PCR) analysis for dystrophin gene
  3. If PCR is normal, but clinical suspicion is high, muscle biopsy with dystrophin immunocytochemistry is done.

Treatment includes supportive management for cardiac decompensation, nutritional management, physiotherapy, and glucocorticoids. Death usually occurs by 18 to 20 years of age due to respiratory failure, intractable heart failure, pneumonia, or aspiration.

Other options:

Option B: Spinal muscular atrophy (SMA), type 1 (which is most common) presents in infancy. Death occurs early; hence, SMA patients may not make upto the age of 7 years, as in the given question.

Option C: Emery–Dreifuss muscular dystrophy presents with predominant involvement of scapular and humeral muscles. The given question describes the involvement of lower limb muscles. Hence, Emery–Dreifuss dystrophy, in this case, is less likely.

Option D: Myotonic dystrophy presents with distal muscle weakness, proximal muscle involvement is very late.

questions.text: Two weeks after an upper respiratory tract infection, a 5-year-old presents with ecchymosis and petechiae all over the body with no  hepatosplenomegaly. Platelet count = 15,000/microL and coagulation profile was normal. Which of the following is false regarding this condition?

choices.text: Bone marrow biopsy shows increased megakaryocytes
Bleeding into the joints is a common manifestation
The condition resolves spontaneously in 80% patients

questions.solution:
Mucocutaneous bleeding and reduced platelet count two weeks after an upper respiratory tract infection is suggestive of acute idiopathic thrombocytopenic purpura. Bleeding into the joints is not a common manifestation of this condition.

Deep tissue bleeding (joints and muscles) such as muscle hematomas and hemarthrosis is seen in coagulation disorders or clotting factor deficiencies. 

Superficial mucocutaneous bleeding such as epistaxis, petechiae, ecchymosis is seen in bleeding disorders or platelet disorders.

Immune thrombocytopenic purpura or idiopathic thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP) is an acquired disorder in which there is an immune-mediated destruction of platelets.

Acute ITP:

  • Acute presentation with a self-limited course in children and resolves spontaneously in 80% patients.
  • Presenting features
    • Preceded by viral infection
    • Mucocutaneous bleeding
    • Hepatomegaly, splenomegaly, lymphadenopathy, fever and jaundice are absent.
    • Resolves spontaneously in 80% of the cases in 4-6 weeks(Option D).
  • Laboratory features
    • Thrombocytopenia (commonly <20,000 / μL)
    • Normal/Increased megakaryocytes in bone marrow(Option B).
    • Prolonged bleeding time.
    • Normal tests for coagulation (PT/PTT/INR).
    • Peripheral smear is normal(Option A).
  • Treatment 
    • Detailed below

Related Pearl: Differences between Bleeding Disorders and Coagulation disorders

It is characterized by

  • Normal bone marrow—normal or even increased number of megakaryocytes
  • Absence of other causes of thrombocytopenia.

questions.text: A 53-year-old male patient  was admitted to the emergency department because of the drop of a construction material from a height to the right shoulder and chest area. O/E the patient was dyspneic and paradoxical respiration was seen. His oxygen saturation was deteriorating (despite of oxygen administration) suggestive of respiratory failure. What is the definitive management of this case?

choices.text: Internal operative fixation of the fractures segments

questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario of blunt trauma to the chest with paradoxical respiration is suggestive of FLAIL CHEST. Management of flail chest with respiratory failure is IPPV(Intermitent Positive Pressure Ventilation).

Flail Chest :

  • A flail chest occurs when a segment of the chest wall does not have bony continuity with the rest of the thoracic cage.
  • This condition results from blunt trauma associated with multiple rib fractures, i.e. 2 adjacent ribs or 3 or more ribs fractured in two or more places.
  • The blunt force required to disrupt the integrity of the thoracic cage typically produces an underlying pulmonary contusion as well.

Clinical Features:

On inspiration the loose segment of the chest wall is displaced inwards and less air therefore moves into the lungs.On expiration, the segment moves outwards(paradoxical respiration).

Diagnosis - Made clinically, not by radiography. To confirm the diagnosis the chest wall can be observed for paradoxical motion of a chest wall segment for several respiratory cycles and during coughing. Voluntary splinting as a result of pain, mechanically impaired chest wall movement and the associated lung contusion are all causes of the hypoxia and respiratory failure.

The patient is also at high risk of developing a pneumothorax or hemothorax.

CT scan, with contrast to display the vascular structures and a 3-D reconstruction of the chest wall, is the gold standard for diagnosis.

Treatment:

  • Chest strapping or splinting should be avoided
  • Currently, treatment consists of oxygen administration, adequate analgesia (including opiates) or epidural analgesia and physiotherapy.
  • IPPV (Intermitent Positive Pressure Ventilation) is reserved for cases developing respiratory failure despite adequate analgesia and oxygen.

Treament Algorithm of treatment of flail chest with respiratory failure:

questions.text: A 35-year-old lady with no comorbidities is on a diet and was incidentally detected to have a hemoglobin of 10g/dl, MCV = 75 fL, MCH = 25 pg.  Peripheral smear is as below , Iron studies - Low Ferritin and high TIBC. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above clinical findings are consistent with the diagnosis of Iron deficiency anaemia .

This patient has microcytic (N: 82-96 fL) and hypochromic (N: 27-33 pg) anemia with target cells.The differential diagnoses of microcytic hypochromic anemia include:iron deficiency, thalassemia,sideroblastic anemia and anemia of chronic disease . The single best test which can differentiate between these is the iron profile. 

Iron Profile: Low Ferritin and high TIBC( total iron binding capacity) is seen in Iron deficiency anaemia, while Thalassemia major has normal/high ferritin and low/normal TIBC.

Hemogram:

  • MCV of 75 fl is suggestive of microcytosis (normal MCV is 82–96 fl)
  • MCH of 25 pg is suggestive of hypochromia (normal MCH is 27–33 pg/cell)

The above peripheral smear shows microcytic, hypochromic blood picture with pencil cells implies that the most likely diagnosis for the patient is iron-deficiency anemia.

She is on a diet too which suggests that there is deficient intake of nutrients and there are no comorbidities which rules out anaemia of c/c disease.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a cluster A personality disorder?
questions.solution:
Avoidant personality disorder is not a cluster A personality disorder . It belongs to Cluster C personality disorders.

Cluster A:

Odd, aloof features.

Includes three personality disorders.

  • Paranoid
  • Schizoid
  • Schizotypal

Cluster B:

Dramatic, impulsive, and erratic features.

Includes four personality disorders.

  • Borderline
  • Antisocial
  • Narcissistic
  • Histrionic

Cluster C:

Anxious and fearful features.

Includes three personality disorders.

  • Avoidant
  • Dependent
  • Obsessive-compulsive

Related Pearl: Personality Disorders

Paranoid
Suspicious, distrustful, hypervigilant
Schizoid
Prefers to be loner, detached, unemotional
Schizotypal
Eccentric & odd thoughts, perceptions & behavior, magical thinking and beliefs

Cluster B (Dramatic, Emotional and Erratic)
Antisocial
Disregard for and violation of rights of others, illegal activities
Borderline
Chaotic relationships, sensitivity to abandonment, labile mood, impulsivity, inner emptiness, self-harm

questions.text: An 11-year-old child comes with his mother to the clinic with features of itching and redness of the scalp. On examination, there are round erythematous patches with loss of hair in and around the lesion, Which of the following is the drug of choice in this child?
questions.solution:
Tinea capitis is a common infection of the scalp hair caused by dermatophyte fungi and occurring predominantly in children. Its clinical manifestations range from mild scaling with little hair loss to large inflammatory and pustular plaques with extensive alopecia. Here, Griseofulvin is the DOC for Tinea capitis in children.

  • Oral terbinafine is used in the treatment of Trichophyton.
  • Selenium sulphide has only supportive role in the treatment of Tinea capitis.

questions.text: A 3-year-old kid was given inhalational anesthesia for circumcision. Two minutes into the procedure, the kid throws incoherent movements along with passing of urine. Which of the following inhalational agent caused the patient's current condition _______
questions.solution:
Seizures have been associated with the use of sevoflurane in high concentrations, especially in the pediatric population. Emergence from sevoflurane is associated with tonic clonic movements suggestive of the seizure.

Hence sevoflurane must be used cautiously in patients with a known history of seizure.

Though isoflurane can cause myoclonus and EEG spiking, frank seizure activity is not seen.

Enflurane has the most epileptogenic potential among the inhaled anesthetics.

questions.text: The preparation shown below is used for the diagnosis of  ________
questions.solution:
Hanging drop preparation is used for diagnosis of trichomniasis.

  • Trichomonas vaginalis is a protozoan, actively mo­tile and slightly larger than a leucocyte and is anaerobic.
  • A trichomonas has four anterior flagella and one posterior flagella, and they move along the mucous membrane.
  • The posterior flagella are respon­sible for motility.

questions.text: A couple presents to the infertility clinic after unsuccessfully trying to conceive. The female partner has no specific complaints. The male partner reports absence of semen during intercourse and cloudy urine afterward. He has a history of diabetes and underwent TURP 6 months ago. What is the underlying mechanism of this complication?

choices.text: Injury to the external urethral sphincter
Disruption of the autonomic nerve supply to the corpora of the penis
Over use of coagulating diathermy during the procedure

questions.solution:
The clinical scenario above suggests the patient has retrograde ejaculation. The most likely mechanism of its development is disruption of the bladder neck. 

Retrograde ejaculation is the most common complication of transurethral resection of the prostate (TURP). 

Other complications of TURP include the following: 

  • Perforation of the bladder
  • Sepsis
  • Incontinence: Occurs due to damage of external sphincter mechanism
  • Urethral stricture: Clumsy/prolonged catheterization
  • TURP syndrome/water intoxication: Absorption of water into the circulation at the time of TURP can give rise to congestive cardiac failure, hyponatremia, and hemolysis. 

Other options:

Option A: Injury to the external urethral sphincter causes incontinence following TURP. 

Option B: Disruption of the autonomic nerve supply to the corpora of the penis causes erectile impotence. 

Option C: Overuse of coagulating diathermy following TURP causes bladder neck contracture.

questions.text: All of the following can be used for radionuclide therapy except:
questions.solution:
• Ga-68 is a PET imaging radioisotope which is only used for imaging purpose. For e.g. Gallium-68 somatostatin receptor positron emission tomography (PET) has been used in the diagnosis of neuroendocrine tumors (NETs).
  • P32 is a pure beta emitter while I131 and Re 186 are beta + gamma emitters used in radiotherapy.

questions.text: Methyl Ergometrine is contraindicated in all except :
questions.solution:
Methyl ergometrine is not contraindicated in patients with renal disease but rather in organic cardiac disease. This is because it leads to sudden squeezing of blood from the uterine circulation into the systemic circulation causing an overload of the right heart and subsequently heart failure. Oxytocin is preferred in such cases.

Other Contraindications of Methyl ergometrine:

  • Twin pregnancy: Second baby gets compromised by tetanic contractions of uterus if given after delivery of first baby
  • Severe pre-eclampsia and eclamspsia
  • Rh negative mother: Increases chance of fetomaternal transfusion.

questions.text: Histopathological examination of a specimen received after staging laparotomy for an ovarian mass revealed the presence of the following structures. Which of the following is associated with this finding?
questions.solution:
The given histological finding denotes Psammoma bodies which are a histopathological finding of ovarian papillary serous cystadenoma and cystadenocarcinoma

They are calcified structures seen in areas of cellular degeneration. Its presence perse does not denote malignancy.

Psammoma bodies are seen in the following:

  • Papillary carcinoma of the thyroid
  • papillary serous carcinoma of the endometrium.
  • Serous cystadenoma/cystadenocarcinoma of the ovary
  • Meningioma

questions.text: Placenta accreta means:

choices.text: Villi penetrate through myometrium to the serosa

questions.solution:
Placenta accreta is when the villi are attached to the myometrium.

Placenta accreta syndromes describe the abnormally implanted, invasive, or adhered placenta. The abnormally firm adherence to the myometrium is due to the partial or total absence of the decidua basalis and imperfect development of the Nitabuch layer.  

Nitabuch layer-A layer of fibrin between the  compact endometrium and the cytotrophoblastic shell in the placenta.This layer is absent in placenta accreta.

Types

Definition

Placenta accreta  

Villi are attached to the myometrium.

Placenta increta 

Villi invade the myometrium. 

Placenta percreta 

Villi penetrate through the myometrium and to or through the serosa. 

These three variants are encountered in an approximate ratio of 80:15:5, respectively.

questions.text: Cryoprecipitate has all the following components except
questions.solution:
Cryoprecipitate does not contain factor IX.

Components of cryoprecipitate are

  • Factor VIII
  • Factor XIII
  • Fibrinogen
  • Fibronectin
  • Von Willebrand factor

Therefore it can be used in patients with hemophilia A, factor XIII deficiency, hypofibrinogenemia, and von Willebrand disease.

NOTE:

Transfusion of pRBCs (packed red blood cells) or whole blood should be completed within 4 hours after the commencement. Transfusion of platelets, fresh frozen plasma, and cryoprecipitate should be completed within 30 minutes.

The optimum temperature for storage of packed RBCs and whole blood collected in preservatives is +2° to +6° C. This temperature maintains the viability of the cells and prevents bacterial contamination.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about antidepressants is true?

choices.text: Antidepressants has no effect on suicidality in depressed patients
Antidepressants decreases suicidal ideation in younger patients in early stage of therapy
Antidepressants increases suicidal ideation in younger patients in early stage of therapy
Antidepressants increases suicidal ideation in younger patients in late stages of therapy

questions.solution:
Antidepressants should be used carefully in the young for the management of depression due to increased suicidal ideation. 

Somatic symptoms of depression improve faster than psychological symptoms when a patient is started on selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRI’)s and hence patients have the energy to act on their thoughts of deliberate self-harm and suicide (paradoxical suicide).

questions.text: A patient with chronic history of severe COPD comes to the emergency room with shortness of breath. Rales and wheeze are heard on auscultation and elevated JVP is noted.  Shortness of breath wasn't relieving with bronchodilators, IV steroids and antibiotics. Chest x-ray shows the image below. What is the pathology behind patient's current condition?
questions.solution:
This patient with COPD has shortness of breath despite appropriate treatment for acute COPD exacerbation, showing peripheral pruning in chest X-ray, due to pulmonary artery hypertension

Pulmonary artery hypertension is associated with peripheral pruning which means that the blood vessels appear cut off before they reach the outer 1/3 of the lung. The edge of the lung fields are, therefore, often darker than usual and the central area often whiter.

Plain radiograph findings in pulmonary artery hypertension :

  • Elevated cardiac apex due to right ventricular hypertrophy
  • Enlarged right atrium
  • Prominent pulmonary outflow tract
  • Enlarged pulmonary arteries
  • Pruning of peripheral pulmonary vessels

Left hear failure would have showed pulmonary edema on chest X-ray (Option B)

Laryngitis would not cause pruning on chest X-ray and shortness of breath would be associated with stridor (Option D)

Patient with severe COPD without (A) and with (B) signs of pulmonary fluid overload and cardiac decompensation. Note the only discrete increase of vascular markings in (B) while the pleural effusion and the enlarged heart indicate the severity of the disease.

questions.text:
A 60-year-old man  who is a c/c smoker presents with increased shortness of breath. His Pulmonary function test values were FEV1/FVC <0.7 and FEV1 30% to 50%.
ABG analysis reveals pH - 7.24; pCO2 - 60 mm Hg, pO2- 52 mmHg, HCO3 - 27 mmol/L. What is the most probable underlying acid-base disorder?
questions.solution:
The underlying acid-base disorder is respiratory acidosis.

A c/c smoker with FEV1/FVC <0.7 and FEV1 30% to 50% can be 1042.

In COPD there is hypercapnia leading to increased H+ formation.

 

How to find if it acidosis/alkalosis:

Step 1: A pH of 7.24 signifies acidosis.

Step 2: A plasma HCO3- is 27 mEq/L is within normal limits. This is very likely to be due to compensation as it does not reflect the direction of the pH change.

Step 3: A pCO2 of 60 mmHg along with an acidotic pH signifies respiratory acidosis. 

Step 4: The expected compensatory increase in HCO3- can be calculated using the following formula:

Increase in HCO3- = 0.4 X Δ PaCO2 (as COPD is a chronic condition and the presentation of the patient is not acute)

Thus, the increase in HCO3- = 0.4 x (60-40) = 8 mEq/L

Therefore expected HCO3- is 24 + 8 = 32 mEq/L.

The actual HCO3- measured is 27 mEq/L (which is less than the expected value) indicating that there could be a component of metabolic acidosis also.

But, the predominant disorder is respiratory acidosis and thus it is the best answer.

pCO2 35 - 45 mmHg 40 mmHg 
Anion gap 6 - 12 mEq/L <10 mEq/L
O2 saturation > 95%
pO2 75 - 100 mmHg

questions.text: A 3-year-old  child with the buccal mucosa finding as shown in the image developed rash  after three days. Which of the following statement is false about this  condition?

choices.text: Hemorrhagic form of the disease is often fatal
Low levels of retinol is associated  with high mortality and morbidity

questions.solution:
The clinical scenario alongwith the image showing Koplik spots is suggestive of measles and the incubation period is 8-12 days.

Koplik spots  are small, bluish-white ulcerations on the buccal mucosa opposite the lower molar tooth.

The virus has an incubation period of 8-12 days, after which the prodrome phase begins with mild fever, conjunctivitis, upper respiratory tract infection, and pathognomic Koplik spots. This follows the appearance of maculopapular rash after 4th day of fever, which begins at the face and spreads to torso and extremities. Lymphadenopathy may be present.Patients can transmit infection 3 days before and 4-6 days after the onset of rash. Warthin-Finkeldey giant cells are pathognomonic of measles. These are multinucleated giant cells formed by the fusion of infected cells.

Complications: 

 Most common complication of  measles is acute otitis media . Sinusitis and mastoiditis are also seen.

Most common cause of death in measles is Pneumonia. Pneumonia can be giant cell pneumonia which is caused by the virus directly or can be due to superadded bacterial infection.

Black measles or hemorrhagic measles is a fatal complication characterised by hemorrhagic skin eruptions. It is rarely seen nowdays.

Other complications include- croup, tracheitis, bronchiolitis, diarrhea and vomiting,febrile seizures and encephalitis.

 Subacute Sclerosing Panencephalitis:

It is a rare but fatal complication characterized by cognitive decline,spasticity of limbs and seizures. It is insidious in onset and clinical manifestations usually begin 7-13 years after primary measles infection. It is caused due to persistent infection with a genetically altered variant of measles virus within the central nervous system.

Low serum retinol levels in children with measles are associaated with higher morbidity and mortality and hence Vitamin A therapy is indicated for all patients with measles.

questions.text: The contraceptive shown in the image below contains which of the following?
questions.solution:
The contraceptive device shown in the above image is ‘Today’. It contains nonoxynol 9.

 

Today:

It is a mushroom-shaped polyurethane disposal sponge

2 inches in diameter, 1.25 inches thick and contains 1 g of nonoxynol-9.

It is provided with a loop for its easy removal.

It should be placed high up in the vagina with the concave side covering the cervix.

It can remain effective for 24 h. It is used only once. It acts as a mechanical barrier and prevents entry of sperms into the cervical canal, absorbs semen and contains a spermicidal agent.

Failure rate: 9-16 per 100 woman years

questions.text: Choose the correct option regarding the flap given below.

choices.text: Latissmus dorsi flap is another example for the flap given above.
Blood supply is isolated, disconnected and then reconnected.
There is no specific relationship to where the blood supply enters.

questions.solution:
The picture shows a radial forearm free flap. In a free flap the blood supply is isolated, disconnected and then reconnected using microsurgery at the new site. Other eg: DIEP (Deep inferior epigastric perforators) flap, free fibular flap.

  • A random flap include three sides of a rectangle, bearing no specific relationship to where the blood supply enters.Eg:V-Y plasty, Z plasty, Limberg or rhomboid flap.
  • Axial flap is much longer and is based on known blood vessels. Eg: Latissmus dorsi flap,TRAM (Transverse rectus abdominis myocutaneous) flap
  • Islanded flap / Pedicled flap are those in which the axial blood supply is swung round on a stalk.

Other type of flaps:

  • Composite flap: Various tissues are transferred together, often skin with bone or muscle (osseocutaneous or myocutaneous).
  • Perforator flaps: This description refers to a whole new subgroup of axial flaps in which tissues are isolated on small perforating vessels that run from more major blood vessels to supply the surface.

Note:

Flap defines the tongue of tissue; pedicle is used to describe the base or stem with the vascular supply.

Skin-bearing flaps are classified according to three basic characteristics—

  • Composition: refers to the tissue contained within the flap, such as cutaneous, musculocutaneous, fasciocutaneous etc
  • Method of movement:
    • Local transfer, eg. advancement or rotation flaps
    • Distant transfer, eg. pedicle flaps from the abdomen to the perineum or micro-vascular free flaps.
  • Blood supply
    • Musculocutaneous arteries travel perpendicularly through muscle to the overlying skin.
    • Septocutaneous arteries travel with intermuscular fascial septa to supply the overlying skin.

questions.text: The maneuver portrayed in the image below is called?
questions.solution:
Ritgen maneuver is done in delivery of head in normal labor.

  • When the head distends the vulva and perineum enough to open the vaginal introitus to a diameter of >5 cm, a towel is draped and a gloved hand may be used to exert forward pressure on the chin of the fetus through the perineum.
  • The other hand exerts pressure superiorly against the occiput.
  • This maneuver allows controlled delivery of the head.

Other options :

McRoberts maneuver is employed during delivery incase of shoulder dystocia. This involves hyperflexion of the mother's legs to her abdomen to allow rotation of the pelvis which aids in delivering the fetal shoulder. (Option B)

Wood's corkscrew maneuver is also emplayed during shoulder dystocia and involves positioning the sholders of the fetus. (Option C)

Rubin's maneuver (reverse corkscrew) is employed during childbirth in the case of shoulder dystocia. (Option A)

questions.text: What developmental anomaly has caused the presentation seen in the following image?

choices.text: Faulty migration of neural crest cells
Incomplete closure of the embryonic fissure

questions.solution:
The image shows a coloboma of the iris. This is due to the incomplete closure of the embryonic fissure. These colobomas may involve the optic nerve, choroid, retina, and iris.

Option B: Faulty migration of neural crest cells results in anterior segment dysgenesis.

questions.text: A 20-year-old female with easy fatigability and weakness presented to the OPD. On examination, there is pallor, glossitis, angular cheilosis and  image of her hand is as given below.  Mean corpuscular volume (MCV) = 112 fL and Mean corpuscular hemoglobin concentration (MCHC) = 34 g/dl. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a 20-year-old female presenting with easy fatigability, and weakness and the image showing findings of skin hyperpigmentation involving knuckles is suggestive of Vitamin B12 deficiency.

Skin hyperpigmentation especially on the dorsum of hands involving the knuckles is seen in cyanocobalamin or vitamin B12 deficiency which is a causative factor of megaloblastic anemia. The peripheral smear in this patient would show a reduction in reticulocyte count, not an increase.

In megaloblastic anaemia, there is an impairment of DNA synthesis that leads to ineffective hematopoiesis. It also causes distinctive morphologic changes, including abnormally large erythroid precursors and red cells.

Clinical features of megaloblastic anaemia (cyanocobalamin and folate deficiency) include anorexia, weight loss, diarrhoea, or constipation. Oral manifestations like glossitis, and angular cheilosis. Mild fever in more severely anaemic patients, jaundice (unconjugated) and reversible melanin skin hyperpigmentation.

Peripheral smear findings include macro-ovalocytes and low reticulocyte count. Nucleated red cell progenitors occasionally appear in the circulating blood when anaemia is severe. Neutrophils are also larger than normal (macro polymorphonuclear) and show nuclear hypersegmentation, having five or more nuclear lobules.

The image given below shows hypersegmented neutrophils seen in megaloblastic anaemia.

Other options:

Option B: Sideroblastic anaemia is characterized by defective heme synthesis, leading to ringed sideroblasts in the bone marrow and microcytic or dimorphic anaemia. Clinical features include fatigue, pallor, and symptoms of iron overload such as hepatosplenomegaly.

Option C: Beta-thalassemia is a genetic disorder causing reduced or absent beta-globin chain synthesis, leading to microcytic hypochromic anaemia. Clinical features include pallor, growth retardation, hepatosplenomegaly, and in severe cases, skeletal deformities due to marrow expansion.

Option D: Iron deficiency anemia is characterized by microcytic hypochromic anaemia due to low iron levels. Clinical features include fatigue, pallor, koilonychia (spoon-shaped nails), and angular cheilitis.

Related Pearl: Causes of Megaloblastic Anemia

Vitamin B12 Deficiency causes:

  • Decreased Intake
    • Inadequate diet
    • Vegetarianism
  • Impaired Absorption
    • Intrinsic factor deficiency
    • Pernicious anemia
    • Gastrectomy
    • Malabsorption states
    • Diffuse intestinal disease (e.g., lymphoma, systemic sclerosis)
    • Ileal resection
    • Ileitis
  • Competitive parasitic uptake
    • Fish tapeworm infestation
    • Bacterial overgrowth in blind loops and diverticula of bowel

Folic Acid Deficiency causes:

  • Decreased Intake
    • Inadequate diet
    • Alcoholism
    • Infancy
  • Impaired Absorption
    • Malabsorption states
    • Intrinsic intestinal disease
    • Anticonvulsants
    • Oral contraceptives
  • Increased Loss
    • Hemodialysis
  • Increased Requirement
    • Pregnancy, infancy
    • Disseminated cancer
    • Markedly increased hematopoiesis
  • Impaired Utilization
    • Folic acid antagonists
    • Unresponsive to vitamin B12 or folic acid therapy
    • Metabolic inhibitors of DNA synthesis and/or folate metabolism

questions.text: A 46-year-old female presents to the emergency after colliding with a four-wheeler. O/E her Pulse Pressure was 80mmHg. What could be the approximate blood loss in this patient?
questions.solution:
Pulse Pressure is increased in this patient. Increased pulse pressure can be seen in Class I Hemorrhage, where the blood loss is usually less than 15%.

The physiological effects of hemorrhage are divided into four classes, based on clinical signs, which are useful for estimating the percentage of acute blood loss

Class I Hemorrhage (<15% Blood Volume Loss): The clinical symptoms of volume loss with class I hemorrhage are minimal.

Note:

Only in class I, Pulse pressure is either Increased or Normal. In all other classes, it is decreased.
