questions.text: A 30-year-old female presents with a painless, rapidly growing lump in her left breast that she noticed over the past few months. On examination, the lump is well-defined, mobile, and firm in consistency. A breast ultrasound reveals a solid mass, and a core needle biopsy is performed. Histopathological examination shows a leaf-like pattern with an overgrowth of the stromal component and ductal structures. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The histopathology of the biopsy of the lump shows increased stromal cellularity, overgrowth, and typical leaflike architecture which is suggestive of phyllodes tumor. 

Phyllodes tumor is also known as cystosarcoma phyllodes, presents as a large tumor with an unevenly bosselated surface. This tumour does not infiltrate the skin though the overlying skin becomes thin and tense due to swelling. Nipple retraction is not seen in this condition.

Phyllodes tumors usually occur in women over the age of 40 years but can appear in younger women. They are mostly benign even though it is also called as cystosarcoma phyllodes or as serocystic disease of Brodie. They are usually mobile over the chest wall despite their large size. 

Histologically, there is a wide variation with some of low malignant potential and others having a higher mitotic index.

  • They are fibroepithelial tumours that arise from the intralobular stroma.
  • It can be benign, borderline or malignant.
  • Phyllodes tumor can be differentiated from intracanalicular fibroadenoma by its subepithelial or periepithelial accentuation of stromal cellularity.
  • Most phyllodes tumor are of low grade. Recurrence rate is high in intermediate and high grade tumors.
  • Increased stromal cellularity, stromal overgrowth (absence of epithelial elements), nuclear atypia, increased mitosis(>10 per 10HPF) suggests the diagnosis of malignant phyllodes tumour.
  • Gain in chromosome 1q is the most frequent clonal acquired chromosomal changes seen in Phyllodes tumor. HOXB13 overexpression is associated with more aggressive clinical behaviour. 

Microscopy reveals the presence of nodules of proliferating stroma covered by epithelium (leaf-like architecture).

Note: "Phyllodes" means "leaf like" in Greek.

Treatment of phyllodes tumor:

  • Benign type- Enucleation or wide local excision
  • Massive tumors, recurrent tumors and malignant type- Mastectomy
  • Axillary dissection is not done if malignant transformation occurs because the lymphatic spread is rare.

Other Options:

Option B: Galactocele: A galactocele is a milk-filled cavity in the breast of a woman who is usually lactating. It can be caused due to lactation problems, prolactin stimulation by drugs, or duct obstruction. It presents as a palpable, round, well-circumscribed, and freely mobile mass with no fever, pain, or inflammation. It is usually subareolar and unilateral.

Option C: Paget's Disease: Presents as a chronic, eczematous eruption of the nipple which may progress to ulceration. In the majority of patients, there is also an underlying breast lump. Histology shows the presence of large, pale, vacuolated cells (Paget cells) with round or oval nuclei in the rete pegs of the epithelium.

Option D: Fibroadenoma is a form of aberrations of normal development and involution of the breast (ANDI), and it is the most common cause of a breast lump in women aged 15–25 years. It arises from hyperplasia of a single lobule and presents as a well-circumscribed, smooth or lobular, firm, non-tender, freely mobile mass (mouse in the breast). The histopathology shows the proliferation of intralobular stroma, and the epithelium may be surrounded by stroma (pericanalicular pattern) or compressed and distorted (intracanalicular pattern). The histopathology image is given below:

questions.text: All of the following are clinical features of MEN2B Syndrome except:
questions.solution:
Parathyroid adenoma is not commonly seen in MEN2B /MEN 3 Syndrome.

It is seen in MEN 1 and MEN 2A/MEN 2. 

MEN syndromes:

  • The MEN syndromes are a group of inherited diseases, resulting in proliferative lesions (hyperplasia, adenomas, and carcinomas) of multiple endocrine organs.
  • Tumors occur at a younger age than sporadic tumors.
  • Tumors arise in multiple endocrine organs, either synchronously (at the same time) or metachronously (at different times).
MEN1 MEN 2 (previously MEN2A) MEN 3 (previously MEN 2B) MEN 4

Similar to MEN 1 plus

  • Reproductive organ tumors (e.g. testicular tumors, neuroendocrine cervical carcinoma)
  • Adrenal + Renal tumors

questions.text: A laborer brings his 3 year old  child to the hospital with complaints of  multiple episodes of loose stools and tiredness. The child has swollen belly and moon face. He has been fed rice water (rice milk) in his diet mostly.  On examination  the child is found to have bilateral pedal edema and a normal capillary refill time. Which of the following statements is false regarding the management of this condition?

choices.text: Give ReSoMal 5 mL/kg every 30 min for the first 2 hours
Administer 10% glucose at 5ml/kg IV , if unconscious.
Do not continue aggressive hydration  after dehydration resolves

questions.solution:
A poor diet history (rice water) and a swollen belly are suggestive of Kwashiorkor, which is a form of severe acute malnutrition (SAM) characterized by edema and apathy and do not give IV fluids unless the child is in shock. Here the child has normal capillary refill time and hence is not in shock.

Treatment of severe malnutrition with loose stools include:

  • Do not give IV fluids unless the child is in shock.
  • Give ReSoMal (low-sodium rehydration solution for malnutrition) 5 mL/kg every 30 min for first 2 hr orally or NG tube.
  • Then give 5-10 mL/kg in alternate hours for up to 10 hr. The amount depends on stool loss and eagerness to drink. Feed every other alternate hour.
  • Give ReSoMal after each watery stool as a prevention strategy.
  • Do not continue aggressive hydration even after dehydration resolves.

Treatment of hypoglycemia in malnutrition:

  • If conscious: 10% glucose (50 mL) orally or 1 teaspoon sugar under the tongue, whichever is the quickest.
  • If unconscious: Immediately give sterile 10% glucose (5 mL/kg) by IV.

Kwashiorkor  

The features of Kwashiorkor are:

  • Edema- most likely to appear first on the feet and then in the lower legs. It can develop into generalized edema affecting the hands, arms, and face.
  • Moon face
  • Skin changes include depigmentation of skin, dermatoses, dark, cracked peeling patches (flaky paint dermatosis) with pale skin underneath that is easily infected.
  • Hair is sparse, easily pulled out, and may turn reddish.
  • Flag sign: alternating bands of hypopigmented and normal pigmented areas on the hair strand
  • The liver is often enlarged with fat (fatty liver).
  • The children are miserable and apathetic and often refuse to eat.
  • Muscle wasting and growth failure are seen.
  • Villous atrophy of small intestine and diarrhea.

Marasmus is characterized by simian facies, wrinkled old-man appearance, loose wrinkled skin with marked wasting of fat and muscle.

Related Pearl: Differences between Marasmus and Kwashiorkar

questions.text: A homeless man who is a chronic alcoholic comes to the emergency with confusion, ataxia, and nystagmus. CBG is 64; BP 110/65; PR 115/min. What should be immediately given to the patient?
questions.solution:
This patient who is a homeless alcoholic would have poor nutrition and poor absorption of Thiamine from GI tract which would lead to Wernicke's encephalopathy/alcoholic encephalopathy an acute neurological disorder caused by Thiamine deficiency. 

The triad of Wernicke's encephalopathy is:

  • Global Confusion
  • Ophthalmoplegia ( first symptom to improve with thiamine +dextrose infusion)
  • Ataxia

Treatment:

It is a medical emergency and requires immediate administration of thiamine 100 mg IV or IM for 3 days followed by two to three times a day orally for 1 to 2 weeks.

Glucose infusions may precipitate Wernicke’s disease in a previously unaffected patient or cause a rapid worsening of an early form of the disease. For this reason, thiamine should be administered to all alcoholic patients requiring parenteral glucose.

Alcohol abuse leads to thiamine deficiency by the following mechanisms:

  • Poor nutritional habits
  • Folate deficiency which reduces thiamine absorption from the gastrointestinal tract
  • Direct damage of the intestinal mucosa

questions.text: A middle-aged male patient presented to the ER with episodic headaches, palpitation, and sweating. His BP is 170/90 and is on 2 antihypertensives. What is the most likely diagnosis here?
questions.solution:
The classic triad of episodes of palpitation, headache and sweating along with hypertension is suggestive of pheochromocytoma.

Pheochromocytoma:

  • Tumour arising from Chromaffin cells
  • MC site of extra adrenal tumour is organ of zuckerkandl
  • produces catecholamines

Clinical triad:

  • Headaches – M/C symptom
  • Profuse sweating
  • Palpitations and tachycardia
  • Hypertension, sustained or paroxysmal – M/C Sign
  • Orthostatic hypotension
  • Anxiety and panic attacks

Diagnosis:

  • Urinary catecholamine and VMA level assay are most sensitive screening test.
  • MRI is the IOC.
  • Biopsy and CT Contrast scan are contraindicated in order to avoid Hypertensive crisis.

Treatment:

  • Adrenalectomy is preferred TOC.
  • Size<5 cm -  Laparoscopic adrenalectomy
  • Preop Alpha blockers should be given before Beta blockade
  • Mitotane should be started as adjuvant or palliative treatment

 

 

Related Pearl: Clinical features of Pheochromocytoma (By frequency of occurrence)

  • Clinical triad:
    • Headaches – M/C symptom
    • Profuse sweating
    • Palpitations and tachycardia
  • Hypertension, sustained or paroxysmal – M/C Sign
  • Anxiety and panic attacks
  • Weight loss
  • Polyuria and polydipsia
  • Constipation
  • Orthostatic hypotension
  • Dilated cardiomyopathy
  • Erythrocytosis
  • Elevated blood sugar
  • Hypercalcemia

questions.text: A 38-year-old pregnant woman with obstetric score G2P2L1 at 10 weeks of gestation presents with third degree uterine prolapse. Which of the following is the best management for her?
questions.solution:
For prolapse during pregnancy or puerperiem, a ring pessary is used until delivery after which an operative procedurre is considered.

questions.text: A 19-year-old woman with a history of type 1 DM is brought to the ER with confusion, vomiting, and abdominal pain. Investigations show blood glucose - 520 mg/dl and urine tests positive for ketone bodies. Which of the following is the next step in the management of this patient ?
questions.solution:
The diagnosis is DKA (diabetic ketoacidosis) and the first step in the management of DKA is to start IV fluids.

Diabetic ketoacidosis is an acute complication of type 1 diabetes mellitus. 

Symptoms

  • Nausea and vomiting
  • Abdominal pain - severe

Signs

  • Kussmaul breathing – Classical sign
  • Fruity odor on the patient’s breath – Classical sign
  • Tachycardia
  • Dehydration
  • Hypotension

Blood parameters

  • Hyperglycemia – 250 – 600 mg%

  • Overall total-body K+ deficit, However, the serum K+ at presentation may be mildly elevated, secondary to the acidosis

  • Osmolality – 300–320 mOsm/kg
  • Plasma ketones –  Positive
  • Metabolic acidosis – Increased anion gap
  • Serum bicarbonate <15 meq/L – Best initial investigation

Management of DKA

  • IV fluids – 0.9 % saline
  • IV short-acting insulin (regular insulin) bolus
  • IV short-acting insulin infusion
  • Treatment of precipitating events – Infections by antibiotics
  • K+ replacement – In the later stages, since insulin therapy causes hypokalemia

(Oral hypoglycemic agents are never used in the initial management of DKA.)

Complications of diabetic ketoacidosis 

  • Cerebral edema – children
  • Myocardial infarction
  • Venous thrombosis
  • Acute gastric dilation
  • Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome

questions.text: A 40-year-old patient with a history of fever, headache and photophobia. On examination he has neck stiffness, Kernig’s and Brudzinski sign is positive with no papilledema or neurological deficit. Which of the following is next most appropriate investigation?
questions.solution:
The next most appropriate investigation is CSF analysis and the likely diagnosis is meningitis.

Since the patient has fever with neck stiffness ,Kernig’s and Brudzinski sign positive it is highly suggestive for meningitis. There are various causes of meningitis which can be bacterial,viral, tuberculous, fungal or parasitic which can be differentiated with CSF analysis done via a lumbar puncture.

There is no associated neurological deficit or papilledema which rules out the need for an urgent imaging of the brain but in the course of an illness MRI brain can be taken.

Kernig's sign : when the thigh is flexed at the hip and knee at 90 degree angles,  subsequent extension in the knee is painful. 

Brudziński's sign : forced flexion of the neck elicits a reflex flexion of the hips.

questions.text: A 50 year old female was brought to the hospital with a history of severe pain in the left renal angle for the past 7 hours. Abdominal X ray was performed and the image (zoomed to the left)  is given below. What is the treatment of choice in this scenario?
questions.solution:
Abodminal X Ray shows a Staghorn calculi. The treatment of choice for Staghorn calculi is percutaneous nephrolithotomy (PCNL).

PCNL is the treatment of choice for Staghorn calculi. PCNL is indicated in the following types of renal calculi:

  • Large renal stones of diameter more than 2cm
  • Staghorn calculi
  • Multiple stones
  • Proximal ureteral stone: >1 cm

Technique: Endoscopic instruments are passed into the kidney using a percutaneous technique and stones are removed.

Option A: Extracorporeal shock-wave lithotripsy (ESWL) is effective for the treatment of stones having diameters of up to 1.5 cm. In ESWL, crystalline stones disintegrate under the impact of shock waves produced by the ESWL machine.

Option C: Ureteroscopical removal - Stones are retrieved by either using wire retrieval baskets (if <6 mm and in the distal ureter)

Option D: Open surgery is obsolete nowadays. Subcapsular Nephrectomy is done for longstanding obstructing calculus that can result in chronic inflammatory change in the kidney with substantial if not complete loss of function leading to Xanthogranulomatous pyelonephritis (XGP).

questions.text: A 57-year-old male patient presented to the clinic for a routine clinical check-up and his BP was 150/90 mmHg. During his subsequent visits, the systolic blood pressure  was within the range of 140-159 mmHg and diastolic blood pressure was within the range of 90-99 mmHg. According to the European guidelines for hypertension 2018, his blood pressure can be classified as ______.
questions.solution:
According to European guidelines for hypertension 2018, systolic blood pressure between 140-159 mmHg and diastolic blood pressure between 90-99 mmHg is classified as Grade 1 hypertension.

The 2017 American College of Cardiology (ACC)/American Heart Association (AHA) and 2018 European Society of Cardiology (ESC)/European Society of Hypertension (ESH) guidelines is given below  for comparison :

questions.text: A 77-year-old patient comes to ER early in the morning with eye pain, redness, and photophobia. Pain radiates to the jaw and temple. Patient's eye appears diffusely red and teary. On examination with conometry and slit lamp, there is an increase in Intraocular pressure, presenting with bulging cornea. The most likely diagnosis is ____________.
questions.solution:
A high intraocular pressure (IOP) leads to an increase in pressure, leading to the thinning of the ocular tissue, thereby resulting in a staphyloma. Ciliary and equatorial staphylomas are most commonly associated with glaucoma.

Staphyloma:

  • It is an abnormal protrusion of the uveal tissue through a weak and thin portion of the cornea or sclera.
  • So, staphyloma is lined internally by uveal tissue and externally by weak cornea or sclera.
  • Types of Staphyloma:
    • Anterior staphyloma: It is characterized by ectasia of the pseudo-cornea, which occurs after the total sloughing of the cornea. It is lined internally by the iris and externally by the newly formed epithelium.
    • Intercalary staphyloma: This is located at the limbus and is lined by the root of the iris and the anterior-most part of the ciliary body
    • Ciliary staphyloma: It is characterized by ectasia of weak sclera lined by the ciliary body. This affects the ciliary zone, which includes the region up to 8 mm behind the limbus.
    • Equatorial staphyloma: This occurs at the equatorial region up to 14 mm behind the limbus of the eye.
    • Posterior staphyloma: This affects the posterior pole of the eye.
  • Note :
    • The most common cause for anterior staphyloma is sloughing corneal ulcer.
    • The most common cause for posterior staphyloma is degenerative high axial myopia.

questions.text: A primi gravida mother in a 1st degree consanguineous marriage undergoes a quadruple screening test during the second trimester. The test results indicate a chromosomal anomaly of Trisomy 21.  Which of the following changes can be seen in the quadruple screening test?

choices.text: Lower  β-hCG, Inhibin and elevated estriol, AFP
Elevated β-hCG, Inhibin and lower estriol, AFP
Elevated β-hCG, PAPP-A and lower estriol, AFP
Lower β-hCG, PAPP-A and elevated estriol, AFP

questions.solution:
Quadruple screening is a second trimester multiple marker screening test for the detection of chromosomal anomalies like trisomy 21-Down syndrome.  

Pregnancies with Down syndrome are characterized by elevated β-hCG, Inhibin and lower estriol, AFP levels.  It is performed from 15 to 21 weeks of gestation. 

First trimester aneuploidy screening combines two maternal serum analytes,

  • Human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG) and
  • Pregnancy-associated plasma protein A (PAPP-A),
  • With the sonographic measurement of the nuchal translucency (NT).

It is performed between 11 and 14 weeks’ gestation.

In cases of fetal Down syndrome, the first-trimester serum free β-hCG level is higher and the PAPP-A level is lower.

With trisomy 18 and trisomy 13, levels of both analytes are lower.

The abnormalities seen on quadruple screen are tabulated below:

  Trisomy 21 Trisomy 18 Neural tube defect or abdominal wall defect
MSAFP Low Low High
β hCG High Low Normal
Unconjugated estriol Low Low Normal
Inhibin A High Low Normal

questions.text: A 19-year-old female comes to the clinic with complaints of poor appetite, amenorrhea, fatigue, and weakness. She feels like she looks overweight. Her BMI is 17; BP 100/60; PR 98/min. Which of the following is more commonly associated with the patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Depression is the most common psychiatric co-morbidity seen in patients with anorexia nervosa.  


Overall, anorexia nervosa is associated with depression in 65 percent of cases, social phobia in 35 percent of cases, and obsessive-compulsive disorder in 25 percent of cases.

questions.text: The maneuver employed in the picture below is called ____
questions.solution:
The maneuver portrayed in the image above is the Modified Prague maneuver.

In a breech presentation, chin to pubis delivery can be done by Prague maneuver.

  • Rarely, the back of the fetus fails to rotate to the anterior.
  • In such cases, rotation of the back to the anterior may be achieved by using stronger traction on the fetal legs or bony pelvis.
  • If this still does not succeed, the fetus still may be delivered using the modified Prague maneuver,which  consists of two fingers of one hand grasping the shoulders of the back-down fetus from below while the other hand draws the feet up and over the maternal abdomen.
  • If the back is oriented anteriorly, extraction may be accomplished using the Mauriceau maneuver and delivering the fetus back down.

 In short,

  1. If the fetal back is anterior- Mauriceau maneuver.
  2. If the fetal back is posterior-Modified Prague. (Mnemonic: P for P)

questions.text: Below skin lesion is seen in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
• Linear nodules and discharging sinuses along the lymphatics are classical of sporotrichosis.
  • Sporotrichosis is an acute or chronic fungal infection caused by Sporothrix schenckii and closely related species.

Other options:

  • Psoriasis - Erythematous plaque with silvery white scales are seen
  • Pemphigus - Flaccid superficial blisters are seen
  • Lichen planus - Purple polygonal, flat topped papules are seen

questions.text: The grade of the given urological condition and the surgical treatment option with the best outcome for this condition depicted in the image is

choices.text: Grade 4, Nephrectomy of the Damaged Kidney to Prevent Recurrent UTI

questions.solution:
The image shows a Grade V vesicoureteral reflux (VUR). The surgical treatment for this is ureteric reimplantation & it has 95-97% cure rates. Here, the ureter is reimplanted in a different site in the bladder from the normal anatomic site.

The other surgical modalities mentioned in the options have no role in isolated Vesicoureteric Reflux.

Vesicoureteric reflux (VUR) is the term for the abnormal flow of urine from the bladder into the upper urinary tract and is typically a problem encountered in young children.

Reflux from the bladder into the upper urinary tract predisposes to pyelonephritis by allowing entry of bacteria to the usually sterile upper tract. As such the diagnosis is first suspected after a urinary tract infection in a young child.

The primary diagnostic procedure for evaluation of vesicoureteric reflux is a voiding cystourethrogram (VCUG). (Investigation of Choice)

Voiding cystourethrogram (also known as micturating cystourethrogram - MCU) should be performed after the first well-documented urinary tract infection up to the age of 6 years. VCUG should evaluate:

  • Presence and grade of VUR
  • Whether reflux occurs during micturition or during bladder filling
  • Presence of associated anatomical anomalies

As VUR is autosomal dominant, USG screening is done is other siblings to rule out the disease.

Scars can be ruled out using DMSA Renal Scintigraphy.

VUR is the most common cause of renal scarring, and hence, scarring is considered one of the indications of VUR.

TREATMENT:

VUR often resolves over time and that if UTIs can be prevented, the morbidity or complications of VUR may be avoided without surgery.

Medical therapy includes observation with behavioral modification or behavioral modification with antimicrobial prophylaxis in some patients.

Surgical therapy includes ureteral re implantation and subureteral injection of a bulking agent.

VUR severity is graded based on the appearance of the urinary tract on a contrast voiding cystourethrogram.

VUR is graded as follows:

 GRADE DESCRIPTION
              I Reflux into a non-dilated ureter
             II Reflux into the pelvis and calyces without dilatation of the ureter
             III Reflux is associated with mild to moderate dilatation of the ureter, renal pelvis, and calyces, with minimal blunting of the fornices
             IV Moderate ureteral tortuosity and dilatation of the pelvis and calyces
              V Gross dilatation of the ureter, pelvis, and calyses; loss of papillary impressions; ureteral  tortuosity

questions.text: Patient comes with fever, annular erythematous painful lesions all over the body including the mouth. On gentle lateral pressure, the skin over the lesion peels off. This sign is seen in all except ?
questions.solution:
The clinical manifestation of this patient is Pemphigus Vulgaris which may present mucosal or mucocutaneous involvement. Nearly all patients present mucosal lesions, mainly in the oral mucosa, with or without cutaneous lesions. Nikolsky's sign is positive in Pemphigus Vulgaris, Toxic epidermal necrolysis,  Staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome. 

Nikolsky's sign is absent in bullous pemphigoid

Nikolsky's sign is pathognomic for pemphigus, toxic epidermal necrolysis, and staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome.

It is elicited by applying tangential/lateral pressure by a thumb or a finger in the perilesional skin, affected skin, or normal skin, which results in a force that dislodges upper layers of epidermis from lower layers.

The core pathophysiology behind this sign is acantholysis defined as the loss of coherence between epidermal cells because of the breakdown of their intercellular bridges.

questions.text: A newborn  child presented with the evisceration of bowel loops in the umbilical region and the contents are covered by a sac. The most probable diagnosis is
questions.solution:
The most probable diagnosis here is Omphalocele as the bowels loops are covered by amnion and is seen in the umbilical region. 

Omphalocele: It occurs when the bowel loops fail to return from the physiologic umbilical hernia. Since the umbilicus is covered by a reflection of the amnion, the omphalocele is also covered by amnion, which helps to differentiate it from gastrochisis where the bowel loops are not covered by amnion. It is associated with severe malformations such as cardiac anomalies and neural tube defects. Both omphalocele and gastrochisis are associated with elevated AFP levels.

The defects seen in ventral body wall include:

  • Gastroschisis: It occurs when there is a failure in the closure of the body wall in the abdominal region.The intestinal loops herniate through the defect in the abdominal wall. The defect usually lies to one side of the umbilicus (right side commonly). The loops of bowel are not covered by amnion as they herniate through the abdominal wall directly into the amniotic cavity. The affected bowel loops can be damaged by exposure to amniotic fluid. . 
  • Congenital umbilical hernia: This is due to a failure of the umbilical ring to close after physiologic herniation of the intestines.

Related Pearl: Difference between gastroschisis and omphalocele

Characteristic Gastroschisis Omphalocele
Defect size (diameter) 2-3 cm 2-15 cm
Sac Never Always, may be ruptured
Gestational age Prematurity Term
Umbilical cord Adjacent to the defect (defect is seen usually on its right side)  Attached to sac
Herniated viscera Small bowel, stomach, colon Small bowel, stomach, colon, liver
Malrotation Yes Yes
Bowel character Inflammatory, edematous Normal
Enternal nutrition Delayed Normal
Associated abnormalities Uncommon (10% atresia) Common (50%)

questions.text: A 65 year old farmer presented with the following lesion in the lower eyelid. He complains of bleeding while itching. All of the following are true regarding the diagnosis EXCEPT?

choices.text: Strongest predisposing factor to BCC is UVR
Nodular/ Nodulocystic variety accounts for majority of BCC

questions.solution:
The given image depicts a classic case of Basal cell carcinoma. BCC is the most common malginant eyelid tumor (not benign).

Basal cell carcinoma is a slow-growing, locally-invasive, malignant tumour of pluripotential epithelial cells arising from basal epidermis and hair follicles; hence, it affects the pilo-sebaceous skin.

Most of the basal cell carcinoma occurs on the face above the line joining corner of mouth and lobule of the ear. Most common site is inner canthus of eye. 

BCC is the most common malignant eyelid tumor.

The strongest risk factor for developing basal cell carcinoma is exposure to UV radiation (UVB rays more than UVA rays). Therefore it occurs on the sun-exposed areas of the skin, most commonly on the nose and face.

BCC can be divided into localized and generalized. The localized can be further divided into

  • Nodular and nodulocystic- account for the majority of BCC
    • characterized by pearly opalescent nodules with central depression with umbilication or ulceration and rolled edges and telangiectasia giving the classic “rodent ulcer” appearance.
  • Cystic
  • Pigmented - difficult to differentiate from nodular melanoma.
  • Naevoid.

Generalized can be further divided into superficial or infiltrative.

The characteristic finding of BCC is the presence of ovoid cells in nests and a single layer of palisading peripheral cells of the nests.

Treatment of BCC includes excision of the lesion or Moh's micrographic surgery.

  1. Surgical excision should include 4 mm margins for small, primary BCC on cosmetically sensitive areas, and 10 mm margins otherwise.
 
  1. Mohs microsurgical excision is sequential horizontal excision. It is the treatment of choice for
    • BCC with aggressive features
    • poorly delineated margins
    • recurrent tumors
    • cosmetically sensitive areas,especially in the midface.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male is brought to the ER with  muscle weakness, fatigue. and is a known case of CKD on enalapril for the same. His ECG is given below. What is the electrolyte abnormality here?
questions.solution:
The history along with absent P waves and peaked T waves in the ECG indicate hyperkalemia.

The patient is also on enalapril which is an Angiotensin converting enzyme inhibitor which leads to RAAS inhibition leading to hyperkalemia and hyponatremia.

The ECG findings constitute a medical emergency and immediate intravenous infusion of calcium gluconate is the first step in management.

 ECG CHANGES IN HYPERKALEMIA  

A peaked T wave is the first ECG change in hyperkalemia and with increasing potassium concentration, P waves are lost and QRS complexes widen, ultimately deteriorating into ventricular arrhythmias/asystole.

 

Classical ECG manifestations 

 S.Pottassium concentrations 
Tall peaked T wave 5.5 - 6.5
Loss of P wave 6.5 - 7.5
Widened QRS complex 7.0 - 8.0
Sine wave pattern >8.0

 

1) Tall peaked T wave

2) Loss of P wave

3) Widened QRS Complex

4) Sine wave pattern

Steps in management:

1) Cardiac stabilization:

Under cardiac monitoring, IV infusion of 10 ml of 10% calcium gluconate in 2-3 minutes reverses the cardiac depolarization blockade caused by hyperkalemia. Thus, fatal arrhythmias such as sinus bradycardia/arrest, asystole, and ventricular tachycardia/fibrillation are prevented.

2) Displacement of potassium into cells:

Following stabilization, intravenous regular insulin is given with/without iv dextrose based on monitored glucose concentrations. 

Inhaled beta-2 agonists have an additive effect and can be used along with insulin.

3) Definitive removal of potassium from the body:

It is accomplished using cation exchange resins, diuretics and through dialysis.

questions.text: A patient is diagnosed to have a ruptured tubo-ovarian abscess. Which staging of PID does this fall under?
questions.solution:
A ruptured tubo-ovarian abscess is seen in stage 4 of PID as described by Gainesville.

Stages of PID:

Stage

Condition 

Stage I 

Acute salpingitis without peritonitis—no adhesions 

Stage II 

Acute salpingitis with peritonitis—purulent discharge  

Stage III 

Acute salpingitis with superimposed tubal occlusion or tubo-ovarian complex 

Stage IV 

Ruptured tubo-ovarian abscess 

Stage V  

Tubercular salpingitis

questions.text: The position of the patient in the image shown below is known as
questions.solution:
The above image shows reverse trendelenberg position, where the patient's head is elevated 15 - 30 degrees higher than the feet.  It is named so, as the position is reverse of the trendelenberg position, where the head end is lower and the feet is at higher level.

Example: In laparoscopic cholecystectomy the patient is placed in a reverse trendelenburg position slightly rotated to the left. This exposes the fundus of the gallbladder which is retracted towards the diaphragm.

The trendelenberg and reverse trendelenberg positions are used in surgeries that are required to move the abdominal viscera, such as small bowel, away from the operative field. Restraints and side boards are placed to prevent the patient from sliding from the bed.

 

Option A: Lloyd Davis position - head down lithotomy used in pelvic and rectal surgeries. (image below)

Option B: Jack knife position - prone with buttocks elevated (also known as Kraske position) used in colorectal surgeries. (image below)

Option C: Trendelenberg position - head down position used in hernia surgeries, surgeries of abdomen and genitourinary system, placement of central venous catheter in the interal jugular vein or the subclavian vein. (image below)

Related Pearl: Eponyms named after Friedrich Trendelenburg

  • Trendelenburg sign: This sign is demonstrated by asking the patient to stand on one limb. When the patient stands on the affected limb, the pelvis severely drops over the swing limb. This is seen in the paralysis of gluteus medius and minimus, dislocated hip, fracture neck of femur
  • Trendelenburg gait: This gait is seen in patients with Trendelenburg sign. The body swings to the opposite side every time when the weight is borne on the same side. 
  • Trendelenberg position: It is a position in which the patient is placed on a bed which is put into incline such that the patient's head is lower than his feet (head-down position)
  • Reverse Trendelenberg position: It is a position in which the patient is placed on a bed which is put into incline such that the patient's feet are lower than his head (head-up position)
  • Brodie Trendelenburg test: It is a test for presence of incompetent valves in lower limb.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child is brought to the OPD with a history of mental retardation, failure to walk or talk, failure to grow, seizures, hyperactivity, and tremors. On examination, there is microcephaly, fair hair, light skin color, and blue eyes. He also has a mousy odor. Which of the following statements regarding this condition is false ?

choices.text: Neonatal screening is useful in this condition
It is due to PAH deficiency

questions.solution:
The given clinical manifestations point to the diagnosis of Phenylketonuria (PKU) and it is an autosomal recessive disorder.

Here there is deficiency of  Phenylalanine hydroxylase(PAH) or of its cofactor tetrahydrobiopterin (BH4)  which leads which leads to accumulation of phenylalanine in body fluids and in the brain. Children affected with this condition can have an unpleasant odor of phenylacetic acid termed as 'mousey' odor.

 Characteristic clinical findings in Phenylketonuria:

  • Mental retardation
  • Failure to walk or talk
  • Seizures
  • Hyperactivity
  • Tremor
  • Microcephaly
  • Failure to grow
  • Deficiency of pigmentation (fair hair, light skin color, and blue eyes)

Neonatal screening is useful in early detection of this condition. Since the clinical manifestations are due to hyperphenylalaninemia, early detection and a low phenylalanine diet is the mainstay of management.

Related Pearl: Phenylketonuria

  1. BH4 - tetrahydrobiopterin (or sapropterin, a synthetic form of BH4)

questions.text: All structures can be seen in the following x ray view except?
questions.solution:
The above X Ray view is called as ' Caldwell's view'.

Structures seen in Caldwell's view are:

  • Frontal sinuses (seen best)
  • Ethmoid sinuses
  • Maxillary sinuses
  • Frontal process of the zygoma and the zygomatic process of the frontal bone
  • Superior margin of orbit and lamina papyracea
  • Superior orbital fissure
  • Foramen rotundum (inferolateral to superior orbital fissure)

In Caldwell's view.

  • The nose and forehead are touching the x-ray film
  • The X-ray beam is projected 15 degrees h

questions.text: The clinical classification under CEAP guidelines in a patient with the following feature would be:
questions.solution:
The given image is characteristic of atrophie blanche which is classified as C4B under CEAP guidelines.

The clinical class of C4 under CEAP includes changes in skin and subcutaneous tissue secondary to chronic venous disease. It is further classified as,

  • C4a-Pigmentation or eczema
  • C4b-Lipodermatosclerosis or atrophie blanche
  • C4c-Corona phlebectatica

Atrophie blanche is a localized white atrophic skin frequently surrounded by dilated capillaries and hyperpigmentation, usually seen around the ankle. This is a sign of severe chronic venous disease.

Image below shows atrophie blanche.

Lipodermatosclerosis(C4b) is due to chronic inflammation and fibrosis leading to a tight, contracted, 'woody' leg. Can lead to contractures over the Achilles tendon and is a sign of severe chronic venous disease.

Corona phlebectatica(C4c) are fan-shaped patterns of telangiectasia over the ankle or foot. Considered an early sign of advanced disease.

 Recent 2020 update on the CEAP system includes the following changes -

  1. C2r for recurrent varicose veins
  2. C4c for Corona phlebectatica
  3. C6r for recurrent active venous ulcer.

Related Pearl: Classification of Chronic Lower Extremity Venous Disease

Telangiectases are less than 1 mm, reticular veins are between 1 and 3 mm, and varicose veins are greater than 3 mm measured in the upright position.

questions.text: A drug with the lowest potency would have the following characteristic _____
questions.solution:
A drug with the lowest potency would have High MAC

Minimum alveolar concentration (MAC) value of an inhaled anesthetic is a measure of potency of the anesthetic agent. A drug with the lowest MAC would have the highest potency.

The speed of induction and recovery is indicated by the blood gas partition coefficient.

Least potent: Nitrous oxide with a MAC value of 104%. 1MAC with nitrous oxide is practically not possible and thus it is always combined with other agents.

Most potent: Methoxyflurane (MAC- 0.16%) > Trilene (MAC-0.2%), both of which are obsolete now. Among the inhaled agents in clinical use, Halothane is the most potent.

Related Pearl: Minimum alveolar concentration (MAC)

Minimum alveolar concentration (MAC) is the minimum concentration of an inhaled anesthetic at 1 atm of pressure that prevents skeletal muscle movement in response to a surgical incision in 50% of patients. 

MAC of inhaled anesthetics

Anesthetic Agents

MAC

(Potency)

Blood-gas coefficient

(Solubility)
Halothane 0.75  2.4
Isoflurane 1.2 1.4 
Enflurane 1.7 1.9 
Sevoflurane 2 0.65 
Desflurane 6 0.42 
Nitrous oxide 104 0.47 

MAC is an indicator of potency. Lower the MAC, higher is the potency.

Blood gas partition coefficient is an indicator of solubility, which affects the rate of induction and emergence. Lower the B-G coefficient, faster is the induction and emergence. It is not related to MAC/potency.

questions.text: A 5-day-old, full-term male infant was severely cyanotic at birth. The physician notes that there is  improvement in oxygenation with Prostaglandin E1 administration  . Chest X ray of the child given below shows ________.
questions.solution:
Cyanosis at birth and improvement in oxygenation with prostagladin E1 administration is suggestive of transposition of great vessels (TGA) and the X ray shows the presence of Egg on side appearance, a characteristic radiograph finding in TGA.

TGA is characterized by the aorta arising from the right ventricle and pulmonary artery from the left ventricle. Since systemic and pulmonary circulations are separate, survival depends on the mixing of oxygenated pulmonary blood and deoxygenated systemic blood which can occur:

  • At atrial level: Through atrial septal defect (ASD)
  • At ventricle level: Through ventricular septal defect (VSD)
  • At great vessel level: Through patent ductus arteriosus

Chest X-ray image shows cardiomegaly, a narrow mediastinum (the classic “egg-shaped heart”), and normal to increased pulmonary blood flow. The narrow pedicle of the heart is because of the malposition of the great vessels.

Treatment: Here, prostagladin E1 administration and septostomy help initial stabilization by creating a communication between the right and left atria, thereby facilitating the mixing of systemic and pulmonary circulations.Rashkind ballon atrial septostomy is done as a temporary procedure in infants who remain severely hypoxemic even after prostaglandin administration.

Definitive surgeryv: Jatene's procedure(arterial switch procedure)

Other options:

Box shaped heart - Ebstein's Anomaly

Snowman's heart appearance or Figure of 8 appearance - Supracardiac TAPVC

Boot shaped heart - Tetralogy of Fallot (TOF)

 

 

Related Pearl: Radiological findings in some congenital heart defects

Boot shaped heart - Tetralogy of Fallot (TOF)

 

Egg on side appearance - Transposition of Great Arteries (TGA)

 

Snowman's heart appearance or Figure of 8 appearance - Supracardiac TAPVC

questions.text: A 38-year-old male is suffering from increasing difficulty in bending forward with increasing stiffness of the spine and reduced chest movements. These symptoms are present for the past 4 months and it improves with exercise. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Based on the clinical description the most likely diagnosis is Ankylosing spondylitis.

Diagnostic criteria for ankylosing spondylitis:

  • Insidious onset
  • Morning stiffness 
  • Symptoms begin early at age <40 years
  • Improvement with exercise
  • Persistence for >3 months  

Examination findings:

  • Loss of lumbar lordosis
  • Increased thoracic kyphosis
  • Diminished spinal movements
  • Decreased chest expansion ( <7 cm)
  • Positive tests for sacroiliac joint involvement

Important X-ray features:

  • Sacro-iliac joints:
    • Cardinal sign/earliest sign– erosion and fuzziness of the sacroiliac joints
    • Later- peri-articular sclerosis and bony ankylosis of the joint
  • Vertebral changes:
    • Earliest- flattening of the normal anterior concavity of the vertebral body (‘squaring’)
    • Later- ossification of the ligaments around the intervertebral discs produces syndesmophytes (bridges) between adjacent vertebrae
    • Bamboo spine appearance- due to bridging at several vertebral levels

Other options:

Psoriatic arthritis: Females over 50 years of age are predominantly affected and it involves distal and proximal interphalangeal(IP) joints.

Reiter's disease: It is predominantly seen in females between 16-35 years and weight bearing joints such as knee and ankle are commonly involved.

Behcet's syndrome: Males between 15-40 years of age are commonly affected.Knee,ankle,hand and wrist joints are primarily affected in this condition.

 

Related Pearl: Ankylosing Spondylitis VS Diffuse idiopathic skeletal hyperostosis

           DISH         AS
Etiology Idiopathic Autoimmune
Age group Older patients (middle-aged) Younger patients
HLA No evidence of association with HLA-B27 Strong association with HLA-B27
Lab investigations Non-specific and inconclusive High ESR and CRP
Syndesmophytes Nonmarginal Marginal
Radiograph "Flowing candle wax"  "Bamboo spine" 
Disc space Preservation of disc space AS in cervical spine will show ossification of disc space 
SI joint involvement  No involvement (SI joint abnormality generally excludes the diagnosis of DISH)  Bilateral sacroiliitis
Associated disease Obesity, diabetes mellitus, hypervitaminosis A Autoimmune conditions like iritis, uveitis, ulcerative colitis

questions.text: A 25-year-old male patient presented with altered bowel habits and intermittent bleeding from the rectum for the past 6 months. Proctoscopy was normal. Colonoscopy was done and the findings as shown in the image below was seen in the entire descending and sigmoid colon. Biopsy revealed tubular adenomatous changes. What is the best method of management in this patient?

choices.text: Total colectomy with ileal pouch-anal anastomosis
Total proctocolectomy with ileal pouch-anal anastomosis

questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is diagnostic of Familial adenomatous polyposis syndrome. Since the patient is young, the patient is best treated with total proctocolectomy with ileal pouch-anal anastomosis. This procedure is usually accompanied by resection of the rectal mucosa.

Familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP):

It is an autosomal dominant condition and is caused due to the mutation in the APC gene located on chromosome 5.

  • Accounts for 1% of all colorectal carcinoma
  • Characterized by the presence of >100 adenomatous polyps in colon and rectum
  • Manifests by late 2nd or early 3rd decade
  • 100% risk of development of cancer
 The current definition of familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP) requires evidence of any one of below:
  1. Germline mutation in APC gene
  2. ≥100 colorectal adenomatous polyps (classical definition)
  3. Any colorectal adenomas under age 30 in a patient with a family history of FAP
  4. Intra-abdominal desmoid fibromatosis, osteoma of the mandible, or multiple epidermoid cysts in a patient with a family history of FA

The treatment of the FAP includes total proctocolectomy with ileal pouch-anal anastomosis (IPAA). Following surgery, the patient has to be routinely followed up for ileoanal-pouch surveillance. Upper GI endoscopy should also be performed to evaluate for the presence of duodenal adenomas.

 Variants of FAP are:

  1. Gardner's syndrome- It is an autosomal dominant variant of FAP. In addition to colonic polyps the patients will have
    • Osteomas of the mandible or skull 
    • Epidermal cysts
    • Soft tissue tumors like desmoid tumor
  2. Turcot's syndrome- In addition to the colonic polyps the patients will have central nervous system tumors (primary brain tumors).

Related Pearl: Features of Familial Adenomatous Polyposis

Gastrointestinal manifestations:

  • Colon and rectum: Multiple adenomatous polyp usually >100
  • Gastric and duodenal polyps are present in 50% cases.
  • Gastric polyp: fundal gland polyp, gastric adenoma.
  • Duodenal polyp usually in the ampullary region: Adenomatous and premalignant

Extraintestinal manifestations

  • Congenital hypertrophy of retinal pigment epithelium (CHRPE) seen in 75% of cases; it is detected by indirect ophthalmoscopy.
  • Epidermoid cysts
  • Desmoid tumors in the abdomen
  • Osteoma: In the skull, mandible, and tibia
  • Brain tumors
  • Tumors of the thyroid, adrenal, liver, pancreas, gallbladder, and bile duct

questions.text: A mother brings her 2 year old child to the Emergency room because she noticed some blood in his stool. The child appears comfortable but cries when the RLQ is palpated. A technetium-99m scan shows findings as shown in the image. Which type of tissue does this scan detect to aid the diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette describing a patient having painless bleeding per rectum with the tenderness of the RLQ and positive imaging findings on 99mTc-pertechnetate describes a case of Meckel's diverticulum. The 99mTc-pertechnetate detects ectopic gastric tissue.

Meckel’s Diverticulum is congenital true diverticulum containing all layers of intestine arising from anti-mesenteric border of ileum.

  • Meckel’s diverticulum is caused by a failure of normal regression of the vitelline duct that develops during weeks 5 to 7 of gestation.
  • May harbour abnormal tissues, containing embryonic remnants of other tissue types, mostly gastric mucosa.
  • Most common presentation is painless, massive, lower GI bleed in children younger than 5 years.
  • Diverticular inflammation may mimic acute appendicitis; since Meckel’s diverticulum and the appendix are both derived from midgut structures, pain is referred to the periumbilical region.
  • A Meckel's can be the lead point for ileoileal or ileocolic intussusception.

Littre's hernia is a rare inguinal hernia where Meckel's diverticulum is the content of the sac.

Diagnosis of Meckel’s diverticulum -

  • Most of the Meckel’s diverticula are discovered incidentally. In the absence of bleeding, Meckel’s diverticula are rarely diagnosed prior to the time of surgical intervention.
  • Radionuclide scans (99mTc-pertechnetate): For the identification of the ectopic gastric mucosa, the most accurate diagnostic test in children is Scintigraphy with sodium 99mTc-pertechnetate. (accuracy 90% ). It is less accurate in adults ( 50% accuracy ) because of the reduced prevalence of ectopic gastric mucosa. In adults: Barium studies are done. The sensitivity and specificity can be improved by pentagastrin and glucagon or H2-receptor antagonists (cimetidine).
  • Angiography: It is used to locate the site of bleeding in acute hemorrhage.
  • CT scan: It has a very low sensitivity.
  • Enteroclysis: It is not applicable during acute presentations.
 

Management of Meckel's diverticulum - 

For asymptomatic Meckel's seen on imaging, no treatment is recommended. For those where symptoms are present and diagnosis is made during abdominal exploration, diverticulectomy is recommended. Conservative management is not the only treatment for an incidentally detected Meckel's diverticulum. When found in the course of abdominal surgery, a Meckel’s diverticulum can safely be left alone, provided it has a wide mouth and is not thickened. When there is doubt, it can be resected. 

In a narrow-mouthed, thickened Meckel’s diverticulum, resection of diverticulum is the treatment of choice.

For symptomatic diverticulum, the treatment is diverticulectomy with removal of associated bands connecting the diverticulum to the abdominal wall or intestinal mesentery. 

Segmental resection of the ileum that includes both the diverticulum and the adjacent ileal peptic ulcer should be performed if

  •  there is bleeding from the diverticulum
  •  the base is inflamed or perforated
  •  the diverticulum contains a tumor.

Related Pearl: Rule of two’s in Meckel's diverticulum

  • 2% prevalence
  • 2:1 male predominance
  • Location 2 feet (60 cm) proximal to the ileocecal valve in adults
  • 2 inches in length
  • Half of those who are symptomatic are under 2 years of age.

questions.text: Which among the following is not a normal physiological change during pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Splitting of S2 is not normal during pregnancy. There is an exagerrated split of S1.

Loud S3, systolic murmur and left axis deviation on ECG are all normal cardiovascular changes observed during pregnancy. (Option B, C and D)

Related Pearl: Cardiovascular changes in pregnancy

  • The resting pulse rate increases by 10 beats/min
  • The apex is moved laterally 
  • Cardiac output remains elevated throughout (maximum in the immediate postpartum period)
  • X-Ray shows a larger cardiac silhouette (due to benign pericardial effusion and shifted apex)
  • ECG: Slight left axis deviation

Heart sounds:

  • First heart sound: Loud with an exaggerated split
  • Second heart sound: Normal but loud
  • Third heart sound: Loud and easily heard

Murmurs:

  • A systolic murmur that was intensified during inspiration or expiration
  • A soft diastolic murmur (in 20%)
  • Continuous murmur arising from the breast vasculature (in 10%)

questions.text: Nephrogram shows the below image. Diagnosis is ______
questions.solution:
The Xray of IVP, there is persistent dense nephrogram on the left side, even when contrast has washed off from the right side. Acute urinary obstruction shows a dense persistent nephrogram.

Hydronephrosis (chronic obstruction) and acute complete arterial obstruction shows a rim nephrogram.

ARPCKD shows a striated nephrogram.

questions.text: The X ray given below is of a child who fell on his  outstretched hand. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given X-ray shows a fracture in the proximal third of the ulna and there is a dislocation of the proximal radioulnar joint, which is diagnostic of Monteggia fracture-dislocation. 

Dislocation of the head of the radius can be detected using the McLaughlin’s line (radiocapitellar line). A line drawn along the centre of the shaft of the radius will cut the capitellum of humerus in the centre irrespective of the position of the elbow. In Monteggia fracture this relationship is disturbed. 

 

Clinical features:

The mechanism of injury in these fractures is usually falling on the outstretched hand. On clinical examination, the deformity in the proximal forearm due to ulnar fracture is usually obvious. The dislocation of the head of radius may be masked by the swelling. Pain and tenderness on the lateral side of the elbow are suggestive of proximal radioulnar dislocation. 

Management:

Monteggia fracture is a fracture of necessity and is treated surgically. The ulnar fracture is reduced and bone restored to full length. It is then fixed with plate and screws. The radial head usually reduces once the ulna is fixed. 

Related Pearl: Named fractures of the upper limb

Colle's fracture: Fracture of the distal radius with dorsal angulation of the distal bone fragment.

Smith's fracture: Reverse Colles' fracture. Fracture of the distal one-third of the radius with palmar displacement.

Galeazzi fracture-dislocation: Fracture of the lower third of the radius and subluxation of the distal radio-ulnar joint.

Monteggia fracture-dislocation: Fracture of the shaft of the ulna with dislocation of a proximal radio-ulnar joint.

Barton’s fracture: Intra-articular fracture of the distal radius.

Rolando's fracture: Intra-articular comminuted fracture of the base of the first metacarpal with a T or Y configuration.

Chauffeur's fracture or the Hutchinson fracture: Fracture of the radial styloid.

Essex–Lopresti lesion: Fracture of the radial head with disruption of the interosseous membrane and distal radial ulnar joint ligaments.

Nightstick fracture: Isolated fracture of the ulnar bone.

questions.text: 36-year-old male patient presents with recurrent episodes of bloody diarrhea. He was also previously diagnosed with primary sclerosing cholangitis. The given image shows the colon of this patient . What is the most possible diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of bloody diarrhoea and Primary sclerosing cholangitis along with the image that shows diffuse involvement of mucosa and ulcers without skip lesions or cobblestone appearance, points towards a diagnosis of ulcerative colitis.

The  characteristic features in ulcerative colitis:

  • Proctocolitis/backwash ileitis
  • Mucosa and superficial submucosal involvement
  • Broad-based ulcers
  • Pseudopolyps and mucosal bridges
  • Toxic megacolon
  • Primary sclerosing cholangitis, an extraintestinal manifestation associated with IBD, more commonly with UC. 

The charachteristic features in Crohn's disease :

  • Normal mucosa present in between ulcers indicates skip lesions.
  • Cobblestone appearance- Deep, longitudinal ulcerations interlaced with intervening normal mucosa
  • Transmural inflammation- Full-thickness inflammation involving all the layers of the bowel
  • Aphthous ulcers- Small, shallow ulcers surrounded by erythema
  • Longitudinal ulcers- Linear or serpiginous deep ulcers 
  • Creeping fat- Mesenteric fat wrapping around the inflamed bowel.
  • Strictures and fistulae are the commonly associated complications of long standing Crohn's disease.
  • Associated with perianal disease

 Cobblestone appearance of the bowel as seen in Crohn's disease-

Endoscopic appearance of Crohn's disease-cobblestone appearance.

Related Pearl: Difference between Ulcerative Colitis and Crohn's Disease

ULCERATIVE COLITIS CROHN'S DISEASE
Proctocolitis/Backwash ileitis Affects any part of the GIT, most commonly the iliocecal region
Mucosal disease Affects the full thickness of the bowel wall (transmural)

Strictures and fistulas are not common They are more commonly associated with strictures and fistulas.

It does not usually affect the terminal ileum.

 When symptoms affect the terminal ileum, symptoms may mimic appendicitis.
Resection of the colon and rectum is curative. Recurrence is common after resection.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding Kawasaki disease?

choices.text: Long term aspirin is contraindicated in patients with coronary artery aneurysms

questions.solution:
Bilateral non purulent conjunctival congestion is a feature of Kawasaki disease.

Kawasaki disease is also known as mucocutaneous lymph node syndrome and is commonly seen in children between 3 months to 5 years of age.

Diagnosis of typical Kawasaki disease is made by fever for 5 or more days along with four of the symptoms listed below:

  • Bilateral conjunctival congestion (not purulent conjunctivitis)
  • Oral changes: erythematous, cracked lips, and strawberry tongue
  • Non-suppurative cervical lymphadenopathy, usually unilateral
  • Polymorphous rash
  • Changes in extremities: erythema and edema, desquamation of palms and soles

Laboratory findings:

Important laboratory findings of Kawasaki disease are anaemia, elevated ESR and CRP.Thrombocytosis is a characteristic finding in Kawasaki disease and commonly occurs in the second week.

Treatment:

 Acute KD:
• IVIG 2 g/kg over 10-12 hr
• High dose aspirin (80-100 mg/kg/day, q6h) until patient is afebrile for at least 48 hr

Convalescent phase:
• Aspirin 3-5 mg/kg once daily for 6-8 wk after illness onset, if  coronary findings are normal throughout the course.


Long term therapy for patients with coronary abnormalities
• Aspirin 3-5 mg/kg once daily 
• Clopidogrel 1 mg/kg/day (maximum: 75 mg/day)

Acute coronary thrombosis
•Fibrinolytic therapy to be started with tissue plasminogen activator
or other thrombolytic agents.

Major complications of Kawasaki disease are arteritis and aneurysms of coronary vessels, myocarditis, myocardial infarction and pericarditis.

questions.text: Causes of acute pancreatitis are all except______
questions.solution:
Hypercalcemia causes acute pancreatitis but acute pancreatitis leads to Hypocalcemia.

Acute pancreatitis:

Abdominal pain  is the major symptom of acute pancreatitis.The pain, which is steady and boring in character,is located in the epigastrium and periumbilical region.Pain may radiate to the back, chest, flanks, and lower abdomen.

In necrotizing pancreatitis, there is bruising of skin seen as

  • A-Grey turner's sign: Bruising in the flanks
  • B-Cullen's sign: Periumbilical bruising

Lab findings of acute pancreatitis include:

  • Elevated pancreatic amylase
  • Leucocytosis
  • Hyperglycemia
    • Including decreased insulin
    • Increased glucagon release
    • Output of adrenal glucocorticoids
  • Hypocalcemia (<8)
  • Hyperbilirubinemia (>4 mg / dL)
  • LDH (<8.5 micromol per litre)
  • Serum albumin (<3 g / dL)
  • Hypertriglyceridemia
  • Proteinuria
  • Granular cast

Differential diagnosis of acute pancreatitis

  • Biliary colic
  • Acute cholecystitis
  • Perforated hollow viscus (e.g., perforated peptic ulcer)
  • Mesenteric ischemia or infarction
  • Intestinal obstruction
  • Myocardial infarction
  • Dissecting aortic aneurysm
  • Ectopic pregnancy
  • DKA
  • Connective tissue disorders with vasculitis

Related Pearl: Causes of Acute Pancreatitis

Common Causes

  • Gallstones (M/C cause)
  • Alcohol
  • Hypertriglyceridemia
  • ERCP
  • Drugs(corticosteroids, azathioprine, asparaginase, valproic acid, thiazides, oestrogens)
  • Trauma (especially blunt abdominal trauma)
  • Postoperative (abdominal and nonabdominal operations)

Uncommon Causes

  • Vascular causes and vasculitis
  • Connective tissue disorders & TTP
  • Pancreatic cancer
  • Hypercalcemia
  • Periampullary diverticulum
  • Pancreas divisum
  • Cystic fibrosis
  • Renal failure
  • Infections (mumps, coxsackievirus, cytomegalovirus, echovirus, parasites)
  • Autoimmune (e.g., type 1 and type 2)

Related Pearl: Assessment of severity of acute pancreatitis

  • At the time of admission:
    • Bedside Index for Severity of Acute Pancreatitis (BISAP)
      • Pleural effusion
      • Presence of systemic inflammatory response syndrome (SIRS)
      • Blood urea nitrogen, > 25 mg/dL
      • Impaired mental status, Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score <15
      • Age > 60 years
    • Harmless Acute Pancreatitis Score (HAPS)
      • Absence of rebound tenderness or guarding
      • Normal haematocrit
      • Normal serum creatinine
      • If all 3 features are present then patient is considered non-severe, i.e., no death, no need for dialysis, and no need of ventilation
  • 24-hours following admission:
    • Acute Physiology and Chronic Health Evaluation (APACHE II) score of 8 or more
    • Can also be done at admission and repeated any time
    • Disadvantages: Complex, not specific for AP, and based on the patient’s age, which easily upgrades the acute pancreatitis severity score
  • At 48 hours of admission:
    • Serum C-reactive protein level of >150 mg/dL
    • Ranson’s score
    • Modified Glasgow criteria
    • In above 2 scores when there are 3 or more positive criteria, the disease is considered “predicted severe.”

Related Pearl: Ranson Prognostic Criteria for Acute Pancreatitis

Ranson Prognostic Criteria for Non-gallstone pancreatitis:

At presentation

  • Age >55 years
  • Blood glucose level, >200 mg/dL
  • White blood cell count, >16,000 cells/mm3
  • Serum lactate dehydrogenase level, >350 IU/L
  • Serum Aspartate aminotransferase level >250 IU/L

After 48 hours of admission

  • Hematocrit: decrease >10%
  • Serum calcium level <8 mg/dL
  • Base deficit >4 mEq/L
  • Blood urea nitrogen level: increase >5 mg/dL
  • Fluid requirement >6 L
  • PaO2 <60 mm Hg

Ranson score ≥3 defines severe pancreatitis.

Ranson Prognostic Criteria for Gallstone Pancreatitis:

At presentation

  • Age >70 years
  • Blood glucose level, >220 mg/dL
  • White blood cell count, >18,000 cells/mm3
  • Serum lactate dehydrogenase level, >400 IU/L
  • Serum aspartate aminotransferase level, >250 IU/L

After 48 hours of admission

  • Hematocrit: decrease >10%
  • Serum calcium level <8 mg/dL
  • Base deficit >5 mEq/L
  • Blood urea nitrogen level: increase >2 mg/dL
  • Fluid requirement >4 L
  • PaO2: Not available

Ranson score ≥3 defines severe pancreatitis.

questions.text: Which of the following is false about Menopause?

choices.text: Premature menopause is before the age of 38
Menopause setting after 55 years is delayed menopause
Average age of menopause is 47 years

questions.solution:
Menopause seting before the age of 40 is termed as premature menopause.

Other features of menopause :

  • The average age of menopause is 47 years. (Option D)
  • The range of menopause age is 45 to 50 years. 
  • Menopause setting after 55 years is delayed menopause. (Option C)
  • Menopause sets in when follicle number falls below 1000.
  • Menopause age is not related to age at menarche, race, number of pregnancy, socio-economic status, or oral contraceptive pills.
  • Menopause is directly related to smoking and genetic disposition. 
  • Smoking induces premature menopause. (Option A)

questions.text: A 20 year old male with h/o RTA has intracranial haemorrhage with raised  intracranial pressure. Which of the following is not seen?
questions.solution:
Raised ICT is not associated with Paraparesis.

RTA with intracranial hemorrhage into the brain causes edema and swelling which can lead to raised ICP. 

Symptoms of raised ICT are Cushing’s triad:

  • Hypertension
  • Bradycardia
  • Respiratory depression.

Paraparesis is usually caused by a spinal lesion such as thoracic myelopathy and neoplasms causing compression of the spinal cord.   

Related Pearl: Intracranial Hypertension

Definition

Intracranial hypertension is pressure within the cranium above normal. Normal range of ICP is 5-15mm Hg. Levels above 20-25mm Hg are usually treated. 

Causes: Intracranial haemorrhage, brain tumors, head injury, meningitis, brain abscess, etc. 

Symptoms of raised ICT

  • Cushing’s triad – hypertension, bradycardia and respiratory depression
  • Headache, visual blurring due to papilloedema and abducent nerve palsy 
  • Focal symptoms may arise due to the local effects in patients with mass lesions or due to herniation.
  • Seizures
  • Stroke

Investigations

  • CT brain or MRI brain with gadolinium to rule out ICSOL 
  • Lumbar puncture is contraindicated in the presence of raised ICT due to the risk of coning.
  • Papilledema (as an indicator of ICT) should be ruled out before lumbar puncture.

Treatment

  • Dexamethasone
  • Ventriculotomy to remove CSF or ventriculoperitoneal shunt
  • Decompressive craniectomy
  • Surgical resection of ICSOL – by craniotomy or stereotactic radiosurgery
  • Whole brain radiation for multiple metastases causing raised ICT

questions.text: Diagnosis of the USG image is ____________?
questions.solution:
Sign seen is Barcode sign and the diagnosis is Pneumothorax

 

On M mode, classical signs for the grayscale imaging are seen:
• Seashore sign: normal lung
• Barcode/stratosphere sign: pneumothorax

Fig 1: This M-mode image demonstrates a linear, laminar pattern in the tissue superficial to the pleural line (arrow) and a granular or “sandy” appearance deep to the pleural line. This phenomenon, known as the “seashore sign” indicates normal lung sliding and excludes pneumothorax at this interspace

Fig 2: This M-mode image demonstrates a linear, laminar pattern in the tissue superficial to the pleural line (arrow) and a similar linear pattern deep to the pleural line. This phenomenon, known as the “stratosphere sign” or “barcode sign” indicates absent lung sliding and suggests the presence of pneumothorax at this .

questions.text: A 4-year-old girl presented with fever, lethargy and bruising. She was investigated thoroughly and was diagnosed to have acute lymphoid leukemia. Which of the following drugs is not used in the management of this condition?
questions.solution:
Cladribine is not used in the management of ALL.

T-ALL commonly presents in adolescent boys. 60% of patients with T-ALL present with a mediastinal mass. The mediastinal mass may be asymptomatic and detected only on chest x-ray or may cause cough and dyspnea, particularly on lying flat or with facial swelling and plethora due to vascular compression (superior vena cava syndrome).

B-cell ALL presents in children between 1-10 yrs of age, with pancytopenia, hepatosplenomegaly, and bony tenderness.

 Treatment of ALL

  • Induction: 4 weeks
    • L-asparaginase: single dose (side effects: pancreatitis, thrombosis)
    • Vincristine: weekly (side effects: neuropathy, SIADH)
    • Prednisolone
  • Consolidation: CNS prophylaxis 
    • Intrathecal methotrexate
  • Maintenance: 24-36 months
    • 6-Mercaptopurine
    • Methotrexate

Note:

  • Cladribine is used in hairy cell leukaemia.

Related Pearl: Prognostic factors in ALL

questions.text: A 24-year-old male patient was brought to the emergency department after sustaining injuries in a fight. He was able to talk but was disoriented and confused. He could only  open his eyes when he was asked to open and also responded to pain by localizing it. What is his Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score?
questions.solution:
For the given scenario, the Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score is 12.

To arrive at this the following clinical clues have to be considered:

  • The patient is able to open his eyes to verbal command  - Eye response = 3.
  • The patient is able to speak but is confused - Verbal response = 4
  • The patient is able to localize a painful stimulus - Motor response = 5

Related Pearl: Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS)

GCS Score

  • 13-15 represent mild brain injury
  • 9-12 represent moderate brain injury
  • scores ≤8 represent severe brain injury 

Head Injury Severity: Clinical classification 

Eyes Opening

 Score
Spontaneously 4
To verbal command 3
To painful stimulus 2
Do not open 1

Non-testable

Verbal response Score
Normal-oriented conversation 5
Confused 4
Inappropriate words only 3

No sounds 1

Non-testable

Motor Response Score

Localizes to pain 5
Withdrawal/flexion 4
Abnormal flexion/Decorticate posturing  3
Extension/Decerebrate posturing  2
No motor response 1

Minimum value: 3

Maximum value: 15

  • The motor score, is the best predictor of neurological outcome.
  • If an area cannot be assessed, no numerical score is given for that region, and it is considered “non-testable." (NT)
  • In case of endotracheal intubation or tracheostomy, the verbal component of the score is denoted as NT.

 

NOTE: 

A new parameter, "pupil reactivity score" has been added to GCS, and now, it is referred to as GCS-P.

P stands for "Pupils unreactive to light"

Pupils Unreactive to light Score
Both pupils 2
One pupil 1 
Neither  0

The pupillary score is subtracted from the GCS score to give the final value. Therefore, the range of GCS-P is 1–15.

questions.text: Which of the following does not show the inheritance pattern shown in the pedigree chart?
questions.solution:
The above pedigree chart denotes a pattern of inheritance of autosomal-recessive disorder and Marfans syndrome show autosomal dominant inheritance. All other options has autosomal recessive inheritance.

Points in favor are the following:

  • Horizontal pattern in pedigrees: the observation of multiple affected members in the same generation, but no affected family members in other generations.
  • Parents are unaffected (both are carriers/heterozygotes);25% of the children have normal genotype, 50% are carriers, 25% are homozygous, and manifestation are seen only in the homozygous state.

Pedigree charts in various modes of inheritance:

Related Pearl: Pedigree chart for different inheritance patterns

 

Autosomal Dominant Disorders:

  • With every autosomal dominant disorder, some patients do not have affected parents. Such patients owe their disorder to new mutations involving either the egg or the sperm from which they were derived.
  • Clinical features can be modified by variations in penetrance and expressivity.
  • In many conditions, the age at onset is delayed, and symptoms and signs may not appear until adulthood (as in Huntington disease).

X-linked Recessive Conditions:

  • All sex-linked disorders are X-linked, and almost all are recessive.
  • Several genes are located in the “male-specific region of Y;” all these are related to spermatogenesis.
  • Males with mutations affecting the Y-linked genes are usually infertile, and hence, there is no Y-linked inheritance.
  • An affected male does not transmit the disorder to his sons, but all daughters are carriers.
  • Sons of heterozygous women have, of course, a one-in-two chance of receiving the mutant gene.
  • Heterozygous females express the disorder partially because of random inactivation of one X chromosome.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a fetal cause of Polyhydramnios?
questions.solution:
Renal agenesis is a fetal cause for oligohydramnios.
