questions.text: A 20-year-old boy presents to you following the burn injury as shown in the below image. Your senior consultant advises you to prescribe a topical antimicrobial that can penetrate eschar. Which of the following drugs would you prescribe?
questions.solution:
The above image shows burns with eschar and among the above-mentioned topical antimicrobials, Mafenide acetate can penetrate eschar.

Mafenide acetate:

  • Mafenide acetate either in cream or solution form is an effective topical antimicrobial.
  • It is effective even in the presence of eschar as it can penetrate burn eschar to reach the interface with the patient's viable tissue.
  • It is an excellent antimicrobial for fresh skin grafts.
  • It is particularly useful against resistant Pseudomonas and Enterococcus species.
  • It has the disadvantage of being painful on topical application.
  • It is also a carbonic anhydrase inhibitor and can result in metabolic acidosis when it is applied over large surfaces.

Other options:

Silver sulphadiazine: It is a most commonly used agent having a wide range of antimicrobial activity because it's silver and sulfa moieties cover gram-positive, most gram-negative, and even some fungal forms. In a few patients, transient leukopenia develops 3 to 5 days after its continued use. This leukopenia is generally harmless and resolves with or without treatment cessation.

Neomycin: Painless but the antimicrobial spectrum is not as wide as the above agents.

Silver nitrate: Effective against Pseudomonas colonization. It has the advantage of being painless on application. However prolonged topical application leads to electrolyte extravasation with resulting hyponatremia. It also causes staining of all the furniture surrounding the patient.It may cause methemoglobinemia in a few.

questions.text: A 30 year old female recently started feeling like an outcast in her office. She had been suffering from on and off nasal obstruction and epistaxis. Her examination revealed foul smelling nasal discharge which the patient was totally unaware,  thick nasal crusts but with a wide and clear nasal pathway. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario is typical of atrophic rhinitis.

It is also known as 'Ozaena'. It is a chronic inflammation of nose characterised by atrophy of nasal mucosa and turbinate bones. The nasal cavities are roomy and full of foul smelling crusts. Atrophic rhinitis is of 2 types: Primary & Secondary.

PRIMARY ATROPHIC RHINITIS:

AETIOLOGY: (Mn: HERNIA)

  • Hereditary factors 
  • Endocrine disturbances - starts at puberty
  • Racial factors - white & yellow races are more susceptible.
  • Nutritional deficiency- may be due to vitamin A, D or iron deficiencies.
  • Infective - Klebsiella ozaenae , E.coli, Proteus vulgaris, staphylococci, etc., are all thought to be involved.
  • Auto-immune process - Viral infection or some other unspecified agents may trigger antigenicity of nasal mucosa.

PATHOLOGY:

Ciliated columnar epithelium is lost and is replaced by stratified squamous epithelium. There is atrophy of seromucinous glands, venous blood sinusoids and nerve elements. 

Arteries in the mucosa, periosteum and bone show obliterating endarteritis. The bones of the turbinate undergoes resorption causing widening of nasal chambers.  

CLINICAL FEATURES:

Disease is commonly seen in females and starts around puberty. There is foul smell from the nose making the patient a social outcast though patient himself is unaware of the smell due to masked anosmia (merciful anosmia) which accompanies these degenerative changes.
Patient may complain of nasal obstruction in spite of unduly wide nasal chambers. This is due to large crusts filling the nose. Epistaxis may occur when the crusts are removed.

TREATMENT:

a) MEDICAL :

Aims at maintaining nasal hygiene by removal of crusts and the associated putrefying smell and to further check crust formation.

  • Nasal irrigation and removal of crusts
  • 25% glucose in glycerine
  • Local antibiotics 
  • Oestrodiol spray
  • Placental extract
  • Systemic use of streptomycin
  • Potassium iodide ( liquefies nasal secretion when given by mouth)

b) SURGICAL:

  • Young's operation - both the nostrils are closed completely just within the nasal vestibule by raising flaps.They are opened 6 months later.
  • Modified Young's operation- To avoid the discomfort of bilateral nasal obstruction, it aims to partially close the nostrils.
  • Narrowing the nasal cavities- It helps to relieve the symptoms 

SECONDARY ATROPHIC RHINITIS:

 Specific infections like syphilis, leprosy and rhinoscleroma may cause destruction of the nasal structures leading to atrophic changes.

   Atrophic rhinitis can also result from long- standing purulent sinusitis, radiotherapy to nose or excessive removal of turbinates.

 

OTHER OPTIONS:

A)Hypertrophic rhinitis presents with thick nasal discharge, nasal block with hypertrophic turbinates.

C)Rhinitis sicca presents with thick and dry nasal discharge but most commonly occurs among people working in hot, dry and humid conditions.

D)Rhinitis caseosa presents with foul smelling nasal discharge with cheesy material.

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman visits the infertility clinic with a complaint of recurrent abortion. Upon investigations, she is found to have a septate uterus. Which of the following corrective procedures has the best obstetric outcome?
questions.solution:
Transcervical hysteroscopic resection of the septum has the best obstetric outcome.

The procedure involves the resection of septum under hysteroscopic guidance. Hence, it doesn't scar the uterus and avoids the necessity of cesarean sections for future pregnancies improving the outcomes.

Jones metroplasty, Strassmann metroplasty, Tompkins metroplasty involve approaching the uterus transabdominally which causes uterine scarring and are hence not preferred.

Related Pearl: Mullerian Anomalies

 

Class Mullerian anomaly Reason/Feature Treatment Complications
I Uterine hypoplasia or uterine agenesis Underdeveloped or non-developed paramesonephric duct

Surrogacy for treatment of infertility 

Vaginal hypoplasia is surgically corrected at the time of marriage

 Infertility

 
II Unicornuate uterus Non-developed paramesonephric duct Excision of rudimentary horn, if any   Uterine rupture, abortions, risk of miscarriage, preterm, and malpresentation
III Uterus didelphys Unfused paramesonephric duct Metroplasty (Resection of membrane and fundal recombination) Risk of miscarriage, preterm, and malpresentation 
IV Bicornuate uterus  Lower part fused where as upper part unfused Metroplasty in selected cases  Risk of miscarriage, preterm, and malpresentation
V Septate uterus  Septa of fused part persists Hysteroscopic septal resection 

Diminished fertility, Risk of miscarriage, preterm, and malpresentation

 
VI Arcuate uterus A small indentation at upper part    
VII Diethylstillbesterone (DES), drug related T-shaped uterus, shortened and narrow fallopian tubes, cervical collars (cockscomb cervix)   Ectopic pregnancy,  cervical incompetance,  clear cell adenocarcinoma of vagina and cervix 

A common complication is an abortion in the second trimester.

Arcuate uterus: Some studies report no increase in adverse outcomes, whereas some studies have shown excessive second trimester loss, preterm labor and malpresentations.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male presented  with complaints of difficulty in breathing even with mild activities for the past 1 month. He has a chronic history of smoking with an estimated toll of 20 pack-years. Auscultation of the chest shows extensive, bilateral wheeze and crepitations. The HRCT of the chest is given below. Which of the following measures is least likely to improve the survival benefit in him?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). Inhaled corticosteroids are least likely to improve the survival benefit in these patients.

The given CT image shows extensive emphysematous changes in the bilateral lungs.

Only the following three interventions have been demonstrated to improve the survival benefit in COPD patients.

  • Smoking cessation
  • Oxygen therapy in chronically hypoxemic patients
  • Lung volume reduction surgery in selected patients with emphysema.

Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD)

  • disease state characterized by airflow limitation that is not fully reversible.
  • Emphysema, characterized by destruction and enlargement of the lung alveoli.
  • Chronic bronchitis and small airways disease,  a condition in which small bronchioles are narrowed.
  • Post bronchodilator FEV1/FVC < 0.7.

Signs of COPD

  • Early
    • Maybe normal with only signs of smoking - nicotine stains and odor.
  • Severe
    • Prolonged expiratory phase with expiratory wheeze
    • Barrel chest
    • Enlarged lung volumes
    • Use of accessory muscles and sitting in tripod position to improve dyspnea
    • Cyanosis, visible in lips and nail beds
    • Paradoxical inward movement of the chest during inspiration - Hoover’s sign
  • Emphysema predominant - cachexic and non-cyanotic at rest - Pink puffer
  • Bronchitis predominant - heavy and cyanotic - Blue bloater

Initial management of acute exacerbation of COPD includes:

  • Bronchodilators: Inhaled beta-agonists and muscarinic antagonists.
  • Antibiotics
  • Supplemental oxygen
  • Non-invasive positive pressure ventilation (NIPPV)

If initial NIPPV fails, then, invasive PPV may be provided. However, during the invasive PPV, the tidal volume is reduced to prevent damage to the alveolar structures. This decrease in minute ventilation causes progressive hypercapnia, which is however permitted to a certain extent for the benefit of the patient (commonly known as permissive hypercapnia).

Note: FEV1/FVC is measured after the administration of atleast one short acting inhaled bronchodilator.

The severity of COPD assessed by Global Initiative for Lung Disease (GOLD) is classified as:

GOLD Stage

Severity

Spirometry

I

Mild

FEV1/FVC <0.7 and FEV1 ≥80% predicted

II

Moderate

FEV1/FVC <0.7 and FEV1 ≥50% but <80% predicted

III

Severe

FEV1/FVC <0.7 and FEV1 ≥30% but <50% predicted

IV

Very severe

FEV1/FVC <0.7 and FEV1 <30% predicted

questions.text: An elderly woman is brought to the OPD with complaints of behavioral change, a history of multiple falls, urinary incontinence, and dementia. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The triad of dementia, ataxic or apractic gait and urinary incontinence is seen in normal pressure hydrocephalus.

The triad of normal pressure hydrocephalus (Adam’s/Hakim’s triad):

  • Dementia
  • Ataxia (gait disturbance) or apractic
  • Urinary incontinence

Normal-pressure hydrocephalus (Hakim-Adams syndrome):

  • It is caused by obstruction to the normal CSF flow in the cerebral convexity and delayed absorption into the venous system.
  • Caused by conditions producing scarring of basilar meninges
  • Communicating hydrocephalus is seen
  • A reversible cause of dementia
  • Adam’s / Hakim’s triad (as mentioned above)
  • Papilloedema is not seen.
  • Dilated lateral ventricles with little or no cortical atrophy are seen on neuroimaging and the lumbar puncture opening pressure is in the high-normal range.
  • Treatment - Ventriculo-peritoneal shunting
  • CSF parameters are normal usually

Related Pearl: Differential diagnosis of dementia

CONDITION FEATURES
Alzheimer’s disease
  • Insidious onset
  • Short-term memory loss
  • Language deficits and spatial disorientation
  • Later, personality changes
Vascular Dementia
  • Stepwise decline
  • Early executive dysfunction
  • Cerebral infarction &/or deep white matter changes on neuroimaging
Frontotemporal dementia
(Pick’s disease)
  • Early personality changes
  • Apathy, disinhibition & compulsive behaviors
  • Frontotemporal atrophy on neuroimaging
Dementia with Lewy bodies
  • Visual Hallucination
  • Spontaneous parkinsonism
  • Fluctuating cognition
Normal-pressure hydrocephalus
  • Gait abnormalities 
  • Urinary Incontinence
  • Dementia
  • Dilated ventricles on neuroimaging
Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease
(Prion disease)
  • Behavioral changes
  • Rapidly progressive
  • Myoclonus &/or seizures

questions.text: Which of the following are causes of high RAIU (radioactive iodine uptake)?
questions.solution:
All three are classical examples of high RAIU.

Radioactive Iodine Scan:

  • Nonpregnant, hyperthyroid patients with physical examination suggesting nodular thyroid disease, radioactive iodine should be the initial test to determine the aetiology of hyperthyroidism.
  • Pregnancy and breastfeeding are absolute contraindications to radionuclide imaging.
  • Hyperthyroidism with a high (or normal) radioiodine uptake indicates de-novo synthesis of the hormone.
  • Hyperthyroidism with a low (nearly absent) radioiodine uptake indicates either inflammation and destruction of thyroid tissue with release of preformed hormone into the circulation or an extrathyroidal source of thyroid hormone, such as in patients with factitious thyrotoxicosis and in patients with struma ovari.

Subacute thyroiditis shows low uptake of radioactive iodine as it involves destruction and inflammation of the thyroid follicles, which also accounts for the thyrotoxic symptoms due to exocytosis of the hormone.

Related Pearl: Radioiodine uptake of thyroid gland

Increased Hormone Synthesis (Increased RAIU) Release of Preformed Hormone (Decreased RAIU)
  • Graves’ disease
  • Toxic multinodular goiter
  • Toxic adenoma
  • Drug induced—amiodarone
  • Iodine
  • Thyroid cancer
  • Hydatidiform mole
  • TSH-secreting pituitary adenoma
  • Thyroiditis—acute phase of Hashimoto’s thyroiditis, subacute thyroiditis
  • Factitious (iatrogenic) thyrotoxicosis
  • Struma ovarii
  • Hamburger thyrotoxicosis 
  • Subacute/ Dequervain thyroiditis
  • Metastatic follicular thyroid carcinoma
  • Radiation thyroiditis

questions.text: A 5 year old child presented to the clinic with complaints of nasal obstruction. On examination he has an elongated face with dull expression, picked up nose, absent naso labial crease, open mouth, prominent and crowded upper teeth. What is the most common diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The described facial features are characteristic of adenoid hypertrophy.    
 
Symptoms:
  • Nasal obstruction is the commonest symptom. This leads to mouth breathing.
  • Nasal obstruction also interferes with feeding or suckling in a child. As respiration and feeding cannot take place simultaneously, a child with adenoid enlargement fails to thrive.
  • Nasal discharge, sinusitis, epistaxis.
  • Eustachian tube obstruction leading to bilateral serous otitis media and conductive hearing loss.
  • Rhinolalia clausa - hyponasal voice.
  • Adenoid facies- elongated face with dull expression, pinched up nose, absent nasolabial crease, open mouth, prominent and crowded upper teeth.
  • Sleep apnea- chronic cases leads to hypoxemia which leads to pulmonary vasoconstriction consequently pulmonary hypertension and cor pulmonale.
  • Aprosexia - lack of concentration.

questions.text: A 46-year-old male presented with abdominal pain, peripheral edema, and ascites. History revealed a loss of appetite, weight loss, and diarrhoea. Laboratory studies showed decreased serum albumin but normal serum levels of transaminases and gastrin. Upper GI endoscopy showed the following appearance involving the fundus and body of the stomach, sparing the antrum. The hispathological image of the gastric tissue is given below. Which of the following is true about the following condition?

choices.text: Gastrectomy is the treatment of choice in severe cases
Caused by overexpression of TNF alpha

questions.solution:
The clinical features are diagnostic of Menetrier disease. Gastrectomy is the treatment of choice in severe cases of Menetrier's disease, as evident by the endoscopic image showing hypertrophic gastric folds and the H&E section showing foveolar cell hyperplasia.

Menetrier's disease / Hyperplastic hypersecretory gastropathy:

  • Characterized by gross hypertrophy of the gastric mucosal folds, mucus production, and hypochlorhydria.
  • The condition is premalignant 

The disease seems to be caused by overexpression of transforming growth factor-alpha - TGF-alpha (not TNF-alpha), which stimulates the EGFR pathway, resulting in increased proliferation of mucus cells/foveolar hyperplasia. 

It is associated with Cytomegalo virus (CMV) infection in children and H. pylori infection in adults.

There is a loss of albumin (up to 10 g/day), across the gastric mucosa leading to hypoproteinemia. Secondary symptoms include weight loss, diarrhea, anemia and peripheral edema.  The features of Ménétrier disease in children are similar to those in adults, but the pediatric disease is usually self-limited and often occurs after an episode of respiratory infection. There is an increased risk of gastric adenocarcinoma in adults.

Treatment:

  • Mainly supportive, with intravenous albumin and parenteral nutritional supplementation.
  • Cetuximab, an EGFR inhibitory antibody, is now considered the first-line treatment for Menetrier's disease, leaving total gastrectomy for severe disease with persistent and substantial protein loss despite therapy with this agent.
  • There is no treatment other than a gastrectomy in severe cases. 

The condition is characterized by diffuse hyperplasia of foveolar epithelium within the body and fundus, causing enlarged gastric folds as shown below. The antrum is usually spared. These hypertrophied rugal folds give a cobblestone or cerebriform appearance to the gastric mucosa.

Histologically, it is characterized by hyperplasia of foveolar mucous cells. The glands are cystically dilated and elongated with a corkscrew-like appearance as shown in the image below.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient comes to the emergency room with a history of severe retrosternal pain radiating to the left jaw, after eating lunch. He has T2DM,Hypertension and is a c/c smoker and alcoholic. His ECG is as shown. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given ECG shows ST-segment elevation in the anterior chest leads suggestive of myocardial infarction.

Features of MI on ECG:

  • ST-segment elevation: Zone of injury
  • T wave inversions
  • Deep Q waves: late sign to develop
  • New left bundle branch block (LBBB)

 Some of the known risk factors for Myocardial Ischaemia are:

  • Older age
  • Hypertension
  • Diabetes mellitus
  • High levels of blood cholesterol ( high low-density lipoprotein, low high-density lipoprotein, and high triglycerides).
  • Smoking and alcohol use
  • Male sex
  • Family history
  • Lack of physical activity and obesity
  • Unhealthy Diet
  • Chronic Stress

Acute coronary syndromes (ACS) includes:

  • Unstable angina(UA)
  • Non-ST elevation myocardial infarction(NSTEMI)
  • ST-elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI)

Atrial flutter shows a sawtooth wave pattern. (Option A)

WPW syndrome shows delta waves. (Option B)

Torsades de pointes is a polymorphic ventricular tachycardia meaning “twisting of the points,” characterized by twisting of the QRS axis around the baseline and a polymorphic appearance.Torsade rhythm is most commonly seen in association with hypomagnesemia and hypokalemia.There is QT interval prolongation in the ECG due to a non-uniform delay in repolarization

Related Pearl: The Temporal Evolution of the Morphologic Changes in Acute MI

Time

Morphological change

0- 1/2 hour

Relaxation of myofibrils; glycogen

loss; mitochondrial swelling

1/2-4 hours

Sarcolemmal disruption;

mitochondrial amorphous densities

4-12 hours

Early coagulation necrosis; edema; hemorrhage

12-24 hours

Ongoing coagulation necrosis; pyknosis of nuclei; myocyte hypereosinophilia; marginal contraction band necrosis; early neutrophilic infiltrate

1-3 days

Coagulation necrosis, with loss of nuclei and striations; brisk interstitial infiltrate of neutrophils

3-7 days

Disintegration of dead myofibers, early phagocytosis of dead cells by macrophages at infarct border

7-10 days

Well-developed phagocytosis of dead cells; granulation tissue at margins

10-14 days

Well-established granulation tissue with new blood vessels and collagen deposition

2-8 weeks

Increased collagen deposition, with decreased cellularity

>2 months

Dense collagenous scar

Related Pearl: Localisation of MI based on ST elevations in different leads

Extensive anterior - I, aVL, V1-V6

Lateral - I, aVL

Inferior - II, III, aVF

Anteroseptal - V1-V4

Anterolateral - I, aVL, V3-V6

Posterior - ST depression and tall R in V1-V4

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman who underwent dilatation and curettage previously, now presents with amenorrhea. The urine pregnancy test is negative. HSG revealed a honeycomb appearance in the uterine cavity. The hysteroscopic evaluation revealed 75% adhesions with agglutinations of the uterine wall. This is classified as ______?

choices.text: Cannot be classified with the given information

questions.solution:
The given clinical features, history and hysteroscopy is suggestive of Asherman syndrome where 75% adhesions with agglutinations is classified as Severe Asherman syndrome.

Asherman syndrome (uterine synechiae) is classified as follows:

  • Mild: <25% adhesion involves the uterine cavity, flimsy adhesions involving the fundus and tubal ostia.
  • Moderate: 25–70% adhesion of the endometrial surfaces, but no agglutination of the uterine wall.
  • Severe: 75% adhesions with agglutination and thick adhesions.

Asherman syndrome can be caused by the following:

  • Dilatation and curettage (D&C) 
  • Medical termination of pregnancy (MTP), spontaneous abortions, recurrent abortions
  • Uterine packing in postpartum haemorrhage
  • Uterine infection
  • Tubercular endometritis

It causes secondary amenorrhoea, oligomenorrhoea, dysmenorrhoea, habitual abortion and infertility depending upon the extent of uterine cavity obliteration.

questions.text: A pregnant lady with a ​history of recurrent abortions shows an elevated isolated increase in activated Partial Thromboplastin Time (aPTT) on blood work-up. What would be the best mode of treatment for her?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette shows an elevated aPTT which is characteristic of Antiphospholipid antibody (APLA) syndrome which during pregnancy is treated with low-molecular-weight heparin with aspirin 80 mg daily known to be the most efficacious regimen.

Beta 2-glycoprotein I, also known as apolipoprotein H, is a phospholipid-binding plasma protein that inhibits prothrombinase activity within platelets.

This inhibits ADP-induced platelet aggregation. Thus, its normal action is to inhibit procoagulant binding and thereby prevent coagulation cascade activation. The antibodies produced against Beta2-GP1 and thus triggers the coagulation cascade causing thrombus formation.

Tests for the diagnosis of lupus anticoagulant:

  • aPTT
  • Kaolin clotting time
  • Dilute Russel viper venom time

Treatment in Pregnancy :

Aspirin in doses of 60-80mg blocks the conversion of arachidonic acid to thromboxane A2 while sparing prostacyclin production. Heparin therapy prevents thrombosis in the microcirculation including the decidual trophoblastic interface. Corticosteroids are not to be used in primary anti-phospholipid antibody syndrome.

Warfarin is not used due to its potential teratogenic effects, the most common being Craniofacial anomaly and the most characteristic is Chondrodysplasia punctata

questions.text:
A 45-year-old man who had a 10 hour long CABG comes for review 4 weeks after the surgery.
The patient's blood report shows Hb -11; MCV -106.
His Pre-surgery Hb -13; MCV -89.
The patient's condition is an adverse effect of which drug?
questions.solution:
• Nitrous oxide inhibits vitamin B12 dependent enzymes like thymidylate synthetase, which is necessary for DNA synthesis – this is responsible for the megaloblastic bone marrow changes.
  • Megaloblastic anemia is seen with nitrous oxide especially when exposure is greater than 2-6 hours – in healthy patients, prolonged periods of exposure > 12 hours is required whereas, in critically ill patients, much shorter periods of exposure can lead to megaloblastoid changes in the bone marrow.
  • Other side effects
    • Bone marrow depression
    • Subacute combined degeneration of the cord
    • Teratogenicity
    • Peripheral neuropathy
  • Contraindications of nitrous oxide:
    • venous or arterial air embolism
    • pneumothorax,
    • acute intestinal obstruction with bowel distention,
    • intracranial air (pneumocephalus following dural closure or pneumoencephalography),
    • pulmonary air cysts,
    • intraocular air bubbles,
    • tympanic membrane grafting

questions.text: A 55-year-old male presents with right upper quadrant pain, nausea, vomiting, and low-grade fever. Physical examination demonstrates crepitus over the right upper quadrant. Ultrasound evaluation reveals air in the walls of the gall bladder. According to the surgical wound classifications, the definitive surgical procedure this patient would undergo will come under ______ category.
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette is suggestive of emphysematous cholecystitis. This is managed with emergency cholecystectomy.

Emergency cholecystectomy is classified as Contaminated wound.

 

Surgical Wound Classifications as Defined by ACS NSQIP:

Class Category Description Examples Infection rate
I Clean Uninfected operative wounds in which no inflammation is encountered and the respiratory, alimentary, genital, and uninfected urinary tracts are not entered Non traumatic elective surgery – Breast, thyroid and coronary bypass < 2-3%
II Clean/contaminated Operative wounds in which the respiratory, alimentary, genital, or urinary tract is entered under controlled conditions and without unusual contamination Elective cholecystectomy, appendicectomy, elective colon surgery after bowel preparation 5 – 10%
III Contaminated Open, fresh, accidental wounds; operations with major breaks in sterile technique or gross spillage from the gastrointestinal tract; and incisions in which acute, nonpurulent inflammation is encountered Emergency cholecystectomy, appendicectomy, emergency colon surgery in unprepared bowel 10 – 20%
IV Dirty Old traumatic wounds with retained devitalized tissue and wounds that involve existing clinical infection or perforated viscera. Abscess, peritonitis (Gross fecal contamination) >20%

 

Related Pearl: Surgical wound classifications as defined by ACS NSOP

  • Clean: Uninfected operative wounds in which no inflammation is encountered and the respiratory, alimentary, genital, and uninfected urinary tracts are not entered
  • Clean/Contaminated: Operative wounds in which the respiratory, alimentary, genital, or urinary tract is entered under controlled conditions and without unusual contamination
  • Contaminated: Open, fresh, accidental wounds; operations with major breaks insterile technique or gross spillage from the gastrointestinal tract and incisions in which acute, nonpurulent inflammation is encountered
  • Dirty: Old traumatic wounds with retained devitalized tissue and wounds that involve existing clinical infection or perforated viscera

questions.text: A 30 -year-old male  with a history of taking medications for rheumatoid arthritis, now presents with obesity, short stature, round face, and his abdominal findings was as in the picture below. On examination, pulse rate is 96/minute, blood pressure is 150/90 mm Hg. The most likely diagnosis is ?
questions.solution:
The probable cause in this case is Cushing's syndrome.

History of Rheumatoid arthritis suggests that patient had been on exogenous steroids for long term management of rheumatoid arthritis.

The presenting features with a round face (moon facies), short stature, along with obesity and purple skin striae suggest a diagnosis of Cushing's syndrome and the most common cause of Cushing's syndrome is prolonged exogenous administration of glucocorticoids. 

Cushing's syndrome is characterized by clinical features that result from chronic exposure of excess glucocorticoids that can be due to

  • Prolonged exogenous administration of glucocorticoids (Iatrogenic: Most common cause of Cushing's syndrome) 
  • Excess endogenous cortisol secretion:
    • In children <7 years: Most often by a functioning adrenocortical tumor
    • In children >7 years: Most often by an adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH)–producing pituitary adenoma (Cushing's disease)

Important clinical features 

  • Obesity or weight gain (most common)
  • Moon facies
  • Purple skin striae
  • Abnormal masculinization (acne, bruising, enlargement of the clitoris in girls)
  • Pubertal developmental delay and amenorrhea in girls
  • Proximal muscle weakness
  • Osteoporosis
  • Hypertension
  • Hyperpigmentation
  • Hypokalemic alkalosis
  • Hyperglycemia
  • Sepsis

Diagnosis:

Step 1: Confirm the diagnosis

The following investigations are used to establish an initial diagnosis of endogenous Cushing's syndrome as per the clinical guidelines of the endocrine society.

  • 24-hour urinary free cortisol (increased 3x above normal), used as a screening test.
  • Midnight salivary cortisol ( >5nmol/L)
  • Overnight dexamethasone suppression (plasma cortisol >50 nmol/L at 8-9 AM after 1 mg dexamethasone at 11 PM)

Step 2: Identify the source

1.This is done by measuring plasma ACTH level

  • If ACTH low-primary cause of hypercortisolism  (suppressed levels of ACTH due to negative feedback)
  • If ACTH high-secondary cause of hypercortisolism(may be due to a pituitary pathology, commonly a microadenoma or an ectopic source of ACTH production by a tumour such as a small cell lung cancer.)

2.Standard 2-day (high dose) dexamethasone suppression test:

  • Serum cortisol level and/or 24-hour urinary free cortisol is measured as a baseline, and then dexamethasone 2 mg orally is taken every 6 hours for 48 hours; urine for free cortisol is collected during the test and serum cortisol is checked 6 hours after the last dose. The suppression of cortisol secretion to >50 % of the baseline is considered positive and indicative of Cushing's disease.

If ACTH is elevated but lack of suppression in high dose dexamethasone suppression test is seen, an ectopic source must be looked for, by imaging studies like CT of the thorax and abdomen to detect the presence of any tumors.

 

Related Pearl: Causes of Cushing's Syndrome

Iatrogenic (Most common cause)

  • Exogenous administration of glucocorticoids

Endogenous Causes

  • ACTH Dependent – (90 % of endogenous causes)
  • Cushing’s disease – ACTH-producing pituitary adenoma
  • Ectopic ACTH syndrome – Due to ACTH secretion by
  • Bronchial or pancreatic carcinoid tumors
  • Small-cell lung cancer
  • Medullary thyroid carcinoma
  • Pheochromocytoma
  • ACTH Independent – (10% )
  • Adrenocortical adenoma
  • Adrenocortical carcinoma

Rare causes

  • Macronodular adrenal hyperplasia
  • Primary pigmented nodular adrenal disease
  • McCune – Albright syndrome

Related Pearl: Screening/Confirmatory Test for Diagnosing Cushing's Syndrome

  • 24-h urinary free cortisol excretion increased above normal (3x)
  • Dexamethasone overnight test
    • Plasma cortisol >50 nmol/L at 8–9 a.m. after 1 mg dexamethasone at 11 p.m.
  • Midnight plasma cortisol >130 nmol/L
  • Midnight salivary cortisol >5 nmol/L
  • Low dose Dexamethasone test – Best initial test
    • Plasma cortisol >50 nmol/L after 0.5 mg dexamethasone q6h for 2 days

If a number of these tests are positive then a diagnosis of Cushing’s syndrome is confirmed.

Related Pearl: Side effects of Corticosteroids: mnemonic "CORTICOSTEROIDS"

The mnemonic is "CORTICOSTEROIDS"

C - Cushing’s syndrome

O - Osteoporosis

R - Retardation of growth

T - Thin skin and easy bruisability

I - Infections and immunosuppression

C - Cataract

O - Oedema

S - Suppression of HPA axis

T - Thinning and ulceration of gastric mucosa

E - Emotional disturbance

R - Rise in BP

O - Others fatal abnormalities like hypokalemia

I - Increase in hair growth (hirsutism)

D - Diabetes mellitus precipitation

S - Striae

questions.text: Following is the X ray image of a 14 year old boy with a bone tumor. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most probable diagnosis, in this case, is osteosarcoma.

In osteosarcoma, the tumor lifts the periosteum and incites an intense periosteal reaction. The periosteal reaction is irregular and it may take the form of a "Codman's triangle" or it may have a "sunburst (sunray) appearance" on x ray.

The X ray  image given has the following features:

  • Irregular destruction in the metaphysis overshadowed by the formation of new bone
  • Lifting of the periosteum due to the formation of new bone inciting a periosteal reaction
  • Bone formation along the blood vessels within the tumor centrifugally giving rise to "sunburst (sunray) appearance" on the radiograph.

Osteosarcoma is the most common non-hematologic primary malignancy of bone. It occurs most commonly in the second decade of life. It is typically metaphyseal. The distal femur, proximal tibia, and proximal humerus are common sites.

 Treatment: Osteosarcoma is treated by neoadjuvant chemotherapy, wide excision or radical surgery followed by adjuvant chemotherapy. Since here safe margins are difficult to achieve limb ablation is done. 

The goal of neoadjuvant and adjuvant chemotherapy is to treat micrometastasis.

Note:

T-10 protocol of chemotherapy is used in the management of osteosarcoma. It involves:

  • High dose methotrexate and Citrovorum factor rescue
  • Adriamycin
  • BCD (bleomycin, cyclophosphamide, dactinomycin/doxorubicin)

Adamantinoma Diaphysis of Tibia  20-40 years
 Fibrous dysplasia  The upper end of femur > tibia  1st to 3rd decade
 Chordoma  Sacrum  5th to 7th decade
Multiple myeloma Vertebrae 5th to 7th decade

questions.text: A 34-year old woman comes with complaints of pain and swelling in her hands and wrists with a stiffness of joints in the early hours of the day. On examination, the following deformity is seen. Identify the deformity depicted in the image.
questions.solution:
The image shows flexion of the PIP joint with hyperextension of the DIP joint. This deformity is known as Boutonnière deformity seen in rheumatoid arthritis.

 Rheumatoid Arthritis :

It is a chronic inflammatory disease. Its incidence increases between 25 and 55 years of age.

Signs and symptoms -

  • Swelling and pain of the small joints of the hands initially(spares DIP joint)
  • Morning stiffness
  • Swan-neck deformity(hyperextension of the PIP joint with flexion of the DIP joint), Boutonnière deformity(flexion of the PIP joint with hyperextension of the DIP joint), or Z-line deformity(subluxation of the first MCP joint with hyperextension of the first interphalangeal (IP) joint )
  • Ulnar deviation of fingers
  • Constitutional findings such as fever, weight loss, etc
  • Monoarthritis of large joints can occur later
  • Tenosynovitis of palm(trigger finger0
  • Atlantoaxial joint involvement

Joints commonly affected in Rheumatoid Arthritis: (bilateral and symmetrically involved) 

  • MCP joints
  • Wrists
  • PIP joints
  • MTP joints
  • Atlantoaxial joint

Diagnosis is made with clinical signs and symptoms with corroboration from lab and imaging findings.

Anti-CCP, RF, and synovial fluid analysis are important lab investigations.

X-ray findings show -
soft tissue swelling, joint space narrowing, periarticular osteopenia, and bony erosions

Treatment of rheumatoid arthritis (RA)

DMARDs (Disease-modifying antirheumatic drugs) are the mainstay of treatment.

Methotrexate is the drug of choice in patients with RA. It can be used alone (in low disease activity) or with a 3-drug combination (in high disease activity) with other DMARDs such as hydroxychloroquine, sulfasalazine, and leflunomide (reserve drug).

  • It is a folic acid analong
  • Inhibits dihydrofolate reductase
  • Causes reversible myelosuppression
  • Leucovorin is used to manage myelosuppression
  • Can cause pulmonary fibrosis
  • Escalation with triple therapy involves - methotrexate + sulfasalazine + hydroxychloroquine
  • Glucocorticoids 

Other extra-articular manifestations are:

  • Sjogren's syndrome
  • Pericarditis, Mitral regurgitation
  • Pleuritis, Interstitial Lung disease
  • Vasculitis
  • Felty's syndrome
  • Diffuse large B cell lymphoma

The image below shows extraarticular manifestations of rheumatoid arthritis -

Related Pearl: Deformities in rheumatoid arthritis

Boutonnière deformity: Flexion of the PIP joint with hyperextension of the DIP joint. 

 

Swan-neck deformity: Hyperextension of the PIP joint with flexion of the DIP joint.

 

Z line deformity: Subluxation of the 1st MCP joint with hyperextension of the 1st IP joint. 

Piano-key movement of the ulnar styloid. 

Trigger finger due to flexor tendon synovitis. 

Related Pearl: Classification Criteria for Rheumatoid Arthritis - ACR/EULAR (2010)

Abbreviations:

  • ACPA, anti-citrullinated peptide antibodies;
  • CCP, cyclic citrullinated pep- tides;
  • IP, interphalangeal joint;
  • MCP, metacarpophalangeal joint;
  • MTP, metatarsophalangeal joint;
  • PIP, proximal interphalangeal joint;
  • RF, rheumatoid factor;
  • ULN, upper limit of normal.

Related Pearl: The 'most commons' of rheumatoid arthritis

Feature of RA Most common  
Involved joints MCP, Wrist, PIP(DIP spared) 
Extra-articular manifestation Subcutaneous nodules (mostly extensor surface)
Cardiac manifestation Pericarditis
Valvular abnormality Mitral regurgitation
Pulmonary abnormality Pleuritis

questions.text: A 6-year-old child abruptly develops fever, oliguria, periorbital edema and smoky cola-colored urine 2 weeks after recovery from a sore throat Following  are the microscopic findings, Light microscopy: Enlarged, pale glomeruli,  Electron microscopy: Epithelial humps. Which of the following is not a complication associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical features and microscopic findings mentioned are characteristic of post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN) and hypophosphatemia is not a complication associated with this condition.

Acute complications of post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN) result from hypertension and acute renal dysfunction.

  • Hypertension is seen in 60% of patients and is sometimes associated with hypertensive encephalopathy and  intracranial bleeding.
  • Acute renal failure can occur, which may require treatment with dialysis.

Other potential complications include the following:

  • Heart failure
  • Hyperkalemia
  • Hyperphosphatemia 
  • Hypocalcemia 
  • Hyponatremia
  • Acidosis
  • Seizures
  • Uremia

The PSGN patient presents with hematuria, red cell casts in the urine, azotemia, oliguria, hypertension, mild to moderate proteinuria, and edema (features of the nephritic syndrome). It usually appears 1 to 4 weeks after a strepto-coccal infection of the pharynx or skin (impetigo). It occurs most frequently in children 6 to 10 years of age. Poststreptococcal GN is caused by immune complexes containing streptococcal antigens and specific antibodies, which are formed in situ.

Findings in PSGN:

  • Light microscopy: Enlarged, pale glomeruli with diffuse mesangial proliferation and an increase in mesangial matrix. Polymorphoneutrophil (PMN) infiltration in the early stages.
  • Immunofluorescence: “Lumpy-bumpy” deposits of immunoglobulin and complement on the glomerular basement membrane (GBM) and in the mesangium. 
  • Electron microscopy: Electron-dense deposits, or “humps,” are observed on the epithelial side of the GBM.

  • To detect leakage of liqor from the cervical os in a case of suspected PROM

Advantege : It is self retaining.

questions.text: A 25-year-old female patient presented with “a palpable lump on the right of thyroid isthmus” which has been found for about 2 months. The patient has no thyroid disease history in her family. She was previously treated for Hodgkin's lymphoma with radiotherapy 5 years ago. O/E, Bilateral thyroid was slightly swollen. A hard lump about 20 × 10 mm was palpated on thyroid isthmus and moves up and down when swallowing. No vascular murmur could be heard. Routine blood examination and the level of thyroid hormones were normal. Which of the following is false regarding the underlying disease?

choices.text: The most common type of  thyroid tumor

questions.solution:
This patient with thyroid swelling, who was treated for Hodgkin’s lymphoma (possibly by radiation), is likely to have papillary thyroid cancer. Papillary thyroid cancer spreads through the lymphatic system.

Radiation is the established risk factor for the development of differentiated thyroid carcinoma (papillary and follicular). This association is stronger for papillary than for follicular carcinomas.

Papillary thyroid carcinomas are the most common forms of thyroid carcinoma and present in younger individuals. They commonly spread by the lymphatic system but have an excellent 10-year survival rate of 95%.

The risk of developing papillary thyroid cancer is high among individuals who:

  • Received external irradiation to the thyroid as children (< 5 years of age)
  • Received radiation for soft tissue malignancies, such as Hodgkin’s lymphoma
  • Have a history of acute environmental exposure
  • Familial syndromes (Cowden syndrome, Werner syndrome, Carney syndrome, etc)

Clinical features - thyroid swelling, "lateral aberrant thyroid"(cervical node invasion my metastasis), dysphagia, horseness

Diagnosis -

  • Thyroid function studies
  • Thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) suppression test
  • Thyroid ultrasound
  • Fine-needle aspiration biopsy (FNAB)(to confirm the diagnosis)

Histopathology -

  • Complex, branching, randomly oriented papillae with fibrovascular cores associated with follicles.
  • Usually dense fibrosis.
  • Papillae lined by cuboidal cells.
  • Nuclei are overlapping with finely dispersed optically clear chromatin (also called ground-glass), which gives a clear or empty appearance, therefore,the name ground glass or Orphan Annie eye nuclei.
  • Macronucleoli, eosinophilic intranuclear inclusions (represent cytoplasmic invaginations) and nuclear longitudinal grooves (represent folding of the redundant nuclear membrane, but nonspecific).
  • Stromal elastosis in 66% - often lymphatic invasion.
  • Psammoma bodies.

Psammoma bodies in Tumors:

  1. Papillary thyroid carcinoma
  2. Papillary renal cell carcinoma
  3. Ovarian papillary serous cystadenocarcinoma
  4. Endometrial adenocarcinoma (Papillary Serous Carcinoma)
  5. Meningiomas
  6. Mesothelioma
  7. Somatostatinoma
  8. Prolactinoma

Psammoma bodies in Benign Conditions:

  1. Endosalpingiosis
  2. Psammomatous melanotic schwannoma
  3. Melanocytic nevus

Prognosis - 

  • >95% 10-year survival rate
  • The prognosis of papillary thyroid cancer depends on several factors like
    • age (less favorable for patients older than 40 years),
    • the presence of extrathyroidal extension, and
    • stage of the tumor (presence of distant metastases).

Staging - 

  • AGES scoring system- Age, histologic Grade, Extrathyroidal invasion, and metastases and tumor Size. Predict the risk of dying from papillary cancer.
  • MACIS scale - Postoperative modification of the AGES scale. Includes Metastases, Age at presentation (<40 or >40 years old), Completeness of original surgical resection, extrathyroidal Invasion, and Size of original lesion
  • AMES system - classifies differentiated thyroid tumors. Includes Age (men <40 years old, women <50 years old), Metastases, Extrathyroidal spread, and Size of tumors (< or >5 cm). 

Note:

Risk factor for the development of thyroid lymphoma is non-Hodgkin's lymphoma (and not Hodgkin’s). Moreover, the absence of B-symptoms (fever, night sweats, and weight loss) makes the diagnosis of thyroid lymphoma unlikely.

Chernobyl disaster: The incidence of childhood thyroid cancer (specifically papillary) rose up to 100 times as compared to before the incident.

The image below shows papillary thyroid carcinoma with characteristic orphan Annie eye nuclei:

The image below shows psammoma bodies in papillary thyroid cancer.

Related Pearl: Papillary thyroid carcinoma

  • Papillary carcinoma is the most common thyroid carcinoma.
  • Most common in iodine sufficient areas, children and in those exposed to ionizing radiation. 
  • Mean age of presentation is 3rd-4th decade; more common in women than men (2:1)
  • Usually cold nodule on the scan
  • Branching papillae and follicles with the fibrovascular stalk, Psammoma bodies
  • Nuclear changes: Optically clear - Ground glass or Orphan Annie eye nuclei, pseudo-inclusions, nuclear grooves.
  • Lymph node metastasis is common
  • Lateral aberrant thyroid denotes a cervical lymph node invaded by papillary carcinoma.
  • Dysphagia, dysphonia and dyspnea are associated with local invasion
  • Most common sites of metastasis : lung > liver > bone > brain
  • Excellent prognosis, with a 10-year survival rate in excess of 95%.

Related Pearl: Gene alterations in thyroid cancer

questions.text: A 7-day old neonate is now under treatment for sepsis. He was born at 28 weeks of gestation and had developed respiratory distress syndrome at birth. You would schedule an evaluation for retinopathy of prematurity (ROP) in ________
questions.solution:
In the scenario above, the postnatal age of the premature infant is 1 week old, and therefore, the infant must be screened after 3 weeks (i.e., 4 weeks of postnatal age) as per the guidelines for the management of retinopathy of prematurity (ROP). 

ROP guidelines state that first examination should be performed between 4 and 6 weeks of postnatal age, or between 31–33 weeks of post-conceptional age (calculated as gestational age + post-natal age), whichever is later.

Screening

  • The first ROP screening should be done at 4 weeks if gestational age is 28–34 weeks or birth weight is <2000 g.
  • The first ROP screening should be done at 2-3 weeks if gestational age is <28 weeks or birth weight is <1200 g.

Ideally, 2 examinations must be performed; however, 1 may suffice if it shows complete retinal vascularisation.

questions.text: Which among the following is false about the procedure performed with this instrument ?

choices.text: Procedure is done with minimal cervical dilatation
Procedure is performed safely upto 14 weeks
Procedure can be done on an outpatient basis

questions.solution:
The image shows a Manual Vacuum Aspiration (MVA) Syringe. This is used to perform Manual Vaccum Aspiration (MVA) as a means of medical termination of pregnancy in the first trimester and is performed safely upto 12 weeks period of gestation with minimal cervical dilatation.

WHO recommends MVA upto 10 weeks POG (period of gestation) as procedure of choice.

It is a safe and simple procedure which is done on an outpatient basis. It can be done with local anaesthesia and is 98% effective. 

Other uses :

  • Incomplete abortion, Missed abortion
  • Molar Pregnancy
  • Blighted ovum
  • Endometrial aspiration.

questions.text: A male infant presented with distension of abdomen shortly after birth with history of not passing meconium. Subsequently a barium enema was done and given below. Which of the following statement is NOT true regarding this condition?

choices.text: It is uncommon in preterm infants.
It is associated with Edward syndrome.
It can also involve the small intestine.
It involves both the myenteric plexus and Meissner’s plexus

questions.solution:
The image depicts barium enema showing dilated right colon with a transition zone in the mid descending colon characteristic of Hirschsprung's disease. Hirschsprung disease is not associated with Edward syndrome.

Hirschsprung’s disease / Congenital aganglionic megacolon:

  • Hirschsprung’s disease is a developmental disorder characterized by the aganglionosis (absence of ganglion cells) in the myenteric (Auerbach) plexus and submucosal (Meissner) plexus in the distal colon and rectum.
  • Incidence: 1 in 5000 live births.
  • oss of function mutation in RET proto-oncogene is associated with Hirschsprung's disease
  • Boys are four times more frequently affected than girls.
  • Sites affected: Rectosigmoid (80%) > Splenic or transverse colon (17%) > Entire colon with variable extension to small bowel (8%).

Pathogenesis of Hirschsprung disease:

During normal embryogenesis, the neural crest cells migrate from the caecum to rectum. The enteric neuronal plexuses develop from these migrated neural crest cells. In Hirschsprung disease, there is an arrest in the migration of these cells, which leads to the development of distal intestinal segment that is devoid of Meissner submucosal and the Auerbach myenteric plexus. Hence this segment is referred to as the aganglionic segment. As a result, there is a lack of co-ordination in the peristaltic contractions and functional obstruction, which further leads to the dilation of intestine proximal to the affected segment, leading to congenital megacolon.

The abnormal/aganglionic bowel is the constricted distal segment, whereas the normal bowel is the proximal dilated portion. The area between the dilated and contracted segments is referred to as the transition zone.

Presentation:

  • Most infants present with abdominal distention and bilious emesis with failure to pass meconium within the first 24 hours of life.
  • Enterocolitis is the most common cause of death1. in patients with uncorrected Hirschsprung’s disease and may be manifested as diarrhea alternating with periods of obstipation, abdominal distention, fever, hematochezia, and peritonitis.

It is associated with other congenital defects, some of which include:

  • Trisomy 21
  • Smith–Lemli–Opitz syndrome
  • Shah–Waardenburg syndrome
  • Multiple endocrine neoplasm 2 syndrome
  • Neurofibromatosis
  • Neuroblastoma
  • Urogenital or cardiovascular abnormalities.

Investigations:

  1. Classic findings on contrast enema are the presence of an abrupt narrow transition zone between the normal dilated proximal colon and a smaller caliber obstructed distal aganglionic segment.
  2. Anorectal manometry is an important screening tool. It shows the absence of rectoanal inhibitory reflex.

A rectal biopsy is the gold standard for the diagnosis of Hirschsprung disease. It shows:

  •  Absent ganglia
  • Hypertrophied nerve trunks
  • Positive immunostaining for acetylcholinesterase
  • Calretinin immunostain­ing: superior to acetylcholinesterase staining.

Treatment:

Surgery is the treatment of choice for Hirschsprung disease.

A multi-stage approach is adopted, with colostomy in the newborn period, followed by a definitive pull-through operation after the child is over 10 kgs.

Definitive surgeries for Hirschsprung disease are as follows:

  1. Swenson procedure, where aganglionic bowel is removed and a coloanal anastomosis is performed.
  2. Duhamel procedure, where aganglionic rectal stump is left in place and the ganglionated normal colon is pulled posterior.
  3. Soave procedure: In this procedure, endorectal mucosal dissection is done within the aganglionic distal rectum and then the ganglionated normal colon is pulled through the remnant muscular cuff, and a coloanal anastomosis is performed.

Postoperative complications - constipation, soiling, incontinence and postoperative enterocolitis.

questions.text: Moraxella lacunata causes _______.
questions.solution:
Moraxella species are involved in causing angular conjunctivitis.

Angular conjunctivitis: Inflammation of the inner and outer canthi with excoriation of skin and collection of dirty-white, foamy discharge at the angles.

Causes: 

  • Moraxella axenfeld
  • Moraxella lacunata
  • Moraxella catarrhalis
  • Staphylococcus aureus (Rare cause) 

Source of infection: Nasal tract of healthy people and the nasal discharge of patients with angular conjunctivitis

Mode of spread: From the nasal cavity to the eye by contaminated hands and handkerchief

Treatment

  • Oxytetracycline for 10 to 14 days 
  • Zinc oxide inhibits proteolytic ferment.

questions.text: A 50-year-old female with a chronic history of Rheumatoid arthritis complaining of irritation in her left eye has the following finding. What is the condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical condition and the given image is suggestive of scleromalacia perforans. It is commonly associated with rheumatoid arthritis.

Scleromalacia perforans is a specific type of progressive scleral thinning without inflammation. It is typically seen in elderly women with longstanding rheumatoid arthritis. Despite the term 'scleromalacia perforans', perforation is extremely rare as the integrity is maintained by a thin layer of fibrous tissue.

Overall, 50% of cases of scleritis are associated with systemic diseases; the most common being connective tissue diseases. About 0.5% of patients suffering from seropositive rheumatoid arthritis develop scleritis.

Other associated collagen disorders are as follows:

  • Wegener’s granulomatosis
  • Polyarteritis nodosa
  • Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE)
  • Ankylosing spondylitis
  • Relapsing polychondritis

questions.text: A 35 year old man suffering from severe COVID-19 infection is showing signs of improvement. Which of the following is correct before discharging him?

choices.text: Discharge after 7 days from symptom onset & no fever for 3 days
Discharge after 10 days from symptom onset & no fever for 3 days
Discharge if SpO2>98% on 2 consecutive days
Discharge if repeat RT-PCR testing is negative

questions.solution:
Severe cases of COVID-19 (and immunocompromised patients) need to have clinical recovery and test negative by RT-PCR test before discharge.

Mild and moderate cases do not need an RT-PCR test before discharge. But, at the time of discharge, they are advised to isolate and self-monitor for a duration of 7 days.

questions.text: Which among the following  best describes "Sepsis"?

choices.text: Suspected or documented infection with SIRS score ≥ 2
Suspected or documented infection with SOFA score ≥ 2
Suspected or documented infection with qSOFA score  ≥ 1
Suspected or documented infection with LODS score ≥ 1

questions.solution:
Suspected or documented infection with SOFA score ≥ 2 best describes sepsis among the given options.

The Third International Consensus Definitions for Sepsis and Septic Shock (Sepsis-3) Task force defines sepsis as a "life-threatening organ dysfunction due to a dysregulated host response to infection".

There is no investigation of choice or gold-standard method to diagnose sepsis with certainty. However, the "Sepsis- 3" Task force has recommended certain clinical criteria and scoring systems to identify patients with infection at risk for sepsis.

The primary method to evaluate the risk of organ dysfunction (sepsis) in patients with suspected infection is by determining the  Sequential (sepsis-related) organ failure assessment (SOFA) score; which includes assessment of:

  • Circulation - Systolic BP & need for vasopressors; platelet count
  • Respiration - PaO2/FiO2 & need for mechanical ventilation
  • Mentation - Glasgow Coma Score 
  • Hepatic function - Bilirubin
  • Renal function - Creatinine 

Organ dysfunction is identified by a SOFA score of ≥ 2

The SOFA score is limited by it's requirement of multiple laboratory tests which makes it complex and time consuming. In order to simplify the scoring process, the "Sepsis - 3" task force recommended the quick sepsis-related organ dysfunction assessment "qSOFA" score. The qSOFA is a bedside prognostic scoring system which includes:

  • Systolic BP ≤100 mmHg
  • Respiratory rate ≥ 22/min
  • Altered mentation/sensorium

Each criteria carries 1 point. A qSOFA score of ≥ 2 is associated with increased mortality due to sepsis.

SOFA Vs qSOFA :

  • SOFA is a more comprehensive and accurate scoring system which is particulary superior to qSOFA in the ICU setting. 
  • qSOFA is a simplified derivative of SOFA for bedside assessment of individuals at risk for sepsis particularly useful outside the ICU. setting (i.e. ward / emergency department). However, note that it was originally designed as predictive tool that calculates the risk of death from sepsis rather than a diagnostic tool.

Thereby, the best description of sepsis based on "Sepsis -3" task force recommendations would be :

  • Suspected or documented infection with SOFA score ≥ 2  Or
  • Suspected or documented infection with qSOFA score ≥ 2

Other scoring systems for sepsis :

The Systemic Inflammatory Response Syndrome (SIRS) score is no longer recommended as is it not specific to infection.

The Logistic Organ Dysfunction System (LODS) score is not recommended as it is complex and has too many variables.

Sepsis lies in the continuous spectrum between infection & septic shock. Terminology like "severe sepsis" is no longer used as sepsis by definition is a severe maladaptive response to infection which can lead to organ dysfunction and death.

 

This MCQ has been revised based on the recommendations of "The Third International Consensus Definitions" for Sepsis and Septic Shock (Sepsis-3) Task force. The description has been updated to provide more clarity on Sepsis Scoring systems.

questions.text: A 54-year-old man comes to the dept to obtain a fitness for hernia repair surgery. The patient gives a history of hepatitis with an anesthetic agent in his previous appendectomy surgery but unsure of the name. Which would be the inhalational agent of choice for this patient?
questions.solution:
Halothane is one of the commonest cause of inhalational anesthetic-induced hepatitis 

Sevoflurane is the agent of choice in a patient with a prior history of halothane hepatitis.

Unlike the other volatile anesthetics, sevoflurane is oxidized to form hexafluoroisopropanol which is stable and does not covalently bind to proteins and cause hepatic injury.

Halothane hepatitis is immune-mediated due to antibodies against highly reactive trifluoroacetyl chloride which is a metabolite of halothane.

Other Options :

  • Like Halothane, Enflurane, Desflurane and Isoflurane also undergo metabolism to produce highly reactive intermediates that can covalently modify hepatic proteins which can cause severe hepatitis.

questions.text: A 18 year old male presented to the emergency department (ED) after a head-on collision with a vehicle traveling at 30 miles per hours (mph) while riding his bicycle. Patient initially presented with a Glasgow Coma Score (GCS) of 13, however, this rapidly deteriorated to a GCS of 5 within a four-hour window.  The doctor performed the CT scan and the image is given below. All of the following are indications for surgical evacuation EXCEPT ________ .
questions.solution:
This patient's presentation is consistent with acute epidural hematoma. Axial CT shows a hyperdense lentiform (biconvex) opacity consistent with an epidural hematoma. The patient would need surgical evacuation if the hematoma is more than 30 mL.

Extradural hematoma (EDH) / Epidural hematoma:

  • It is a collection of blood that forms between the inner surface of the skull and the outer layer of the dura, which is called the periosteal layer.
  • It is commonly associated with a history of trauma and associated skull fracture.
  • The source of bleeding- A torn meningeal artery (most commonly, the middle meningeal artery).
  • It is associated with an underlying fracture of the squamous part of the temporal bone.
  • The patient is initially unconscious from the concussive aspect of the head trauma. The patient then awakens and has a “lucid interval,” while the hematoma sub-clinically expands. As the volume of the hematoma grows, intracranial pressure (ICP) increases, and the patient rapidly becomes lethargic and herniates.
  • Investigations- CT and MRI.
  • It can cause a mass effect with herniation. 
  • Uncal herniation from an EDH classically causes ipsilateral third nerve palsy and contralateral hemiparesis.
  • They are usually limited by cranial sutures, but not by venous sinuses.

CT Changes :

  1. Typical hyperdense lentiform (biconvex) opacity with mass effect.
  2. Swirl sign:
    • It refers to the non-contrast CT appearance of acute extravasation of blood into a hematoma, for example, an extradural hematoma or subdural hematoma.
    • It represents unclotted fresh blood which is of lower attenuation than clotted blood that surrounds it.

The definitive management is craniotomy with emergency evacuation of the hematoma.

Surgical evacuation of the hematoma is required if:

  • the volume of hematoma is more than 30 mL
  • the thickness of the hematoma is >1.5 cm
  • midline shift is > 5mm
  • GCS is <8.

Related Pearl: Intracranial haemorrhage

Related Pearl: Intracranial Hemorrhage (ICH)

Extradural hemorrhage (EDH): 

  • Source: Arterial bleed
  • MC- Middle meningeal artery 
  • Cause- Trauma 
  • Clinical features: Lucid interval is characteristic 
  • CT – Lentiform opacity 
  • Treatment: A large or rapidly evolving EDH requires surgical evacuation

 

Subdural hemorrhage (SDH)

  • Source: Venous bleed 
  • Bridging dural veins 
  • Causes: Trauma, anticoagulants, antiplatelets, alcohol abuse, shaken baby syndrome 
  • Clinical features
    • Acute SDH: may be associated with lucid interval
    • Chronic SDH: drowsiness, headache
  • CT- crescentic opacity
  • Treatment: May resolve spontaneously or require surgical drainage

 

Subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH)

  • Source: Arterial bleed 
  • Causes:
    • MC – Trauma
    • 2nd MC – Rupture of berry aneurysm
  • MC sites: Terminal ICA, MCA bifurcation, top of basilar artery 
  • Clinical features: Thunderclap headache with neck stiffness +/- FND 
  • Investigations:
    • Non-contrast CT brain,
    • CSF xanthochromia (peaks in 2 days and subsides in 2 weeks) 
  • Treatment:
    • Clipping/coiling of berry aneurysm,
    • Triple H therapy – hypertension, hypervolemia, and hemodilution to prevent vasospasm 

 

Intraparenchymal hemorrhage- (MC type of ICH)

  • Source- Arterial bleed 
  • Causes:
    • MC – hypertension
    • Trauma, cerebral amyloid angiopathy, bleeding disorders, neoplasms, vascular malformations 
  • MC sites:
    • Putamen (basal ganglia)
    • Thalamus
    • Cerebellum
    • Pons 
  • Treatment:
    • Correction of any identified coagulopathy by infusing prothrombin complex concentrates, FFP or fresh platelets as required
    • Surgical evacuation for cerebellar hematoms >3 cm in size

questions.text: Which of the following is not true regarding the image given below?

choices.text: It is a drainage procedure for chronic pancreatitis.
Resection of tail with longitudinal pancreaticojejunostomy.
Failed due to restenosis and segmental obstruction of the pancreas.
Used in resectable tumors of the body or the tail of the pancreas.

questions.solution:
The image shows the distal resection of the pancreatic tail, with end-to-end pancreaticojejunostomy, i.e., Duval procedure.

Resection of tail with longitudinal pancreaticojejunostomy is known as Puestow Procedure.

It is a drainage procedure for chronic pancreatitis (Option A). It was developed on the basis of presumption that a single stricture of duct of Wirsung near the ampulla was responsible for the obstructive pathology and terminal drainage would treat the condition.

It consists of a distal pancreatectomy with roux-en-Y pancreaticojejunostomy. But it almost invariably failed due to restenosis and segmental obstruction of the pancreas due to progressive scarring. (Option C)

Note: This procedure is outdated and not in use due to low improvement rates. It is now used in resectable tumors of the body or the tail of the pancreas. (Option D)

Related Pearl: Drainage procedures for chronic Pancreatitis

Duval procedure: Distal pancreatectomy with Roux-en-Y pancreaticojejunostomy

Puestow procedure: Resection of tail followed by longitudinal pancreaticojejunostomy

  • Partington and Rochelle modification of Puestow procedure: Elimination of resection of pancreatic tail
  • A longitudinal pancreatotomy typically discloses segmental stenosis of the pancreatic duct and the presence of intraductal calculi in a patient with chronic calcific pancreatitis.
  • Following mobilization of a Roux limb of jejunum, a longitudinal pancreaticojejunostomy is performed to permit extensive drainage of the pancreatic duct system.

Related Pearl: Resection and Hybrid Surgical Procedures for Chronic Pancreatitis

Beger’s procedure: Duodenum-preserving pancreatic head resection (DPPHR)

  • The completed resection after transection of the pancreatic neck and subtotal removal of the pancreatic head, with preservation of the distal common bile duct and duodenum (Marked A).
  • Completion of the reconstruction of the anastomosis to the distal pancreas and to the proximal pancreatic rim by the same Roux limb of the jejunum.

Frey’s procedure:

  • The local resection of the pancreatic head with longitudinal pancreaticojejunostomy (LR-LPJ) provides complete decompression of the entire pancreatic ductal system. Reconstruction is performed with a side-to-side Roux-en-Y pancreaticojejunostomy.

Warren’s modification of Beger’s procedure:

Berne modification (Beger + Frey) involves excavation of the central portion of the head without formal division of the neck.

(image below)

Hamburg modification of Frey’s procedure

Note:

Surgical treatments for chronic pancreatitis

Resection

  • Pancreaticoduodenectomy (Kausch–Whipple procedure)
  • Pylorus-preserving pancreaticoduodenectomy (Traverso–Longmire)
  • Beger procedure
  • Near-total or total pancreatectomy

Decompression/Drainage

  • Duval procedure
  • Puestow–Gillesby procedure
  • Partington–Rochelle procedure (Puestow)
  • Izbicki procedure

Hybrid (resection+decompression)

  • Frey procedure
  • Hamburg modification
  • Berne modification

questions.text: A lactating mother in her 4th week post-childbirth came to the OPD with complaints of fever, localised breast erythema, swelling and pain of the right breast since 3 days. She also complains of difficulty in breastfeeding. What is the first line of treatment for this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette is suggestive of mastitis for which Dicloxacillin is the first line of treatment in lactating mothers.

The beta lactamase-resistant penicillins have been recommended in the treatment of mastitis. These include cloxacillin, dicloxacillin, or flucloxacillin.

Since penicillins are acidic, they are poorly concentrated in human milk, which is also acid. Hence cloxacillin and its congeners tend to treat cellulitis.

Erythromycin is given to women who are penicillin sensitive. If the infection is caused by resistant, penicillinase-producing staphylococci or if resistant organisms are suspected while awaiting the culture results, then vancomycin, clindamycin, or trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole is given.

Mastitis:

The most common organism causing breast infection is Staphylococcus aureus.

  • Symptoms appear in 3rd/4th week
  • Infection is almost unilateral
  • The immediate source of organism that cause mastitis is always the infant's nose and throat. (Not GIT)
  • Predisposing factors:fissures/abrasions/cracks in nipple
  • It is not a contraindication for breastfeeding. She should continue breast feeding from both breasts.
  • Treatment: Dicloxacillin for 10-14 days
  • If abscess is formed, surgical drainage is done under general anesthesia.

questions.text: The X ray abdomen image given below shows _______.
questions.solution:
• The X ray shows “double-bubble” sign which is suggestive of  duodenal atresia.
  • It is a characteristic plain abdominal radiograph finding in duodenal atresia, which is caused by the distension of a filled stomach and proximal duodenum.
  • Duodenal atresia results from failed recanalization of the intestinal lumen during gestation. A history of polyhydramnios is present; half of the infants seen with duodenal atresia are premature. The hallmark of duodenal obstruction is bilious vomiting without abdominal distention, which is usually noted on the 1st day of life.
  • Management: The initial treatment of infants with duodenal atresia includes nasogastric or orogastric decompression and intravenous fluid replacement. The typical surgical repair for duodenal atresia is duodenoduodenostomy.

Other options:

Coffee bean sign - It is a plain abdominal X ray finding In sigmoid volvulus.

Triple bubble sign - It is a plain abdominal X ray finding in jejunal atresia.

Cupola sign - It is seen on a supine chest/abdominal radiograph in the presence of pneumoperitoneum.Gas that rises within the abdominal cavity of the supine patient to accumulate underneath the central tendon of the diaphragm in the midline. It is seen as lucency overlying the lower thoracic vertebral bodies.

 

Coffee bean sign

Triple bubble sign

Cupola sign

questions.text: A 19-year-old girl was brought to the emergency. She had a panic attack and was breathing rapidly. On examination, she was found to have tachycardia and when the  BP measurement was attempted her hand was seen like in the image below.Which of the following acid-base disorders is expected in this patient?
questions.solution:
The patient has rapid breathing which leads to the washout of CO2. Hence, the acid-base disorders expected in this scenario is respiratory alkalosis. 

The image in the question shows carpopedal spasm or Trousseau sign.Carpo-pedal spasm on inflation of bp cuff is a clinical manifestation of hypocalcemia.

Alkalosis promotes the binding of calcium to albumin and reduces the fraction of ionized calcium in the blood leading to the given manifestation.

Symptoms and signs of hypocalcemia 

  • mild circumoral or digital numbness and paresthesia, carpopedal spasm, or laryngeal spasms and cardiac arrhythmias. 
  • ECG changes may show QT prolongation or QRS changes.

Causes of respiratory alkalosis:

A. Central nervous system stimulation:

  • Pain
  • Anxiety, psychosis
  • Fever
  • Cerebrovascular accident
  • meningitis, encephalitis
  • Tumor
  • Trauma

B. Hypoxemia or tissue hypoxia:

  • High altitude
  • Pneumonia, pulmonary edema
  • Aspiration
  • Severe anemia

C. Drugs or hormones:

  • Pregnancy
  • Salicylates
  • Cardiac failure

D. Stimulation of chest receptors:

  • Hemothorax
  • Flail chest
  • Cardiac failure
  • Pulmonary embolism

E. Miscellaneous:

  • Septicemia
  • Hepatic failure
  • Mechanical hyperventilation
  • Heat exposure
  • Recovery from metabolic acidosis

Related Pearl: Causes of Acid-Base Disorders
