questions.text:
A 50 year old male patient underwent a laparoscopic TEP hernia repair. During the procedure, stapling was done in an area damaging the external iliac vessels inadvertently. Which of the following is true regarding the area damaged?
  1. Medial border is bound by gonadal vessels
  2. Medial border is bound by Vas deferens
  3. Lateral border is bound by gonadal vessels
  4. Lateral border is bound by iliopsoas
questions.solution:
Injury to the external iliac vessels occurs during laparoscopic hernia repair in the TRIANGLE OF DOOM.

Medial border of the triangle of doom is bounded by Vas deferens and the Lateral border is bounded by lateral border of the vessels of the spermatic cord (gonadal vessels).

The triangle of doom is bounded

  • Medially by the vas deferens
  • Laterally by the vessels of the spermatic cord (gonadal vessels)
  • Inferiorly by peritoneal reflection

Important areas to be remembered during hernia repair:

  • Triangle of Doom
  • Triangle of Pain
  • Circle of Death 

Related Pearl: The triangle of doom

The triangle of doom is bounded

  • Medially by the vas deferens
  • Laterally by the vessels of the spermatic cord (gonadal vessels)
  • Inferiorly by peritoneal reflection

Apex oriented superiorly at internal ring.

The contents of the space include

  • External iliac vessels
  • Deep circumflex iliac vein
  • Femoral nerve
  • Genital branch of the genitofemoral nerve

Related Pearl: The triangle of pain/Electrical hazard zone:

The triangle of pain/Electrical hazard zone:

It is bounded

  • Superio-medially by gonadal vessels
  • Laterally by peritoneum
  • Inferio-laterally by the iliopubic tract

Contents:

  • Lateral femoral cutaneous nerve
  • Anterior femoral cutaneous nerve
  • Femoral branch of the genitofemoral nerve
  • Femoral nerves

Related Pearl: The circle of death/Crown of death/Corona mortis:

  • It is a vascular continuation formed by the common iliac, internal iliac, obturator, inferior epigastric, and external iliac vessels.
  • Accessory obturator artery which is a branch of inferior epigastric artery, arches over Cooper’s ligament and joins the normal obturator artery and forms a complete vascular ring.
  • Injury leads to torrential haemorrhage which is difficult to control.

questions.text: The triad of Situs inversus totalis, chronic sinusitis and bronchiectasis indicates the diagnosis of __________.
questions.solution:
This clinical triad is suggestive of Kartagener syndrome.

The primary defect in Kartagener’s Syndrome is primary ciliary dyskinesia (PCD). Patients with PCD (also called immotile cilia syndrome) have Kartagener triad, characterized by:

  1. Situs inversus totalis
  2. Bronchiectasis
  3. Chronic sinusitis

Primary ciliary dyskinesia

  • Defects in ciliary motor proteins leads to ciliary dysfunction. This causes the retention of secretions due to a failed mucociliary clearance mechanism. Clinically, this manifests as chronic sinusitis and recurrent infections that ultimately lead to bronchiectasis.
  • Ciliary function is necessary during development to ensure proper rotation of the developing organs in the chest and abdomen. In its absence, their location becomes a matter of chance. As a result, approximately half of the patients with primary ciliary dyskinesia have Kartagener syndrome, marked by situs inversus or a partial lateralizing abnormality along with chronic sinusitis and bronchiectasis.
  • Males with this condition tend to be infertile, as a result of sperm dysmotility due to impaired sperm flagella function.

Other options:

Churg-Strauss syndrome - Consists of asthma, fever, eosinophilia, vasculitis and granuloma.

Cystic fibrosis -  It is a multisystem disorder caused by the dysfuction of cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator protein (CFTR). It is an autosomal recessive trait with multiple clinical manifestations involving GIT, respiratory tract, pancreas, genitourinary tract and sweat glands.

Young syndrome - It consists of sinopulmonary disease and azoospermia.

questions.text: Which of the following is a method of assessment of airway?
questions.solution:
• Mallampati grading
  • Cormack and Lehane grading
  • Wilson’s scoring

All 3 of them are methods for assessment of airway

Various methods of airway assessments are

Mallampati grading: correlates tongue size to pharyngeal size.

Cormack and Lehane grading is based on laryngoscopy view

Wilson’s scoring is based on 5 factors: weight, upper spine mobility, jaw movement, receding mandible, and buck teeth.

questions.text: An 8-month-old infant who has recently been weaned off breast milk presented with incessant cry and blood-stained stool. An Ultrasound examination was performed and the findings are shown below. Which of the following statements is NOT true about this condition?

choices.text: The most common location is Ileocolic region
Submucosal lipomas can lead to recurrent intussusception.
New rotavirus vaccine is not associated with increased risk.
Inner tube is called as intussusceptum.

questions.solution:
The given condition is INTUSSUSCEPTION. USG image depicts target sign in intussusception. The currently approved rotavirus vaccines are associated with a slightly increased risk of intussusception.

Intussusception refers to a condition where one segment of the intestine becomes drawn in to the lumen of the distal segment of the bowel.

The most common location of intussusception is the ileocolic. Ileoileal location is seen postoperatively and in Henoch–Schönlein purpura.

  • most common in children, with a peak incidence between 5 and 10 months of age.
  • seen in infants during the weaning period following the introduction of new food, vaccination, or upper respiratory tract infection.
  • 90% of cases of intussusception in children are idiopathic in nature.
  • Lead points are more common in children older than 2 years of age and can cause recurrent intussusception. Some recognizable lead points are as follows:
    • Enlarged submucosal Peyer's patch; Meckel diverticulum; intestinal polyp; neurofibroma; intestinal duplication cysts, leiomyomas; submucosal lipomas; hamartomas; anastomotic suture line; enterostomy tube; hemangioma; or malignant conditions such as lymphoma or Kaposi sarcoma.
An intussusception is composed of three parts:
● the entering or inner tube (intussusceptum);
● the returning or middle tube;
● the sheath or outer tube (intussuscipiens).
 
The part that advances is the apex, the mass is the intussusception and the neck is the junction of the entering layer with the mass.
 
CT is the Investigation of Choice which shows Target Sign.
 
TREATMENT:
Children: Nonsurgically by radiological reduction.
Adult: Surgical resection of the involved segment and the lead point.

USG image depicts target sign in intussusception. The target sign of intestinal intussusception is also known as the doughnut sign or bull's eye sign. The appearance is generated by concentric alternating echogenic and hypoechogenic bands. The echogenic bands are formed by mucosa and muscularis whereas the submucosa is responsible for the hypoechoic bands.

Ultrasound signs include:

  • Target sign (Also known as the doughnut sign)
  • Pseudokidney sign: this is seen in the longitudinal section of the bowel. The edematous bowel resembles renal parenchyma and the mesentry which is dragged into the intussusception resembles renal hilum.
  • Crescent in a doughnut sign.

The intussusception appears as a sausage shaped mass in longitudinal plane or a target mass in transverse plane  on CT and USG. 

USG films showing Target sign (first) and Pseudo-kidney sign (second image) respectively.

In intussusception the occluding mass prolapsing into the lumen has been termed the coiled spring appearance (barium in the lumen of the intussusceptum and in the intraluminal space).

questions.text: Which of the following is seen with cannabis usage?
questions.solution:
Amotivation syndrome and flashback phenomenon are seen with cannabis usage.

Amotivation syndrome:

It is characterized by a person's unwillingness to perform a task in school/at work that requires prolonged attention. It is mostly seen with chronic usage of cannabis. Person with amotivation syndrome is usually described as apathetic, anergic, usually gaining weight and appearing slothful

Flashback phenomenon:

Person experience sensations related to substance intoxication after the short-term effects of the substance have disappeared. That is person relives the substance(cannabis) use experience without consuming it.

Flashback phenomenon is also seen in Lysergic acid diethylamide(LSD), phencyclidine whch are hallucinogens.

questions.text: Advantages of vertical abdominal incision for cesarean are all except _____
questions.solution:
Vertical abdominal incisions causes poor cosmetic results. This is because it doesn't follow Langer lines of skin tension and higher fascial wound dehiscence.

Related Pearl: Transverse and vertical incisions in Cesarean section

Transverse Incisions Vertical incisions

Advantages

  • Follows Langer lines of skin tension, so superior cosmetic results
  • Less Postoperative pain
  • Less fascial wound dehiscence
  • Low incidence of incisional hernias

Advantages

  • Quick entry
  • Minimal blood loss
  • Superior access to the upper
    abdomen
  • Wide operating space
  • Flexibility for easy wound extension if necessary

Disadvantages

  • High infection risks
  • Narrow operating space
  • Injury to neurovascular bundles
  • Reentry during repeat C-section is difficult due to scarring 

Disadvantages

  • Poor cosmetic results
  • Higher fascial dehiscence 
  • Higher incisional hernia rates
  • Greater postoperative pain

questions.text: Which of the following is not a part of Amsel's criteria?
questions.solution:
Amsel's criteria is used for the diagnosis of bacterial vaginosis and does not include the presence of WBCs on wet mount. The precence of WBCs is indicative of Trichomonas vaginalis or Candida albicans infection. Clue cells are visualised on wet mount in bacterial vaginosis. 

Amsel’s criteria  includes:

  • White, milky, nonviscous homogenous vaginal discharge
  • Vaginal diischarge pH > 4.5
  • Positive Whiff test - Amine like odour (fishy odour) on adding 10% KOH.
  • Presence of Clue cells (>20% of cells)

Related Pearl: Vaginal infections

Candida albicans

Symptoms Fishy odor, no itching Itching and burning Itching, burning
pH >4.5 >4.5 <4.5
Speculum No vaginal epithelium inflammation Strawberry cervix Inflamed-epithelium
KOH Positive Whiff test Whiff test can be positive. Pseudohyphae seen.
Wet mount Clue cells. No WBCs seen Motile trichomaonads, WBCs seen WBCs seen

questions.text: An intubated patient is on ventilator in an ICU. An intern who is to calculate the GCS-P score recognizes that the patient opens eyes to verbal command and is able to withdraw when painful stimulus is applied. O/E, both the pupils are reactive to light.  What is the Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS-P) score of the patient?
questions.solution:
In this case:

  • Eye opening to verbal commands: E3
  • In case of endotracheal intubation or tracheostomy, the verbal component of the score is denoted as "not testable" NT. Earlier in intubated patients, V score was denoted as VT. According to current update, the V score should be VNT, where NT stands for 'not testable'.
  • Motor response – withdrawal to pain: M4
  • Pupillary reaction - bilaterally reactive to light: P0

So, GCS score is E3 VNT M4 P0.

Revised Glasgow coma scale for head injury: Minimum GCS is 3, maximum GCS is 15.

Related Pearl: Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS)

GCS Score

  • 13-15 represent mild brain injury
  • 9-12 represent moderate brain injury
  • scores ≤8 represent severe brain injury

Minimum value: 3

Maximum value: 15

  • The motor score, is the best predictor of neurological outcome.
  • If an area cannot be assessed, no numerical score is given for that region, and it is considered “non-testable." (NT)
  • In case of endotracheal intubation or tracheostomy, the verbal component of the score is denoted as NT.

 

NOTE: 

A new parameter, "pupil reactivity score" has been added to GCS, and now, it is referred to as GCS-P.

P stands for "Pupils unreactive to light"

Pupils Unreactive to light Score
Both pupils 2
One pupil 1 
Neither  0

The pupillary score is subtracted from the GCS score to give the final value. Therefore, the range of GCS-P is 1–15.

questions.text:
Match the following:
  1. First-degree heart block
  2. Mobitz type 1 heart block
  3. Mobitz type 2 heart block
  4. Complete heart block
questions.solution:
The correctly matched pairs are 1-B, 2-D,3-A,4-C.

The different types of heart blocks are:

1.First Degree Heart Block: Prolonged PR > 0.2s, RR interval equal

2. Second Degree Heart Block:  missed QRS

  • Mobitz type 1/ Wenckebach: Progressive prolongation of PR interval, missed QRS
  • Mobitz type 2: fixed PR interval, missed QRS

3. Third Degree Heart Block/Complete Heart Block

  • Escape rhythm
  • RR equal, PP equal
  • P waves > QRS waves
  • No relationship between P & QRS

Related Pearl: Types of Heart block

questions.text: CT pelvis shows the image below. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Renal papillary necrosis refers to ischemic necrosis of the renal papillae.
  • Patients can present with both acute episodes and chronic renal papillary necrosis.
  • Calyceal or ureteral obstruction by sloughed papillae manifest with flank pain, haematuria and renal impairment.
  • Causes:
    • Analgesic abuse (phenacetin, NSAIDs, paracetamol: especially in combination)
    • Diabetes mellitus
    • Sickle cell disease
    • Pyelonephritis (especially in children)
    • Obstruction
  • Classical features on CT/IVP include:
    • Ball on tee
    • Forniceal excavation
    • Lobster claw
    • Signet ring

Illustration showing different signs of Renal papillary necrosis.

Different signs of Renal papillary necrosis seen on IVP.

  • (B) Central excavation with Ball-on-tee appearance 
  • (D) Lobster-claw appearance
  • (F) Sloughed papilla with clubbed calix
  • (E) Signet ring appearance

questions.text:
A 30-year-old female is brought to the emergency with burns sparing the chest, back, and face but involving both lower limbs circumferentially, genitalia, abdomen, and painful erythema in both palms. The burns blanch on touch. Based on the 2018 ATLS guidelines, what fluid resuscitation plan will you choose? (Patient weight: 50 kg)

ATLS- Advanced trauma life support

choices.text: 2.75L over 8 hours, followed by 2.75L over 16 hours
4.5 L over 8 hours, followed by 4.5 L over 16 hours
6 L over 8 hours, followed by 6 L over 16 hours
9 L over 8 hours, followed by 9 L over 16 hours

questions.solution:
The given image shows 2nd-degree burns as evident from the moist appearance of the skin, associated with pain and blanching on touch. The total volume of fluid needed is 5.5 liters of which 2.75L is given in the first 8 hours and 2.75L is given in the next 16 hours as indicated by 

Step 1: Calculating % of burns using the Wallace rule of nines

  • This includes only 2nd and 3rd-degree burns.
  • Right lower limb + left lower limb and anterior-posterior lower torso+ genitalia = 18 + 18 + 18 + 1= 55%

STEP 2: Calculating fluid using resuscitation formula for thermal burns

According to ATLS 10th ed. 2018 guidelines, the fluid resuscitation formula for thermal burns is 2ml/kg/TBSA% given IV.

Fluid requirement = 2ml x body weight x TBSA

                          = 2ml x 50 kg x 55 %

                          = 5.5 litres.

One-half of the calculated fluid need is given in the first 8 hours, and the remaining half is given over the subsequent 16 hours.

The rate of infusion for IV resuscitation fluid should be as constant as possible; sharp decreases in infusion rates can lead to vascular collapse and an increase in edema.

Superficial (epidermal) burns are excluded from this calculation.

This formula gives the total fluid requirement for 24hours. Half of this volume is infused in the first 8 hours, and the remaining half is infused in the next 16 hours.

Note:

The goal of resuscitation is to maintain the fine balance of adequate perfusion as indicated by urine output. It is important to understand that formulas provide a starting target rate; subsequently, the amount of fluids provided should be adjusted based on a urine output target of 0.5 mL/kg/hr for adults and 1 mL/kg/hr for children weighing less than 30 kg.

questions.text: In reproductive age group, vaginal cytology shows predominance of which layer of cells?
questions.solution:
Superficial cells are predominantly seen on a vaginal cytology amongst women in the reproductive period.

On cytology, they present as large cells with a pyknotic nucleus and are acidophilic on staining and it's predominance is related to the effect of Estrogen.

During pregnancy, the prolonged increase in progesterone leads to proliferation of the intermediate cells.

Reproductive period

Preovulatory phase

questions.text: A 40-year-old diabetic man who sustained a trauma to the scrotal area a few days back came to the hospital with sudden onset of pain in the perineal and scrotal area with blackening of the scrotum as shown in the image. Which of the following statements is false regarding his condition?

choices.text: Alcoholism predisposes to the development of this condition.

questions.solution:
The image above indicates that the patient has Fournier's gangrene, and despite best therapy, mortality rates are 50%. 

It is a polymicrobial infection and a type of necrotizing fasciitis of the perineum, external genitalia, and perianal region.  

Risk factors include immunocompromised states such as HIV, alcoholism, diabetes, etc and the infection may be precipitated by minor procedures in the perineal area, such as a bruise, scratch, urethral dilatation, injection of haemorrhoids or opening of a periurethral abscess. The infection spreads along the dartos, Scarpa's and Colle's fascia.

The sequence of events that lead to the development of gangrene are as follows: A mixed infection of the aerobic and anaerobic bacteria → fulminating inflammation of subcutaneous tissue → obliterative arteritis of the arterioles that supply the scrotal skin → gangrene

The testis is usually not affected, and hence, it is also called as "shameful exposure of the testis."

Clinical features include pain out of proportion to physical examination findings, fever, prostration and pallor. Cellulitis spreads rapidly and may be associated with eschars, necrosis, flaking skin, and crepitus.

It is a surgical emergency.

  • Initial management is by intravenous (IV) fluid resuscitation and use of broad-spectrum antibiotics.
  • Urgent wide surgical excision of dead and infected tissue is essential. 

 Despite best therapy, mortality rates as high as 50% have been reported.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man with a chronic history of erythematous skin lesions covered with grey scales comes for evaluation. A section of skin scrapping on histopathology shows the below image. What is the arrow pointing to?
questions.solution:
In this given image, the arrow points to a small collection of neutrophils seen within the stratum corneum. This a Munro's microabscess. 

Munro's microabscesses: These lesions are small collections of neutrophil polymorphs usually found within the stratum corneum. These lesions are indicative of chronic established psoriasis. Hyperkeratosis and parakeratosis are also seen here.

  • Other options such as camel foot or club foot appearance of rete ridges, acanthosis can also be present in psoriasis.
  • Pautrier's microabscesses occurs in Sezary Syndrome of Cutaneous T-cell lymphoma

questions.text: Grisel syndrome involves which joint?
questions.solution:
Grisel syndrome refers to nontraumatic atlantoaxial joint subluxation.
Grisel syndrome involves Paraspinal muscle spasm which occurs post adenoidectomy. It is one of the complications of adenoidectomy.

 

  • Patient complains of neck pain and develops torticollis. Mostly it is due to spasm of paraspinal muscles, but can be due to atlantoaxial dislocation requiring cervical collar and even traction.

questions.text: A 48 years old male was admitted with a chief complaint of dysphagia since adulthood. The patient had to drink a lot of water to help swallow solid or soft food. Complaint worsened in the last three months followed by odynophagia, nausea, and vomiting undigested, retained food. The patient also complained about heartburn and nocturnal cough. The patient had a history of weight loss but no anorexia, no prior history of corrosive ingestion. The patient was an active smoker. Physical examination revealed no abnormality. A barium swallow was performed and showed the following finding. Which of the following is not true regarding the given condition?

choices.text: Elevated LES pressure in esophageal manometry
Esophagectomy is considered in any symptomatic patient with mega oesophagus
decreased release of NO and VIP in the distal part of esophagus

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of achalasia cardia. It is treated by Heller's myotomy and not Nissen's fundoplication.

Achalasia cardia is a primary esophageal motility disorder characterized by the absence of esophageal peristalsisand impaired relaxation of the lower esophageal sphincter (LES) in response to swallowing. The LES is hypertensive in about 50% of patients. These abnormalities cause a functional obstruction at the gastro-esophageal junction (GEJ).

Achalasia cardia is characterised by decreased release of NO and VIP in the distal part of esophagus. Normally, the inhibitory neurons present in Auerbach's plexus in the distal part of the esophagus, release the NO and VIP, which relaxes the lower esophageal sphincter (LES). In achalasia cardia, these inhibitory neurons degenerate leading to decreased release of NO and VIP, which causes increased LES tone.

 The classic triad of presenting symptoms of achalasia cardia consists of:

  • Dysphagia (initially, liquid foods and then progresses to solid foods)
  • Regurgitation
  • Weight loss

As the food gets accumulated in the esophagus, patients may complain of halitosis. With further progression of the disease, the patients may develop pneumonia, lung abscess, etc.

Achalasia is a premalignant condition of the oesophagus. Adenocarcinoma, appears in the middle third of the oesophagus, below the air fluid level, where the mucosal irritation is the greatest. However, the most common type identified is squamous cell carcinoma.

Investigation:

The initial diagnosis is made by barium swallow or endoscopy, which shows the presence of dilated esophagus due to the constriction of the lower esophageal sphincter (bird-beak appearance). Periodic relaxation of the lower esophageal sphincter with continued drinking is a critical observation for distinguishing primary achalasia from pseudoachalasia—carcinoma of the gastroesophageal junction (a fixed, nonrelaxing obstruction).

The gold standard test to confirm achalasia cardia is esophageal manometry. Manometric features of achalasia cardia are as follows:

  • Incomplete lower esophageal sphincter (LES) relaxation
  • Aperistalsis of the esophageal body
  • Elevated LES pressure
  • Increased intraesophageal baseline pressures relative to the gastric baseline pressure

Treatment:

The most common surgical procedure for achalasia cardia is laparoscopic Heller myotomy in conjugation with partial fundoplication.

The POEM (per-oral endoscopic myotomy) procedure is a natural orifice technique that involves creation of a long oesophageal myotomy using a flexible gastrointestinal endoscope.

Esophagectomy is considered in any symptomatic patient with

  • Failure of more than one myotomy,  
  • Tortuous oesophagus (megaoesophagus),
  • Sigmoid oesophagus,
  • Reflux stricture that is not amenable to dilation.

Chicago classification of oesophagal motility divides achalasia cardia into 3 types. This classification is based on the readings obtained by High-Resolution Manometry (HRM).

The Chicago classification system of oesophageal motility:

Achalasia and EGJ outflow obstruction

Criteria

Type I achalasia (classic achalasia) - hypomotile esophageal body

Elevated median IRP (>15 mmHg),

100% failed peristalsis (DCI <100 mmHg·s·cm).

Premature contractions with DCI values <450 mmHg·s·cm satisfy criteria for failed peristalsis
Type II achalasia (with oesophagal compression) - simultaneous tonic contraction after swallowing  

Elevated median IRP (>15 mmHg),

100% failed peristalsis,

panesophageal pressurization with ≥20% of swallows.

Contractions may be masked by oesophagal pressurization and DCI should not be calculated
Type III achalasia (spastic achalasia) - massive, simultaneous, high-pressure contractionsof the distal esophagus

Elevated median IRP (>15 mmHg),

no normal peristalsis,

premature (spastic) contractions with DCI >450 mmHg·s·cm with ≥20% of swallows.

May be mixed with panesophageal pressurization

DCI: Distal contractile integral (mmHg·s·cm);

EGJ: Esophagogastric junction;

IRP: Integrated relaxation pressure (mmHg);

 

Related Pearl: Achalasia Cardia

Achalasia is a rare disease caused by the loss of ganglion cells within the esophageal myenteric plexus.

Their absence leads to increased tone of the lower esophageal sphincter, impaired relaxation of the lower esophageal sphincter (LES), and absent peristalsis.

Achalasia is the only true motility disorder of the esophagus.

Primary achalasia is due to ganglion cell degeneration and is thought to be due to an autoimmune process attributable to latent infection with human herpes simplex virus 1 (HSV1) combined with genetic susceptibility.

Secondary achalasia may arise in Chaga's disease

Clinical features:

  • dysphagia (solid and liquid food)
  • regurgitation
  • chest pain
  • weight loss
  • bronchitis, pneumonia, or lung abscess from aspiration

Differential diagnosis: Diffuse esophageal spasm, Chagas’ disease, and pseudoachalasia

On barium swallow: Bird beak-appearance

Investigation of choice: Manometry (most sensitive)

Treatment: Pneumatic dilatation and Heller myotomy

Related Pearl: Radiological findings in various GI disorders

Condition
Findings
Duodenal atresia
Double bubble sign (plain erect X-ray abdomen)
Jejunal and ileal atresia
Multiple air-fluid levels (plain erect X-ray abdomen)
Sigmoid volvulus
Coffee bean sign (plain erect X-ray abdomen)
Achalasia cardia
Bird-beak sign (barium swallow)

Related Pearl: Manometric findings in oesophageal disorders

Manometric Findings in Nutcracker Esophagus

  • Peristaltic esophageal contractions 2 standard deviations above normal
  • Amplitude > 180 mmHg and duration > 7seconds.
  • Normal peristaltic sequence

Manometric Findings in Diffuse Esophageal Spasm

  • Simultaneous, multipeaked contractions of high amplitude (>120 mm Hg) or long duration (>2.5 sec)
  • These erratic contractions occur after more than 20% of wet swallows.
  • Intermittent normal peristalsis

Manometric Findings in Hypertensive Lower Esophageal Sphincter-

  • Elevated LES pressure > 26mmHg and normal relaxation of LES
  • The esophageal body may be hyper-peristaltic or normal.

Manometric findings in Achalasia Cardia

  • Incomplete LES relaxation
  • Aperistalsis in the esophageal body
  • Elevated LES pressure ≥26 mmHg
  • Increased intraesophageal baseline pressures relative to gastric baseline

Manometric findings in ineffective esophageal motility disorders

  • Decreased or absent amplitude of esophageal peristalsis (<30 mmHg)
  • Increased number of non-transmitted contractions

questions.text: A  45-year old male presents with bilateral flank pain, gross hematuria. He has a family history of autosomal polycystic kidney disease. How many cysts should be present in the kidneys to diagnose him with ADPKD?

choices.text: At least 2 cysts in each kidney
At least 3 cysts in each kidney
At least 4 cysts in each kidney
Even a single cyst in each kidney

questions.solution:
2 cysts in each kidney should be present to make the diagnosis of ADPKD.

Since the genetic analysis is not known here but has a family history , diagnosis of ADPKD based on USG findings is generally made using the unified criteria by Pei et al in 2009:

Age (in years) Imaging findings
15 - 39  Total of ≥3 cysts, unilateral or bilateral
40 - 59 ≥2 cysts in each kidney
 

The age of the person is 45 and hence 2 cysts should be present in the kidney to make the diagnosis of ADPKD.

If the genetic analysis is known, then ultrasonographic diagnostic criteria for ADPKD1 is based on Ravine criteria:

  • At least 2 cysts in 1 kidney or 1 cyst in each kidney in an at-risk patient less than 30 years
  • At least 2 cysts in each kidney in an at-risk patient aged 30-59 years
  • At least 4 cysts in each kidney for an at-risk patient aged 60 years or older
 
 Adult polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD)

Inherited as an autosomal dominant trait with a mutation in the genes PKD1 (chromosome 16p, produces a protein called polycystin1) and PKD2 (chromosome 4q, polycystin 2).

ADPKD

  • Autosomal dominant trait 
  • Mutations in PKD1 and PKD2, which, respectively, code for polycystin-1 (PC1) and polycystin-2 (PC2). It is
  • Characterized by the progressive bilateral formation of renal cysts.
  • Many patients are asymptomatic until the fourth to fifth decade of life.
  • Kidney stones with more than half of the stones  composed of uric acid.
  • Intracranial aneurysm (ICA) occurs four to five times more frequently in ADPKD patients.

Clinical features: The disease does not usually manifest before the age of 30 years, and in some patients, it is never diagnosed.

  • Hypertension (most common)
  • Irregular upper quadrant mass
  • Loin pain
  • Hematuria
  • Infection
  • Uremia

 Extrarenal cysts in ADPKD:

  • Hepatic cysts
  • Pancreatic cysts
  • Seminal vesicle cysts
  • Arachnoid membrane cysts

ADPKD is an important cause of renal failure, affecting 10-15% of the patients who receive haemodialysis.

In autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease(ADPKD), cysts are least likely to be present in the lungs.

questions.text: Which one of the following has the highest ionization potential?
questions.solution:
Alpha particle is similar to helium with two protons and two neutron has the highest ionising potential but least penetrating ability and penetrates only superficial tissues to extent of 1 mm.

Gamma rays have the maximum tissue penetrating ability.

Related Pearl: Ionising and penetrating ability of radiation

  • Penetration power: Gamma rays > X-rays > Beta particle > Alpha particle (helium ion)
  • Ionising or tissue damaging ability: Alpha particle (helium ion) > Beta particle > X-ray > Gamma ray
  • Alpha waves have the highest molecular mass
